title: Canada's Largest Chinatown
reviews: Ah, Chinatown! I think it’s quite timely for the penning of this review. The current and ongoing pandemic adds another complex layer to this historic neighbourhood. Once described as an area “humming busily for more than a century with vivid colours, exotic cuisine and a vibrant culture,” the Chinatown of today is more reminiscent of a deteriorating ghost town. The streets are dirty, souvenir shops have been reduced to 2, windows are boarded up, and the vacancy rate currently sits at an elevated 17%. While still not nearly as bad as Vancouver’s notorious Downtown Eastside, you’d probably be forgiven if you thought of the two neighborhoods as one and the same. They almost look it. Indeed, this “decline” has been happening for some time, but there can be little doubt that the COVID pandemic has accelerated and exasperated these sharp social cleavages.Vancouver’s Chinatown wasn’t always “void of life.” When it was established in 1885, the neighbourhood was a proverbial beehive of activity. Immigrants began settling here following the completion of the CPR in the late 1880s and immediately made Chinatown an important social, cultural and business hub. Evidence of this early prosperity can still be seen today in the many historic buildings that make up Chinatown. Consider the Sam Kee Building, which was built in 1913, and has been recognized as the narrowest commercial building in the world; or, even consider the Wing Sang Building, built in 1889, which functioned as an important early business space. There are, of course, many more notable structures that hint at Chinatown’s rich and complex history, but you get the point. In more contemporary times, the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden and International Village have done much to try and revitalize the area.I rarely patronize Chinatown; in fact, the last time I actively explored the area – outside of visits to the Cineplex at International Village – was back in 2011, and that was just to partake in the Chinatown Night Market (RIP since 2014). Thus, when I came by with my partner a few weeks ago, I was genuinely surprised by what I saw: A ghost town with hints of Vancouver’s Downtown Eastside. If it wasn’t for the phenomenal Phnom Penh, I doubt we would’ve made the journey. Well, the CHINATOWN neon lights and monument to the Chinese railroad workers is nice.It’s hard not to compare Vancouver’s Chinatown to Victoria’s. The latter may be much smaller, but it’s cleaner, more robust and safer. Try walking in Victoria’s Chinatown after dark and then do the same thing here in Vancouver and you’ll see what I mean.Interestingly, when I wrote about Victoria’s Chinatown, I lauded it as demonstrating “just how far we’ve all come” because we’d “shifted from discriminatory practices [. . .] to one of inclusion.” Oh how quickly a pandemic can erase that. Now the Asian community in Vancouver – and elsewhere – has to walk on eggshells because of ignorance. Chinatown’s “Millennium Gate,” which is a symbolic representation of the neighbourhood’s journey through time, aptly highlights this, having been vandalized a few times over the last year. I’m sure the negative sentiment contributes to the ghostly feel of Chinatown these days.If we can overlook the social and economic negativity, there are still some nice things to see in Chinatown: The classic architecture, heritage buildings and monuments are definitely worth a look. And then there’s the restaurant scene: Jade Dynasty, Phnom Penh, Virtuous Pie, Devil’s Elbow, Jam Café and Catfe are all superb (okay, Catfe is more about the cats than the cheap cookies!). Just come to this neighbourhood and view it within context. Doing so, I think, will result in a more positive experience!

title: Ok
reviews: Chinatown it's like a ghost town after dark only a few restaurants are open East Pender I need to stay in after dark around here all the crazies come out

title: Ok
reviews: Chinatown needs to be cleaned up I live down here there are a few good restaurants down here graffiti on the wall

title: Chinatown needs a good cleaning.......
reviews: Chinatown is faced with a number of problems...a third of the frontages are closed....businesses are faced with exorbitant rents and taxes, the problems of the Downtown Eastside spill over into Chinatown, and I believe the city fathers(and mothers) honestly dont give a damn about the tourist areas of Chinatown and Gastown. Its almost like they want these areas to fail, so that the lowrises can be knocked down and highrises erected in their place. The Chinatown BIA should insist every shop/restaurant owner cleans their frontages daily, and the city should ensure the streets and alleyways are free of litter and detritus. The poor will always be with us, but they shouldnt have to live in filth either. The sidewalks of Chinatown need a good pressure wash, and the lamp standards(which are works of art) should be cleaned, repaired and painted where necessary. With a little TLC, Chinatown could be a great Vancouver tourist attraction again.

title: Where is everybody?!?
reviews: One of the highlights of my trips into Vancouver is getting off the Skytrain a few stops early so I can walk through Chinatown. But the place was noticeably deserted on my most recent trip. Perhaps it's Covid, perhaps it's not tourist season, but talk about closed! Sun Yat-Sen Gardens (my favourite) only open limited hours. Museum and Archives closed and locked, people using the front steps to roll up their sleeping bags. Just two examples, I could give more. I hope this will change soon, but in the meantime, be sure to check websites, or phone your favourite restaurant or attraction before making the trip.

title: What a sad state of affairs!
reviews: This was perhaps the most disappointing part of my visit to Vancouver.  I have never been to a Chinatown so void of life. On a Sunday afternoon, the streets of empty of foot traffic, most of the stores were either vacant or closed. While Chinatowns are often known for their less-than-sanitary conditions, the Vancouver Chinatown was disgustingly dirty and smelly. The smell of urine permeated the air and was repulsive. This was perhaps a great place in its prime, but now, Chinatown seems like an extension of notorious Downtown Eastside, albeit still a very mild version in comparison. I was thankful that I was walking through in broad daylight...I would not want to come here after dark. In comparison, the Chinatown in Victoria was far more charming. Even though it was much, much smaller, at least there was street life, and it was relatively clean, and most importantly, I did not feel unsafe there.

title: ~~ Sad Sad ! is it worth to Come Down ~~
reviews: It is so sad to see the glory day of the   this place ,it was hustle ,bustle ,full of life , family looking forward come down on the week end  shopping ,eating dim sum , gift shop ,tourists  every where , so happy those were the days !!!so sad  I come down with my family to see the exhibition at the Hon Hsing building  about  Chinese Immigration   **, A seat  at the Table **only temporary  ,they will build a museum in distance future   ,  90%  neighborhood shop all closing down , very dirty ,smelly  unsafe ,homeless  every where , not ever one traditional Wonton noodle restaurants around , lot of new  restaurants move in ,the neighborhood old buildings are gone replace a new mordant  new look in the area ,but still I say to my self  ,is it worth to come down here ??? if you do ,keep your eye open ,around the  surrounding   park in open area and a  lot of foot traffic !

title: A sea of human sadness
reviews: As with many Chinatown's there seems to be some shops and restaurants.There are some nice decorations on the lampposts and some interesting looking Chinese shops.I was however shocked at the massive amount of poverty on the streets and saddened at the numbers of people living on them. In the middle of the day there are rows of homeless people , some in tents some on nothing more than cardboard.This city has a huge problem.My heart goes out to the people who find themselves without a home.

title: Lunch
reviews: Like most Chinatowns in North America what remains are shops and restaurants. There’s some nice decorations. Just stay long enough for lunch.

title: Sketchy
reviews: Um, this place was unusually quiet and actually quite sketchy when we visited and we didn't feel very safe or comfortable at all....and we're NYers, so that's saying something.There are some interesting things to see but keep a wary eye and be on your guard.Spent maybe 45 minutes and couldn't wait until the hop on/hop off picked us up.I do think it's worth a visit just be very mindful or your surroundings. Junkies everywhere.

title: Really underrated, and safer than most suggest
reviews: I am a frequent Chinatown shopper, one who’s been going for quite a while now. Chinatown is chalk full of history and traditional Chinese culture you frankly don’t find anywhere else. The stores are fantastic, some of my favourites in the whole city, Ochi, Bamboo Village, The Tea Shop, there’s so many great small locally owned shops that will be a delight to anyone interested in traditional Chinese culture and products. All the store owners are fantastic and I enjoy speaking with them every time I visit. Chinatown does get a bad rap though and it’s a shame. I’ve been through here many times and haven’t experienced any issues, however some areas nearby Chinatown aren’t the safest to be in or walk through, so it’s best to stay around West Pender and the main areas. Aside from that I absolutely love it here, and I would highly recommend visiting whenever possible.

title: Better places to go
reviews: Chinatown no longer has any good Chinese restaurants or many businesses at all. I used to come here often, now I go to other places like Crystal Mall, Golden Village or anywhere else in Vancouver for good Chinese food and products. Don’t let the name fool you, you will find better places to experience Chinese culture in hundreds of other places throughout Metro Vancouver. Also, it feels dangerous at night as it is in a poorer part of Vancouver. However, it does have a lot of Chinese-Canadian history, so that is the only real reason for visiting.

title: Dirty and Homeless
reviews: This area of Vancouver was rundown and dirty. Many homeless people and drug addicts loitering. I would not walk here alone at night.

title: Continues to get a bad rap
reviews: Walked through here on my favourite trek when I visit the big city: get off the train at Main Street, walk by Science World, through Chinatown, then WEST towatds the Stadium or Waterfrront Stations. What is important here is Chinatown's proximity to some of the scarier areas in the downtown eastside, so tourists are encouraged NOT to judge Chinatown itself by its surroundings. Consider the world's shallowest building, the traditional medicine shop, and the amazing Sun Yat-Sen Garden. Put another way: Chanatown good, areas to north not so much.

title: Go to the Garden
reviews: It's been a Chinese neighborhood for decades, so there is history here along with the great food.  The real estate is becoming valuable so change is happening.  The garden is the gem, so go!

title: Dirty - Stay Away at Night
reviews: Chinatown in Vancouver is dirty and filled with evidence of drug use.  It must be a favorite place for the homeless population. I would suggest that you go during the day if you go at all.  This place needs to be cleaned up and does not represent what we visited in the rest of the city.

title: Amazing Chinatown
reviews: I recently had the opportunity to see Chinatown. I found it a unique and exciting visit  the stores had an abundance of items for me to check out. The people were very friendly and were happy to help me. Even the street people there were helpful in guiding me to certain stores. I have constantly heard all the bad things about how bad and dirty it is, about how it’s dangerous to visit the area but i am extremely happy i ignored that and went to see it for myself. Yes the area has some issues but so does every other place in the world. I have been travelling extensively my whole life and been to areas on this planet that makes it look tame by comparison. So my advice to anyone wanting to see Chinatown, but is deterred by the bad stigma attached to it. Ignore it all and go see for yourself to make your own judgement. I’m sure you’ll be pleasantly surprised and will take away fond memories of the place.

title: Disappointing!!
reviews: Stay away! Too many drug addicts. Needles on the streets. Drunk/wasted are all over the area. Not much restaurants to choose from. Seemed deserted. Someone needs to clean up this place.

title: Great to find some Chinese food
reviews: You can get Chinese food especially Dim Sum & noodle here at Vancouver Chinatown. Happen to visit on Sunday so most of the shops are closed.

title: Disheartened
reviews: Joined the hop on hop off bus, wanted to go to China town to see the gardens!!!!!!!!! within 50 walking paces we were in the middle of what I would call Hell on Earth, Vancouver has obviously gathered up all drug takers, mental health problems, homelessness and dumped them in China town!!!!!! I have never seen anything like it in my life, I was emotionally upset for days after this encounter, get your act together Vancouver and start providing proper services for these people, I am very grateful it was in daylight that we arrived in China town, still never seen the gardens.

title: Visit Chinatown
reviews: The Hop On Hop Bus stopped here. We hopped off. We went to the garden and to the entrance gate but did not walk the opposite direction. We wish we would have known to do so. We felt as though we were missing something. Our friends went there several days before us and said they had some great food. Therefore, I am rating it a 5.

title: Disappointing
reviews: This is a very disappointing China town and probably the worst I have visited around the world.  It covers a large area but has very little appeal.  It is certainly not attractive and does not have a 'buzz' or any form of excitement.  It could easily be just any area with numerous shops and restaurants, some empty and hardly any that were busy, in any part of town.  Maybe I expected too much.We walked there from Downtown and found ourselves walking in streets lined with homeless people and where others were openly taking drugs.I did not see anything to recommend it other than the gardens.

title: Not pretty
reviews: Feel mixed about this area, thought it would be visually better on the eye but parts are very rundown and border on one of the least desirable areas of the city. The large monumental arch is impressive but not as good as the ones near my home in Liverpool and Manchester.

title: mixed experience
reviews: We had very some good food here, but not as bustling as maybe it once was. Some of the surrounding areas are rather gritty, due to drugs and homelessness.

title: Beautiful, historical, and so much food!!!
reviews: We walked around enjoying the food, the people and historical sites here in Vancouver's China Town.  I would come back again if I were in the area.China town was established in the 1890s and has seen ups and downs as all cities have, but the people here are great and the history is riveting.

title: Interesting Part of Town
reviews: I recommend a walking tour of this area, especially the garden.  Very vibrant area, some good restaurants.  It's low income but feels quite safe on our walk around.

title: Great fun
reviews: Fantastic shops with great prices. Fantastic restaurants - huge portions so dont order to much. People are lovely but it is a busy part of town.

title: Not great
reviews: Some nice places but we walked through some seedy places getting there . Sun Sat Yen park very interesting So Sad to see all the homeless street people .Confronting to see people who appeared to be taking drugs in broad daylight .No signs of any police presence .Would not recommend a visit unless in a group .

title: Interesting
reviews: We enjoyed our visit to Vancouver ChinaTown.  The area is not really big so we were able to walk and stroll through it in a short amount of time.  We did go in to a couple of shops.  Mostly we just liked walking and absorbing the are!

title: What happen to the Good Old Day ? Where is all the Wonton and Congee restaurants gone ???
reviews: Vancouver China Town during the 60's 70's 80's ,is one of the busy place in Vancouver ,great noodle house ,restaurants ,tea house  , BBQ shops every corners ,place is life with hustle & bustle , sad to say ,time change ,,,,,, Vancouver China Town is not the same since the early days ,of course the place still have the traditional Hong Kong style bakeries ,dim sum restaurants , the Dr.Sun Yat Sen garden , and the area is  so so clean  , still homeless and junkies  around ,lot of new hip restaurants open up .yesterday I notice  there is No More traditional  Wonton Noodle  restaurants around !in China Town ?WOW ! that very shock me , very  disappointed to see , but still a place to see if you visiting  ,but  do not exceeded any expectations too high !

title: Caution high crime area
reviews: Visited Chinatown today. I have visited a number of world cities but never felt so unsafe. Everywhere we walked we were confronted by scenes of down and out drug affected people.  It was quite concerning and couldn't wait to get out of the area.  Much worse than the strip on Granville St. People were shooting up, passed out, zombies on every corner, in every doorway and alley. It was horrible and this was day time.  Exercise extreme caution venturing around this area.

title: Oldest Chinatown 3rd latgest
reviews: A few blocks away from Chinatown looked sketchy. We saw the monuments, lots of restaurants and shops, and went into the beautiful Dr. Sun Yat Sen Park.

title: Chinatown IS cool
reviews: Everyone saying how scary Chinatown is, May not understand its potential to the full extent. Being around a couple junkies and homeless people rly isn’t a huge deal. It’s important to remember how much more vulnerable homeless people can be than us.  I’ve lived East side all my life and never once have had a problem with the street people I’ve encountered. Actually, many of them are quite nice!! It’s fair to be more on edge in those areas, as it’s natural to have your instincts up around those we are conditioned to feel are more of a threat to us, but Chinatown is one of my favourite places in the city! Beautiful old buildings, cool local businesses (try to avoid businesses and company’s in the area that contribute to gentrification!), and delicious Chinese and Asian food. Not to mention my fav dollar store in town, Yoko yaya! which has a fun assortment of East Asian candies and drinks. Also if you climb to the top of certain parkades in Chinatown, the view of the city is amazing!!!! Incredibly photogenic for your instagram. I understand for those who prefer more luxurious vacationing, like expensive shopping and dinning, and fancy rich parts of town, then Chinatown ISNT for you. If you are a cool down to earth person who likes to interact with locals, learn the history of the city, learn our history of Chinese’s immigrants that helped build our society, then HEAD ON DOWN!!! Oh ya also you can visit the skinniest building in the world in the Chinatown! Kinda cool

title: Has really gone downhill since last visit
reviews: My husband and I visited Chinatown since he had visited in 1994 and enjoyed it. He was horrified walking around. I was too, but I hadn’t been there before. I clutched my purse and was nervous the entire time. There was a lot of sketchy people walking around, and it smelled like urine. The only positive was that we ate at Phnom Penh, which was good food. We booked it out of there after we ate though. After reading other reviews, maybe we just didn’t go to the right part? Too bad it’s not clear on where to visit in Chinatown, just to visit this tourist attraction. We won’t be returning unless it vastly improves.

title: Absolute No Go - one of the worst places in the world
reviews: I've gone there with my family and kids after following a recommendation by tourism Vancouver on what to do in 3 hours in Vancouver. Had the worst experience in my life. We're all still in shock. Already complained at the tourist office and asked them to remove the recommendation on their website and to alert tourists not to go to the Hastings/Carrell/Main area.

title: Sad what this has become.
reviews: China Town is now the home to most of the homeless, drug addict peoples in Vancouver.  it is sad, but if you are on a vacation and want happy stress free adventure, then skip China Town.

title: Avoid at all costs...
reviews: I saw a man who had passed out standing up, with a needle literally still stuck in his arm.  The closest thing I can liken it to is the "Walking Dead" ride at Universal Studios in LA - random zombie like beings popping out everywhere.Oh, and it smells horrific.In 3 weeks touring Canada this is the only place that I really, really did not feel safe in.

title: Not a nice experience at all
reviews: We had heard that Vancouver had a Chinatown worth seeing. We’ll, I wish I had read the excuses before we visited. We parked our car at a parking garage and decided to walk into Chinatown. The area seemed ok but as we walked further into Chinatown, it became very shady. There were drug addicts, homeless people, and prostitutes on most corners it seemed. We walked for about 30 minutes and as area got even more shady, we decided to turn back walk back to our car. Please, do yourself and your family a favour, stay away from this part of Vancouver.

title: Drug use everywhere
reviews: The garden was nice but the homeless and drug users where everywhere. They were shooting up heroin in the garden pathway.

title: Nope. Nope. Nope.
reviews: Came around the corner from a great dinner at Bao Bei and were walking toward Gastown with an increasing sense of doom as the smell of urine and the amount of people passed out or screaming obscenities increased. At the intersection of Hastings and Columbia there were no less than 15 drugged out souls on each corner and my husband and I made eye contact and silently agreed to get out and away as quickly as possible. In short, if you’re looking for needles, poop, rubbish, prostitutes, being screamed at, and/or being aggressively panhandled, head over to this part of town. Otherwise, avoid at all costs.

title: Give This Place A Miss
reviews: A very squalid area of Vancouver, full of drug addicts and homeless. Overall very dirty and worth avoiding.

title: Horrendous Vancouver Chinatown!!!!!
reviews: Thinking since there is so many Hongkonger & Chinese from other part of world migrated to Vancouver Chinatown in the early years it must be amazing. But I was totally wrong!!! IT'S THE WORST CHINATOWN EVER !!! I am utterly gutted shocked that how is this possible in Canada!!! When we arrived at the entrance we sense something is not quite right, there was graffiti everywhere and it's not bustling. We continue to walk in we could smell urine we thoughts this is not quite right, but continue a little further in and we knew that this is not good we decided to turn left to East Hasting street to Gastown. What a BIG BIG mistake, we were traveling with kids, we will walking into a horrified scene of drugs, needles, smelly urine, load of drug addict people lying and walking everywhere. It's almost the scene of a movie the walking dead! Because its day time we walking calming and as fast as possible. We manage to get out to Gastown.  Why are the government of Canada not doing anything about Chinatown and East Hasting street??? It completely outrageous to have this going on! I been to amazing chinatown in San Francisco, New York , Sydney, Melbourne, Houston & London. Vancouver government should be very much ashamed on them for not doing anything !!! I am still totally gutted that how could Canada the land of good things allowed this?????? Shocking!!! PPPPPLEASESSSSSSSS DO NOT GO TO CHINATOWN IN VANCOUVER EVER !!!Show less

title: Somebody help this area
reviews: This is a very run down dirty area of Vancouver.  It needs a major face lift.  We were excited to walk into the area and find good Chinese food but the area was trashed and scattered with homeless crack heads.  In fact that is a huge problem in Vancouver.  The night before we literally watched 3 people shooting up while HUNDREDS more were falling all over the city.  Vancouver, What the heck!  Clean up your city!

title: Collusion?
reviews: What the hey Vancouver, BC!!! Do real estate developers have their hands deep down the pants of your city leaders,  planners and council members promising a “happy ending”? How are we supposed to read law enforcement ignoring the hundreds of drug addicted folks throughout the area shooting up, urinating and defecating in public? Has law enforcement been asked to ignore the area in hopes of driving tourism dollars out of Chinatown so hardworking Chinese have to give up and sell out? Take a lesson from your history books where you will remember you didn’t do such a great job with your indigenous people and asked yourself where this unbridled greed is leading to. It was sad to see the neglect being committed by your city leaders when it comes to maintaining the cultural jewel that Chinatown once was. I don’t blame this on law enforcement as they are instructed by city leaders. We saw zero police presence during our multi hour visit to this area and saw people openly shooting up on sidewalks.   Shame on all of you.  This was not the Chinatown we remember from twenty years ago.

title: I wished I hadn’t
reviews: For some reason it’s been very difficult find a Chinatown as good as the one in San Francisco. I also mustn’t have been asking google or Trip Advisor the right questions either, cause we wandered down there today totally unprepared for the sad state of affairs that is the Chinatown precinct of Vancouver. Just two streets over from the beautiful stores and cafes of the Gastown district lies the worst of tales to be told out of this city. Streets are lined with poor unfortunate folks, beggars, junkies, hustlers and hookers. The first warning signed were the street corner being hoses down where there was a large gathering of people with their possessions in carts, the smell of urine was overwhelming. I had my two adult children 22&24 with me and they we conceded for our safety. We saw people injecting, dealing, urinating and tripping out. At one stage two squad cars rocked up sirens blasting and someone’s day was about to get worse. We tagged along with a tour group figuring there was safety in numbers and hightailed it out as fast as we could. The whole scene was almost surreal and very very sad. I am going to find a way to get to the Chinese Gardens which seems to be at least one good thing the area has going for it.

title: Avoid this area while in Vancouver
reviews: Reading about China town made me want to visit last week as I had visited China this past year. My daughter, her husband and I decided to check it out on our way to bike ride in Stanley Park. What a mistake....and our experience clouded our entire day. First, the streets smell of urine, so bad you have to hold your nose. A visit to Tim Hortons was a bust....the store was filthy dirty, we didn’t even bother to order. Tables were covered with garbage, floor the same, washroom out of service. Our saddest experience though was coming upon a fresh faced young girl, huddled in a door way shooting up, syringe still in her arm. This scene haunts us to this day. I wanted to say something so badly, and hugged my daughter a little tighter the rest of the trip. That young girl was someone’s daughter, and how sad to see her sitting among all the filth destroying her life.

title: This was declared a National Historic Site of Canada in 2011
reviews: We walked the entire length of Chinatown on Pender Street while out exploring and going to visit the Botanical Gardens.  This is the biggest Chinatown in Canada and apparently ranks #2 behind San Francisco's Chinatown.   There was much to admire and appreciate here.The huge Millenium Entry Gate into Chinatown is a thing of beauty.  The red lampposts with gold dragons are so special; we admired the gracefulness of the curving figures.  Some of the historic buildings, like the Wing Sang building (1913) and the Cheng Wing (1926) are beautifully maintained.There was much that interested us, like the Sam Kee building, Shanghai Alley, and the beautiful memorial to soldiers and railroad laborers but its geographical boundaries cross over into the DTES (Downtown Eastside) which is ground zero for mental illness and drug use.  Since the 1980's, the Vancouver government instituted a policy of de-institutionalizing mental health care hospitalizations and they made their way here.  The zone for the DTES includes parts of Gastown as well as Chinatown.We stopped in at a street market while walking to Chinatown.  Nothing interested us but we did see a vendor selling marijuana baked goods but they were gluten free (that has to account for something).  A young woman on the sidewalk was being cuffed so paramedics could administer medical treatment to her.  Sometimes it is hard to look away.In San Francisco's Chinatown, the shops were more interesting and there seemed to be a flow out onto the street with sights, sounds, and (good) smells that we just didn't find here.  That aspect of "bringing it out to the street" just was lacking.

title: Chinatown
reviews: We walked through the main gates and then proceeded to enjoy the gardens, Dim-Sum, and shopping. The entire family enjoyed exploring the area.

title: Chinatown gets a bad rap
reviews: The area between the bustling Gastown/cruise terminal/downtown is a short distance, but it is NOT Chinatown.  That short area is filled with yukky street people.  Take a cheap taxi to Dr Sun Yat Sun's garden and museum.  Walk the few blocks to Main St to see ethnic stores and restaurants.  All that is interesting there can be seen in an hour, plus time to dine.  One of the best Chinese restaurants anywhere is The Pink Pearl on Hastings St.  Don't walk there, take a taxi.The REAL Vancouver Chinatown, however, is called Richmond--the area around the YVR airport.  There you may see modern Chinese super markets and a variety of furniture/arts/craft stores and specialty malls.  The weekend night market there will transport you to China.

title: Not so impressed.
reviews: We went here the second day of our trip. hop on hop off tour takes you right there. We were fairly disappointed in the area. Right next to it was Hastings street. DO NOT walk from China Town to Gas Town. NOT SAFE. Take the time to get back on the bus and go that route. There are many more places to visit that have great restaurants off Robson and off Cambie.

title: Yipes!!!
reviews: I was a social worker in Chicago on the west and south sides during the crack/heroin epidemic era. I NEVER saw anything like this!  Block after block of heroin addicts, prostitutes and stolen goods for sale. Urine and feces on the street. I was completely taken aback and my kids were in tears. It was the saddest thing I've ever seen. Avoid.

title: Frightening - DO NOT BRING YOUR FAMILY - NOT SAFE!
reviews: We were interested in checking out Chinatown after seeing online that there were shops and places to enjoy traditional Chinese cuisine. IT IS NO MORE THAN STREETS FILLED WITH CRACK ADDICTS and HOMELESS. We enjoyed the traditional Chinese gardens and then no more than a block away found ourselves on streets filled with needles, aggressive homeless people, garbage. It was truly scary. There is an ignored problem in Vancouver and it is all concentrated in Chinatown. PLEASE do not go there.

title: Very uncomfortable!
reviews: I’ve traveled around a lot and never before have I been in an area that I felt so uncomfortable that i lost interest in seeing the sights. We were told by locals that Chinatown was rough and to stay off of Hastings street but if you go through the main gate, it was worth the walk. I disagree. Getting to the gate had us walk through areas where people were openly shooting up heroin  not just one person but lots of people. We were optimistic that once we walked through the Chinatown gate things will get better. We were wrong. The streets were filled with The homeless and downtrodden. We walked up a block hopeful and quickly turned around. It took 2 to 3 blocks before we were in an area that made us comfortable to walk in. There are many other interesting places to visit in Vancouver. My advice is to skip the Chinatown area.

title: So that’s what a man defecating in the street looks like
reviews: We were on one of those hop on hop off bus tours, which included the Chinatown stop. We were told of a beautiful Chinese garden that was featured in national geographic. the garden was closed so we explored the rest of the district. We were met with no less than 40-50 individuals who clearly were using, many many homeless, bared up shops, a man attempting to defecate in the street, witnessed 2 separate drug dealings and a man pick up 2 needles from the ground. Pretty much stayed for twenty seconds. You felt really unsafe and felt like a target. Please please AVOID AT ALL COSTS especially if you have small children. Even the Starbucks was like f*** this and closed down. It was certainly....an experience. God bless toilets.

title: DO NOT GO TO CHINATOWN FOR YOUR SAFETY
reviews: Me and my mom and sister got off a tour bus and what we saw was lots of graffiti. Trash. Drug needles and homeless people using them openly. Felt very unsafe and held my phone in my pockets because i was very worried about being pick pocketted. Just avoid it at all costs there is nothing pretty to see. Just dont.

title: Addicts and Homeless
reviews: After walking around Downtown and Gastown, 4 of us went to Chinatown. Sadly, what we saw besides Millennium Gate and the Jack Chow Building were many many homeless people and addicts. The smell was of urine and the atmosphere felt threatening. We all live in major cities but this area was truly sad. My recommendation is to skip this part of Vancouver.

title: Thanks to Trip Advisor I modified my plans
reviews: Like many others on here I was going with guide book recommendations even though the Chinatown where I live is not at all what it perhaps once was. Anyway...I had decided to go to Gastown and wasn't super excited about that area, especially when seeing the obviously pregnant woman with fresh track marks shuffling along. It soon became clear to me that there is a grey area between Chinatown and Gastown, except for where stores are concerned - that's pretty black and white. Chinatown, with the exception of Hastings St., was just depressing but I didn't feel unsafe per se. Hastings St. - while I didn't go by it on foot I did see it from the car as a friend took me down there. That was just an open air market for drugs and stolen goods and I absolutely had no interest in exploring that.I think those that post on here saying they don't see what the issue is with Chinatown perhaps went around the gate and not much further. Because I have plenty of international travel experience and have been in all sorts of situations I can say that I can handle a lot. I'm aware that having a roof over my head, food on the table, and no addictions (unless coffee or chocolate count) puts me in a much better spot than many people, but do I want to spend my time in a place like this? No.

title: Perhaps a work in progress?
reviews: Having visited Chinatown in other cities, I arrived with some expectations: lively atmosphere, streets offering great restaurants, interesting shops.  Despite what tour books say, Chinatown, Vancouver, does not need to be on anyone's "must see" list.  Aside from Sun Yat Sen Park and a good dumpling place, there was nothing about this neighborhood that I enjoyed. One very unfortunate feature, which has nothing to do with the Chinese cultural presence, is that a couple of the main streets (e.g. Hastings) are thronged with homeless people, to the extent that it was difficult to navigate the sidewalks at times. Not that I would like to repeat that part of my touring experience, but I was almost "glad" to have seen this less-than-perfect side of Vancouver, a city that is frequently rated as an almost ideal place to live.

title: not so much fun
reviews: We got here on the hop on hop off bus and got dropped off at a very dirty area full of full homeless folks living on the street. It is not somewhere I would ever have anyone visit.

title: Chinatown is ok but avoid going past Hastings St.
reviews: I’ll save you some time - go to the Chinatown plaza 3rd floor for amazing dim sum!! The free Chinese garden is nice but it’s right next to the worst part of town - and Canada! East side is THE WORST PART OF CANADA! We took a wrong turn out of the garden and ended up there with four children 15 - 12 months old and we had to high tail it out!!

title: Lots of Restaurants
reviews: This is truly the old Chinese neighborhood, still an important Asian presence in this changing city.  The best feature is the traditional garden.  Oh, and lots of good food.

title: Avoid this Area
reviews: We passed through on a tour bus.  Tourists should avoid this area, make sure you know where it is because if you walk too far through Gastown, I think it leads into China Town.  Looked very unsafe.

title: Blighted Area
reviews: Vancouver’s Chinatown is located in a blighted area of the city. The area is characterized by vacant storefronts, filth, graffiti, and scores of homeless openly using drugs. A real disappointment and what should be an embarrassment to the city’s government.

title: Large and delicious options for lunch
reviews: Jade Dragon for dim sum:Anytime up until 12:45p, be prepared to stand and wait for a table.  If you like dim sum, it’s worth the wait.  It’s crowded, loud, has a feel of disorganization, but there’s actually a system in place.Go VERY hungry.  I thought I was, but didn’t even eat all of what I ordered.  I had grilled radish cakes, fried prawns and onion dumplings and fried sesame seed balls.Be mindful of any Chinese food which could potentially have a surprise inside. (wontons are filled with hot liquid) and the sesame balls have a black liquidy paste (suspect bean curd). They were by far my favorite of the three.I liked the shrimp dumplings.  They don’t skimp on the shrimp at all.Jade Dragon is in the heart of Chinatown and easy to find.  (Green building)As far as other things to see and do, a garden is nearby and there are a lot of authentic Chinese shops for medicine, souvenirs, etc.

title: Uncomfortable
reviews: Walked into this run down area of Vancouver and it was a mistake. Clearly the area is an attraction for down and outs and drug users. Couldn’t wait to get out and flagged down a taxi at the earliest opportunity.

title: Same as all other china towns
reviews: This is no different to any other china town in any other country that we have visited. It has the usual shops and bakerys. Nice to look at but it wont take you very long to see it all.

title: Couldn't get out of there quick enough!
reviews: After walking around the gaslamp district we decided to head a few blocks over to Chinatown for a nice chinese meal. The more we progressed into Chinatown the more we noticed all shops closed and roller doors down. More and more homeless people everywhere. By the time we got to the centre we were surrounded with what felt like hundreds of homeless and beggars doing drug deals and taking drugs in alleyways only meters from us. It felt scary and after not finding anywhere open we just flagged down the next taxi and returned to our hotel. I'm sure not everyone there chose to be in that position but it just didn't feel right us being there at that time.

title: A Lot To Be Desired
reviews: Didn't feel safe with all the beggars and homeless people around there. I'm surprised that the city hasn't done much about this problem given that it is so close to the cruise port. Beware if you do decide to visit. The place is filthy.

title: Deserted and dangerous
reviews: We had always heard of the fabulous Vancouver Chinatown and nothing could be further from the truth Not sure what happened but it’s a deserted area of boarded up shops with a lot of dodgy homeless derelict people sleeping and living on the streets Felt very unsafe Avoid at all costs

title: Shopping
reviews: Is there any shopping malls or stores where u find purses , shoes or clothes there? Looking for shopping places in vancouver

title: Worst China Town I have ever visited.
reviews: This place is old and depressing.  There is nothing inviting about it.  I did enjoy the red poles with the gold dragons with red pearls and the nearby Dr. Sun-Yat Sen Chinese Garden, but  that is it.  Do not venture north or you will run into the saddest sight you have ever seen of homeless people everywhere living in the street.  Visitors should be warned.  Vancouver BC needs to clean up China Town and do something for those sad and needy homeless people.

title: Avoid Chinatown!
reviews: After visiting the Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese Gardens, (which is lovely!) my Husband and I accidentally stumbled upon the streets of Vancouver that are overrun by the homeless... the streets I did my research on before coming to Vancouver, but when you have very little means to wifi and maps, you get lost and just sometimes wing it! If you are heading to Chinatown, go to see the Chinese Gardens and then head straight back to the train station, stray any further than this area and you might find yourself in a confronting situation. Between Carrall Street and Main Street there is an alley way that looks like a sea of homeless people, the mentally unstable and drug abusers... we got as far as this, crossed the street and walked back in the other direction. It’s an absolute shame for Chinatown, the impact this has had and will have on the many business in this part of Vancouver is devastating!

title: depressing
reviews: Given how popular Vancouver has become with the Chinese and how much mainland money has been pouring into the city it is surrising to say the least to see how run down and frankly depressing is the city's Chinatown. It does not have a particularly Chinese vibe to it ... it feels moth-balled, moribund, trinkety. Parts of it are the skid row, teeming with junkies. This being Canada there is no overt hostility but you can feel (and understand) the dislike for the tourist.  The City appears to have happily lifted its hands, allowing the rampant drug abuse and vapor-laden chaos to rule the streets. Vancouver is, I am realizing, as living demonstration that a city can be too liberal for its own good, and for the good of the people living there. I wish SF supervisors who are driving the city into a similar politically correct Disaster visited this Chinatown to see where permissive drug regulations and lack of enforcement lead. Nowhere good.

title: Don't Walk North of Pender Street!
reviews: Judging from the reviews of my fellow TripAdvisors, it is clear that us locals are remiss in not making it clear to our visitors that Pender Street and areas to the south are Chinatown, while Hastings Street, just to the north, is Skid Road. After recently enjoying the atmosphere in Chinatown, I took a short cut to Gastown by going directly north - big mistake! What a difference one block can make, as Hastings was definitely depressing, and a world away from the gardens, museums, restaurants, and herbal stores on Pender. Maybe try approaching from the west, as I did.BTW - some years ago I noticed a similar paradigm shift when I walked from Market Street to Mission Street in San Francisco - it happens!

title: Used to be a nice place...
reviews: We are currently on a trip through the West of Canada. We started the trip in Vancouver. We visited the City about 10 years ago already. We already knew the neighborhood of China Town is bad. We hoped this have been improved since then but we just found out it got even worse. In case you plan to walk from China Town to Gas Town you will go through a dangerous area with Junkies and strange people looking for rests of cigarettes, asking for money to buy drugs, shouting around, checking you out...If you are young and healthy: Watch your back. If you are a bit older or anxious: Call for a Taxi. I don‘t understand why the City of Vancouver still concentrates all these problems in a small spot. Other cities around the world have tried this and failed. I expected the Chinese would take care of this situation and keep China Town clean. But it is actually the other way around. Also China Town is going down. The Drugs and the dirt are taking over command. China Town in Vancouver is not a nice place anymore.

title: Not what I expected in Chinatown
reviews: I recently took my wife and kids(15 years old) to Vancouver Chinatown and was shocked at what I saw. I have been to Chinatown in Major cities ( NYC, San Fran, Boston, Philadelphia,Seattle and Toronto) but none was like this one.  We saw stores that were out of business or closed. The energy, culture experience was missing but replaced by homelessness and people high on drugs. There were 10 to 15 tents set up with homeless people and high individuals in a state of zombie like with a needle in their hands.  Another individual with a propane tank carrying above his head walking aimlessly with his eyes closed. Ok.. you get the picture..  where is the law and order in this place.  I was afraid for my kids and wife’s safety. While we were speed walking back to the hotel, I keep asking myself, where are the law enforcements to crack down the sell of drugs in this area?  This is coming from a kid that grew up in Bronx in NY in the 70s and 80s. It was an eye opener & a learning lesson for my kids and a flash back from my childhood.

title: Disgustingly
reviews: Walked through China town today & it was awful, there were homeless people everywhere, most of which were clearly on drugs. Although they didn't particularly bother us I was called the swear word for a female dog, so it was very intimidating. The stench of urine on some streets was overpowering. There was litter everywhere, much of which was drug paraphernalia including needles and turnikas. I was very glad to leave this area & would honestly say to any tourist heading that way not to go

title: Great community!
reviews: I am really surprised by the poor reviews. I was thrilled to learn that Vancouver has one of the largest Chinatowns in N. America. Imagine my surprise when I saw all of these low ratings with references to drugs, homelessness, not being tourist-friendly (side note:  aren't us millennial travelers supposed to eschew touristy places and seek out "authentic experiences"?)But that aside, the blatant racism and demand that an entire community put on a show for white tourists is disgusting. The reason that we have so many Chinatowns across the US is that in the mid-1800's, many Chinese people moved to the US to work on the US transcontinental railroad. The US loved this and even signed a treaty to bring more Chinese to the US. But then the economy in California faltered and who did we blame? The Chinese immigrants for taking our jobs (we love doing that in the US). Then we passed a bunch of laws to make it harder for them to be real citizens - they couldn't own property or marry non-Chinese people. Chinatowns were literally the only community they had. The fact that so many of them have become tourist destinations speaks to the strength and industriousness of these communities. But they don't exist for white tourists. They exist for the people who live in them and run businesses in them because until not that long ago, this was the only safe community where they could work. After WE brought them here to work for US (again, sound familiar?) And this doesn't actually matter, but I felt perfectly safe in Chinatown. I saw a few homeless people there. I also saw a few homeless people on Robson Street yesterday (one of the fanciest streets in Vancouver). I saw no drug use in Chinatown. I smelled pot all over Robson Street. So I have no idea what these reviews are talking about. I really enjoyed the food, shops, friendly people, and beautiful gardens. There was also a senior home with some plaques sharing a bit more about influential Chinese immigrants in Vancouver so make a little detour to learn more!

title: Chinatown was not available
reviews: Hey, today we wanted to visit Chinatown but it wasn't possible. The streets were full of junkies and drunk people (14 Uhr or 2pm)..

title: Run down and intimidating
reviews: I feel sorry for the people of Chinatown as the entire homeless population of Vancouver seems to have been flushed into this area making it seem very run down. Though they didn't bother us, the overt drug use and colourful language made us feel unsafe wandering around. There is an overwhelming stench of urine in most streets and some very questionable stains down walls. We didn't stay long and the visit left me feeling very sad at the unfortunate circumstances people find themselves in.

title: Good Food
reviews: Very clean and nice area to find some food.  At a food court (4th Floor), I ate large Vancouver Crabs for 12 bucks (only 10 if you do not want the cook to add any sauce).

title: An eclectic mix
reviews: This area is undergoing huge changesand is a mixture of the old and new.Hip restaurants and bars nestle amongst old-time therbal shops, restaurants and bakeries with bargain prices.New town Bakery is a favourite. Long lineups throughout the day, 7 days a week. There is also a full restaurant in back.Kent's kitchen is a very simple cafeteria style restaurant serving up huge orders of authentic and good food. Huge variety. Crowded and noisy. You can call it a dive.The first Chinese immigrants settled here. It became a thriving community but slowly declined as new generations moved to other areas of the city.Some of the historic structures and buildings are now undergoing restoration.  New residential apartments are being built. Starbucksis here too!The Rennie Gallery is housed in the lovingly restored Yip Sang building.The little hidden alleyyway where Chinese residents used to congregate to socialize has been incorporated into the back building.The Dr. Sun Yet Sen gardens are open to the public.All in all this is very interesting area to visit. The gentrified and the gritty.

title: Not as expected
reviews: Chinatown is congested with tramps. No significant attractions over there. It’s quite dangerous for a solo traveler to hangover there

title: Only spent an hour but it was fun!
reviews: This is a special cultural section of Vancouver. So many places to shop for different things or eat in amazing places, some cost very little.

title: Vancouver Chinatown... I really tried to like it...but
reviews: We have visited many Chinatowns around the world, including the one in Victoria, BC.  While visiting Vancouver waterfront, we decided to walk through Chinatown, instead of taking the Rapid transit.  Whilst the Vancouver waterfront is pristine and devoid of what any city would consider "unfavorable people", later on, as we walked through Chinatown, we to came to the realization that "perhaps" the City of Vancouver may have swept all of  the homeless people to  Chinatown.  It seems so unfair.Chinatown is a living neighborhood and we saw old buildings and new modern ones. We walked past one of the homeless shelters.  The people loitering around were dirty, smelly and the stench of urine permeated the area.  Now I ask, if these homeless people have a shelter, why do they trash the neighborhood.  I almost rented a beautiful apartment through Airbnb, and because the reviews said that you would have to go past the smelly shelter to get to the flat, we decided not to rent the flat. Not the owner's fault, but more like the City's fault..

title: Traditional Chinese scenery 中華街の景色を満喫
reviews: I visited there for walk around and enjoying different atmosphere.There are a lot of interesting Chinese cuisine restaurant and retails as well. Some people said that dangerous place but I couldn't get any trouble in there.Souvenir shop staff was very kind.チャイナタウンは意見な場所ということで言われがちですが、昼間の時間で大通りであれば、ホームレスの方もいらっしゃりますが、特にこちらに被害を与えてくるわけではないので大丈夫でした。０.５cc シリンジとかがたまに転がっていますが、それに刺さるわけもなく、道路は東京のが汚いと思う場所もあると思います。中華街の中の焦点はユニークなものが多く、とても楽しいです。食べ物も美味しく安いです。お土産やさんの方々もとてもフレンドリーでした。

title: A Cultural Icon in the City
reviews: Vancouver is 1/3 Chinese in 2019.This is a beautiful, well done and unique showcase of this important cultural component of the city.

title: Poo on you
reviews: What is a Chinatown? Historically, little more than a ghetto. Chinese people created self-sustaining communities not to impress tourists but because their lives were considered peripheral. Not unlike the Jewish or African American ghettos, Chinatowns exist because of discrimination and racism. Your complaint about Chinatown changing says more about you than about the neighborhood.When a ghetto changes, it means the people who lived there prospered themselves and their families, pushed through and overcame racism, and then moved to the suburbs. Now they have more lucrative businesses than their grandparents had. And that pisses off some people because it also means no more Orientalized "Chinatown." The Other is out of the Ghetto. I have always loved Chinatown in Vancouver and am thrilled to see all the new businesses there: independent, fun, creative, progressive businesses. Haunts of the moment include the Keefer bar, the Union, and Kissa Tanto. Phnom Penh is as great as it was 20 years ago, and worth every minute of that wait in line.Change means moving the Other out of the ghetto and allowing the ghetto to become a living, breathing architectural testimonial of history. And it's a scrumptious area, visually. A few buildings have been modified to the point where you kind of wish they had preserved more, but as much as possible new construction is integrated into the traditional architecture. The Jack Chow building. The Sun Yat-Sen philosopher-scholar gardens. The herb shops, the produce stands.Urine-scented alleyways, grunge, grime, and maybe even a few goobers of old man spittle on the ground now share space with world class cocktail bars and experimental restaurants. I miss the $3 congee as much as the next person. I mean, now I have to take the Skytrain all the way to Richmond to get a fix of traditional Chinese food. Anyone angry with their experience in Vancouver Chinatown is either not all that interested in actual Chinese culture, or are just really sketched out by poor people. They came expecting an Oriental Chinatown, the Disney version. If that’s what you were hoping for, go to Epcot.For everyone else, see you at Matchstick during the day for a god shot of batch-roasted coffee. Then we can meet at the Union or Kissa Tanto for belly fills and cocktails. Or Phnom Penh if you don't mind waiting in line. Then if you're keen, we can catch a show up at the Rickshaw or lounge at the Keefer Bar. Change is good.

title: Sad and disturbing
reviews: We walked thru Chinatown on a Saturday on our way to dinner.It was dirty, run down and full of beggars and homeless people. With so much wealth in Vancouver, it was a very sad and chastening experience, alas not restricted to Vancouver.

title: Really really not worth it
reviews: I do wish the Chinatown was worth it. We love Chinatown all over the world. We have gone to San Francisco Chinatown, the Japan town in São Paulo, Chinatown in Washington DC, Chinatown in New York, our favorite. But this Chinatown unfortunately is the ugly side of Vancouver. Vancouver is such a beautiful and energized city but this place has been left behind. It seemed like there were drug deals going on on every corner, homeless people ambulating around not knowing where to go. I wouldn’t say that we are shy tourists, we lived in Brazil for many years and saw the poverty there, we have been to Harlem and Hells kitchen, but this place really takes the cake. There are so many beautiful places in Vancouver, don’t go here. The city really need to invest in this region for a major facelift!

title: Chinatown is changing
reviews: Chinatown is changing in Vancouver. It is becoming slowly but surely a millenials hangout of restaurants, tatoo parlors, marijuana dispensaries and pizza joints. along with new condos shooting up into the sky. it is a bit sad. there are pockets of the old character with stores, food stalls and fish and meat mongers.

title: Ole China
reviews: I really have a hard time with China because of their policies and human rights violation, but you can get a good meal here.

title: Not particularly interesting
reviews: This did not feel or look like the Chinatown of San Francisco.  Not many vibrant colors, not many small shops or food stalls.  This area was really run down.   A great many homeless and druggies on the streets.  No interesting shops. The Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Garden is is need of care.  The pathways were leaf-filled, the ponds dirty. Only one koi appears to be holding on.  The design is beautiful but the dereliction and lack of cleanliness is is off-putting.  The Millennium Gate was very pretty and reminiscent of the building painting in China. The Sam Kee Building is shallowest commercial building in the world.  A narrow, steel-framed building - ground-floor depth (from storefront to rear of building) measures 4'11" (1.50 m), with a second-floor depth (from overhanging bay window to rear) of 6' (1.83 m).   This is the most interesting part of Chinatown.  Not really worth the visit.

title: Little China
reviews: Compact but vibrant part of Vancouver situated on the east part of the central city. Many small outlets specialising In Chinese groceries and spices. Various restaurants with Chinese and international menus. Food menus are quite substantial with a long list of hot and cold beverages. Alcohol prices are medium but lists are short. Food is excellent and good value money.

title: Miss unless you are eating
reviews: We walked through the area which was grubby and slightly threatening.  There were none of the colours and culture of other major city Chinatowns.  We dined there but even the decent restaurant that we tried did not look attractive from the outside.  We returned back to the hotel in a taxi.

title: Awful, just awful.
reviews: Wandered into Chinatown today from Gastown expecting the usual colorful display you see in Chinatowns the world over.  Instead we found ourselves walking through the sketchiest, dirtiest part of any city I’ve ever visited.  I’ve never seen so many drug addled or homeless people congregating in one place before, it was truly shocking and a huge blemish on Vancouver’s otherwise great image.  I cannot believe we actually saw a man lighting a crack pipe on the side of the street at midday, and a woman high on drugs pushing a baby in a pram.  It’s an awful, awful part of the city, and something should be done about it.  Avoid it, and definitely don’t walk there at night or with your kids!

title: Vibrant, Safe, and Exciting - surrounding areas not so much
reviews: I have been to China-towns on four continents, and still enjoy my home town. The big issue for tourists is to NOT try and walk from Gastown's Maple Tree Square south to the western part of Chinatown. This route means passing through Skid Row. So, DON'T go north of Pender, DO go east of Main to the non-touristy part, visit the Cultural Centre and the Sun-Yat-Sen Gardens, and you should have a pleasant experience.

title: This was a disappointment. I expected more from a city as large as Vancouver.
reviews: We were expecting more from a city with such a rich Chinese heritage as Vancouver. There was a large arch that was interesting, with stone lions guarding it, but the rest of China Town was just a few restaurants. Granted, it was raining for part of the time, so we dodged in and out, but unless there was more hidden somewhere we couldn't see, there wasn't much to do here. Nearby there was a modern Asian multi-level mall called the International Center, but it was almost deserted as well.

title: Do not go to Chinatown
reviews: This section of the city is a stop on the Hop on Hop off bus.  We got off to see the Cultural center and park/garden.  When it opened at 9:30 we went into the Park (free) and spent 10 minutes and noticed there was trash along the wall and looked like homeless had set up camp in the site.  Pond was dirty and there was only 1 fish that we could see.  Nothing here was lovely and we walked out.  Instead of waiting for the next bus, we decided to walk to Gastown since it was next stop and only 2 blocks away.  These 2 blocks were filthy, loaded with druggies shooting up, sleeping on mattresses on the sidewalk and men were rummaging thru trash cans looking for food.  This is not a place for visitors or children.  Hop on Hop off bus should skip this area completely.  Do not go here day or night , and do not spend money here.

title: A Grim & Depressed Area
reviews: On the basis of travel guide advice, we decided to visit ChinaTown after walking through the nearby disappointingly themepark-like Gastown area.I honestly can’t think of a single reason to recommend a visit to this district, unless you are a philanthropist looking for a worthy project or a dedicated social worker.The area is clearly poor and unloved by local authorities. It has a grim and depressed air, with a large homeless population, many of whom appear to have severe mental health needs that aren’t being met.The Andy Livingstone ‘Park’ was a dead and barren space, full of makeshift shelter, rubbish and evidence of drug use - right up to & encroaching into the playground of a local school.Very sad.

title: skip it
reviews: Wandered through part of it after getting off the hop-on/off bus since we were tired of sitting.  Bad decision.  Lots of drug usage, homeless and generally a less than comfortable area.... and we were there in the early afternoon.  Positive side, none of the people asked us for hand-outs or even spoke to us.  Even DH was uneasy.  Next morning early (around 6am... it was in August) we walked from our hotel up Pender so I could get some photos of the sidewalk inlay in the center of Chinatown.  Not so many people ut, so was more comfortable,,, but nothing was open due to the early hour.

title: Not somewhere I'd recommend for children
reviews: My family and I decided to visit China town after reading about the Chinese garden. It was three of us, me, my husband, and 10 year old son. If I had known what the area was like I would NEVER have taken my son into that area. Whilst the Chinese garden is pleasant, the area around it is not. We walked from the Bus Stop to the gardens and it was frightening; the level of homelessness, and drug abuse was shocking. Blatant drug use; people injecting on the main streets! Police arrests, etc. We left after seeing the gardens as to be honest I didn't feel safe, and that was in the middle of the day. I hear that it was a great tourist spot in the past, but I certainly would not recommend it.

title: Disappointing ...
reviews: Vancouver's China Town is quite extensive but has seen better days.  The Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Garden is beautiful and worth seeing as are the Asian markets.  We were told that the "new China Town" is located in Richmond which was too far for us to visit during our short stay in Vancouver.  Unfortunately, the "old" China Town area in Vancouver seems to be home to drug addicts during the day.  We did not go back at night.

title: Off the bus
reviews: Four of us got off the hop on hop off bus tour here. The stop is across the street from the Chinese Garden so we entered and walked among the greenery and koi ponds. It was nice to see so much green in the city. There is a gift shop also. We left to walk a few blocks and noticed how old, dirty and run down Chinatown has become. It was a great disappointment. We decided to walk from here to Gastown rather than ride the bus 3 blocks. A big mistake. We walked the route of the bus thinking that would be the easiest way. The streets had a lot of homelessness people hanging around, some asleep and others doing drugs in the alley. A bit scary so I recommend not walking around. If I would have known about Chinatown beforehand I would not have gotten off the bus.

title: It’s a NO NO!
reviews: In June 2018 we entertained a visitor from Australia. He wanted to visit Chinatown. Off we went and were delighted to find easy parking! We bought a couple of hours and proceeded to the Chinatown we’d become accustomed to. Oh my goodness, gone were all those fascinating shops (save one) that were filled with all sorts of trinkets and interesting items. We found a store that sold wigs but didn’t enter. Then we walked on to what we knew as a beautiful garden with a pond that was always teeming with fish. The gardens were derelict and the pond was dirty and so full of algae that if there were still fish there it was not possible to see them. So we voted with our feet. Came across some shops that sold food stuffs but that was all. Will we visit again? Don’t think so. It’s not worth a visit and what a pity that is!

title: Nothing like NY or San Fran Chinatowns
reviews: As is so often this case, this Chinatown is  OK but it is adjacent to some really seedy looking alleys, and back streets.  Stay on the main drag and you should be OK.

title: Oops-should have checked TA first
reviews: Having enjoyed Chinatown in New York, San Francisco and Sydney, we walked here on a balmy Tuesday evening for a meal. But we quite agree with many of the other reviews. The streets are wide and just felt like any other run-down part of a large city. We walked from street to street for 45 minutes, hoping it would improve. But it lacked the Chinese cultural feel, was dirty, full of homeless and a bit scary. Found a Korean restaurant which was OK. Left before dark.

title: Don't bother
reviews: We walked 2km to get there early evening to have an authentic Chinese meal. The place felt unsafe,  was filthy & we couldn't find any restaurants to eat in. Such as disappointment as I usually visit Chinatown in every city that has one & all have been bustling at night with excellent food. Give this one a miss

title: A place full of contrasts: Chinese culture and degraded streets
reviews: ChinaTown is the neighborhood in Vancouver, where tradicionally there are a lot of immigrants from China. It is a place full of contrats, because there is full of Chinese culture,you can see tradicional Chinese monuments or see some pèople doing ioga in streets like in China. On the other hand, some streets are degraded and I think that it is not very recommendable to come here at night, so be careful!

title: Tropical fruits galore
reviews: If you are looking for exotic tropical foods you can find them here, jackfruit, Manila mangoes, chick, lanzones, atis, and many many more they also have bakeries that have rice cakes ...

title: Not super
reviews: I visited many Chinatowns in différents countries..This one is strange and please don’t go there in the night...It look not sure place....Not very interesting...We founded a very good Cambodgian/vietnamian  restaurant : » Phnomen Penh...244 East Georgia Street...perhaps you will expect to get one table...But  ,please do it...good food...good price etc...

title: Bring your body guard with you.........
reviews: Started into China Town because I wanted to see the world's narrowest free standing office building.  Stopped after just a few blocks and went back to Gastown.  Too many homeless and druggies laying on all the sidewalks.  Too much trash.  Too much urine smell.  Not someplace I wanted my teens to be.

title: Can be skipped! Boring
reviews: If you've ever been to San Francisco's Chinatown you will be very disappointed!  No fascinating meat markets with bins of frogs and ducks hanging from the window...just a few interesting dried food and tea stores mixed in with apartments and businesses.  This Chinatown is transitioning to a regular neighborhood as the children of shop owners sell to developers for very high prices. Also, the streets were dirty and there were a number of spill overs from the East Hastings street area.  East Hastings is the area everyone told us to stay away from because of druggies etc.

title: Don't bother
reviews: Went to Chinatown looking forward to a nice dinner and was instead greeted with what looked like a run down part of Vancouver. Homeless people and druggies everywhere. Felt unsafe walking around the streets. Was shocked as I've never seen a Chinatown like this.

title: Not Very Active
reviews: We visited on Canada Day and found the area to not be very busy.  There are normal Chinese restaurants and some shops but not very big as compared to Chinatowns in other major cities.

title: Be Careful
reviews: While there are a number of sites of interest to the visitor such as the Chinatown Millennium Gate on Pender Street near Taylor Street, Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Chinese Garden at Carrall and Keefer Streets, and the Sam Kee Building at Pender and Carrall Streets, Vancouver’s Chinatown, located immediately south of the Gastown neighborhood, is relatively dirty with homelessness and open drug use apparent even during daylight hours.

title: Chinatown in Vancouver, Canada
reviews: We passed through this neighborhood a few times during our short stay in Vancouver. There are a few things that caught or attention like some of the buildings, grocery shops and the big Millennium Portal. Be careful, if you walk north too much you may end up in the famed Downtown Eastside.

title: Vancouver Chinatown
reviews: Small Chinatown compared to others in the States, but easy to walk around and some landmarks available. My favorite was Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese garden. They have many souvenir shops and places to eat. The main entrance is from Pender St. using the Millennium Gate. Maps available at most hotels and tourism offices.

title: Don’t Waste Your Time; Not Worth It!
reviews: Dirtiest place I’ve ever been to. It’s run down, dirty and smelly from dried seafood on sale. Most of the stores and restaurants are closed.  I don’t know if it’s a poor neighborhood, but they should at least keep it clean. There is no beauty or art to appreciate in this area.

title: Truly sad
reviews: After reading the numerous warnings about homeless people on Tripadvisor, we decided to visit with family including two younger kids.  Wanted to at least visit once and see for myself. My goodness, Vancouver's Chinatown is a really sad sight to see.  During our few hours there, we saw more homeless people and drug addicts than I've seen in my lifetime.  Witnessed several drug transactions, folks talking to themselves, and even a shoplifting incident between a store employee and homeless lady. And to top it off, we got a parking ticket for parking too long in the garage. Other Chinatowns such as San Francisco and New York are not anywhere close to Vancouver's seedy Chinatown. We should've avoided this place and so should you.  Very sad sight to see, I can't believe the city of Vancouver allows this to happen in a touristy spot.  What a horrible reflection of this amazing city.

title: same everywhere
reviews: if you visit china town anywhere all over the world then you do not need to visit again ,,,,it is copy paste every where same buildings,same style of street , same shops and same goods ,,,but always worthy to visit

title: My advice? - Don't go
reviews: I've never felt so unsafe as when we walked though Chinatown. It has to be my worst experience while travelling. The place is run-down, dirty, and full of drug addicts. I've never seen so much hard drug taking in public. People are passed-out in the street. I didn't enjoy walking past alleys which stank of piss. I've been to several other Chinatowns internationally and they've all been vibrant, lively, and fun. This one has a post-apocalypse feel. Horrible.

title: Skip it!
reviews: I’m always up for spending some time in Chinatown in any city I visit. When I had an extra hour prior to going to dinner in Gastown, I figured I’d check out the scene in Vancouver. Really wish I had com online to TA and checked out the reviews in advance. Although I wasn’t personally harassed by anyone in the area, I really wish I hadn’t gone. Lots and lots of homeless and drug addicts. The whole area is dirty & smelly, and you’ll definitely feel the urge to get the heck out of there shortly after you arrive. Sadly, there weren’t even any decent stores to visit. Do yourself a huge favor, and stay away from this area (as well as the far south end of Gastown where lots of homeless congregate at a park).

title: Terrible
reviews: I have never seen such a horrible Chinatown in the word like this. Actually, it is not a Chinatown but home of homeless and down condition people. Dirt, smell, drug everywhere. We saw a police action as well. Although we were four I scared. I think Chinese already moved away from this area and it’s not a real Chinatown any more. I can’t understand how the City can keep it in this condition.

title: Good & bad
reviews: I’ve read the poor reviews and I need to say, you’ve gotta look past the “homeless and addicts”. Chinatown is truly a cultural experience, with many great shops and plenty to see and do. There are definitely homeless people and unsavoury activities happening. But keep your eyes open for what you’re there for and experience the beauty Chinatown has to offer. There are negative things about every area one can visit! There are homeless in every area. They aren’t bad people. Let Chinatown be- the positives outweigh the negatives. I do believe a good cleanup is in order however. Also, if more shops would be friendlier towards English speaking patrons, that’d be awesome.

title: dirty
reviews: poor up keep,scary part of the city not far from east pender seedy part of town,didn't feel safe, didn't even bother stopping in any of the shops ,did go to the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden ,it was nice.

title: Go in a Group!
reviews: This place looks like it belongs in a scary movie. Homeless by the bunch. Crazy talking to them selves and trying to scare you. We were standing trying to take a picture and some crazy girl csme to kick the umbrella that we had put down.  Not a friendly place at all.

title: How could this get a better rating then a 1?
reviews: I travel a lot. This was one of the worst places I have ever been. The streets are littered with homelessness and drug addicts. If you stay long enough, you can probably catch a buzz from heroin or pot trailing through the air. It is almost like entering an apocalypse of slum. I would never, I mean ever, recommend anybody to go here. I actually feared for my life. We got back to our hotel and the hotel staff told us we were on "skid row" of Vancouver. I don't know what everybody else was looking at when they gave this a higher rating of 1...... I'm baffled.

title: Run down and filled with addicts
reviews: We walked the main street and we're almost stepping over homeless and addicts. There were so many! Many shelters and halfway houses in this area, so don't go at night. Lots of shops are closed and buildings vacant.

title: Go visit before it is gone
reviews: I exaggerate, but Van Chinatown is a shadow of its former self, with Richmond now being the Chinatown for all purposes in BC.  Still, Van Chinatown is worth visiting and remembering for its historical significance and current contribution to the Van community.  The Sun Yet Sun garden and adjacent Chinese Cultural Center are underappreciated sites and worth the visit. A stroll up and down the streets of Chinatown offers the visitor numbers shopping and eating opportunities.  The New Town Bakery in CTown is still the best of all the locations. Various noodle joints offer good eats.  I am glad the Vancouver City Council is at least looking into efforts to preserve historical Van Chinatown.

title: China Town
reviews: We parked in a parking garage to go to a yoga class at 638am. Turns out street parking free before 8.Strolled through to eat at Jam after class. Saw some homeless people and my girlfriend said they freaked her out. (And she wants to go live in a big city. Ha!) we also saw a lady maybe doing tai chi on a circle.Anyway, here is picture of a dragon on a pole.(and the Chinese garden is closed on Mondays this time of year) And look at those weapons at the “Athletic club”. Wonder if they teach gwailou? #bruceleereference

title: Biggest Chinatown in Canada
reviews: I used to live in Montreal's (Quebec) Chinatown district. It was tiny. It was dirty. It was decrepit.  Shops were closing at an alarming rate, the homeless situation was huge and rats ran through the cobblestone streets after dark. Then I moved to Vancouver and hello! Found the largest Chinatown in the country spread across (I lost count of how many blocks, I think 10 in one direction and 6 in the other) chock full of gift shops, restaurants, bakeries, sidewalk markets with pungent, colorful and unidentifiable edibles. There is also the Chinese Cultural Centre and the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese Garden and park to see. It's the largest Ming era-style Chinese gardens outside China. There are several indoor centres with shops on the 2nd and 3rd floors that are hard to get at due to bad signage and never-ending escalator repairs but once you find them, you'll feel like you've been thrown back to the 60's and 70's with the faded packages, corny pictures, odd selection of random merchandise (plastic pink shower caps next to cat teapots) and really cheap prices.  It's a fun day trip and you'll find lots of nice little bakeries and souvenir shops and plenty of inexpensive paper lanterns to hang around home.  There are also some bubble tea shops and you can find typical North American fast food fare (like Mcdonald's)  if Asian food doesn't tickle your tastebuds.

title: Photography Hub
reviews: As I am passionate about photography,  with my photo club we met to take "street people photos in their environment".   The market place overflowing on the street is so colorful  & makes a beautiful backdrop for merchants & customers.

title: Dreadful - avoid
reviews: This was the worst part of our trip. Depressing, underwhelming and slightly seedy. We went there in the evening and felt like we had walked into a third rate movie set. Determined to find something to like we kept on walking and landed up in what can only be described as drug land. It felt dangerous and uncomfortable and we literally ran out of there. We love Chinatown inLondon, go there often and always seek out authentic Chinese restaurants but this didn’t seem to have anything safe or inviting open. Really disappointing.

title: Small and uninspiring
reviews: Most Chinatowns have the same look and feel and this one mostly is similar, but it’s smaller and somehow feels more depressing. It may have been the wet and gloomy weather hut I think it’s also the fact that it seems to be morphing into part hipster/modern suburb and part homeless shelter. Unless you have a craving for dim sum I wouldn’t bother with this part of Vancouver.

title: This is not a place, it's an atmosphere!
