reviews: I've been to many Chinatowns, and still like this one best. Had a friend visiting from Shanghai, and when he was feeling homesick, brought him here - the change in his attitude was profound. Stores with traditional herbs and medicines, Sun Yat Sen Gardens, and great food. Ignore the critics and go with an open mind.

title: The worst chinatown I've been to!
reviews: Chinatowns are usually lovely places showing off chinese culture in cities around the world. They are often wonderfully decorated and full of great restaurants. This chinatown however is seedy and full of the low side of society. We really didn't feel safe walking the streets even in broad daylight.Many of the restaurants look dirty and run down and my other half refused to eat here. We only came to find the chinese garden and won't come back again.

title: History trip
reviews: Original Chinatown with some interesting old buildings and wall art of how it was back in history. An interesting walk through the streets. A good history trip

title: Seedy and dirty
reviews: Really seedy and dirty area. Chinatown is probably home to Vancouver’s entire homeless population as they are everywhere on the street. Felt unsafe when I visited after dark.

title: A must visit in the city!
reviews: Having spent time in SF and also in Vancouver's Chinatown ( as well as NYC) I would say this is my most favourite, compact Chinatown. Don't miss Sun Yat Sen gardens!

title: Don't miss it if like something wonderful!
reviews: We found a time to visit Chinatown in downtown Vancouver BC after 3 years living here in metro Vancouver. Beside old and cultural buildings, stores with Chinese items and foods are very prominent in this area. For me, store with dried sea creatures and plants were interested; dried lizards, turtles, sea cucumber, fishes, ... were interested. Although there was a nice place to visit, still I've expected more Chinese marks or sights and cleaner side walks to be a Chinese location.

title: Nothing special
reviews: It is worth a trip to or from Gastown if you are looking for some great Chinese food but other than that it really isn’t worth a stop. Although I didn’t feel threatened, some of the streets around this neighborhood can be dicey and filled with aggressive homeless. Our cab driver even felt the need to warn us not to venture to certain areas.

title: Not worth visiting.
reviews: We were very disappointed with Chinatown in Vancouver. It has a lovely gate at the entrance, so it looked promising. But the whole place was very dirty and not welcoming. There was a lot of drug addicts in doorways and just laying in the street. It didn't have the atmosphere of other Chinatown's we've been to.

title: Careful when walking there from Gastown!
reviews: Interesting to see, with all the Chinese restaurants and stores that sell all sorts of unrecognizable herbs and dried items (I prefer not to ask or know what most of them are...). Also a few kitchy Chinese gift shops, if you want to buy a little something. Be wary, though, if you walk to Chinatown from Gastown. Better to take West Pender>East Pender over, and NOT West Hastings>East Hastings (especially around the intersection with Columbia). This is a really seedy part of town, full of homeless (which you'll see everywhere else in Vancouver as well, just not nearly as many as here), prostitutes, and junkies that shoot up right on the street (and you'll see syringes with needles lying around here and there)... If you walk the right way though, you should be able to avoid most of that.

title: The sketchy part of Vancouver
reviews: The Chinatown near downtown Vancouver is in serious decline as many of the members of the Chinese community have moved to Richmond. Apart from some of the better maintained buildings, the neighborhood is dirty, decrepit and sketchy, with beggars and panhandlers in almost every corner. Although not as pleasant as other districts, the Chinatown still worth a stroll. It is safer than it looks.

title: Chinatown
reviews: We went to Chinatown in the early afternoon, and it was safe and fun. There are plenty of stores, restaurants, bakeries. I enjoyed the authentic Chinese food. The Chinese garden is also in this area.

title: Holiday visit
reviews: This place is shocking people are drugged up drunk in most side streets they just sit there suffering there affects from drugs and alcohol I wouldn't like to be there at night time I suggest you miss this place and visit gas town a adjoining area much better clean tidy and very safe

title: Canada Road Trip.
reviews: We wandered into Chinatown from Gastown, and almost immediately felt uneasy and the further we went the worse it got. It is seriously run down, with lots of homeless and addicts around the place. Waiting at one crossing we almost got a free high from the dense drug fumes in the air. We felt unsafe, so hightailed it out of there double quick, back to downtown, as Gastown was also a bit run down too, but not to quite the same level yet.

title: Very interesting part of Vancouver
reviews: We always like to visit China Town in any city we go to, it is always interesting. The shops have unusual goods and you can always find a good restaurant. Just look at the diners, if they are Asian, the food is usually very good.

title: Terrible!
reviews: I love to visit each and every single Chinatown and I thought I had been to the least interesting one when I visited the one in Chicago but this one was just horrible. The old tattered stores and the restaurant did not help the streets that were cluttered with trash and needles laying around. Just a bunch of unsavory characters hanging around. Yelling and fighting. Do not waste your time like we did.

title: Vancouver downtown Chinatown being eclipsed by Richmond's "Golden Village"!
reviews: At one time this was a bustling, interesting centrally located commercial area/place... but the influx of Asians over the past 20+ years, mainly to Richmond (South of Vancouver), has drawn much business and "VIBE" there!!  While there are remnants remaining, the GLITZ has disappeared!!  One is better off taking public transport to the Golden Village" {SKYTRAIN STOP: ABERDEEN].

title: nothing special
reviews: i saw lot's of them around the world but unfortunally in vancouver is not very characteristic. Could be much better.

title: Why I Am An Advocate for Chinatown, Vancouver, BC
reviews: I'm Chinese American from Seattle. I especially enjoyed going to Chinatown on my latest trip up in August. I particularly enjoyed the photo displays depicting historic moments/events/people in the community's history. Though I'm American, I felt a sense of unity with the Chinese Canadians historically and contemporaneosly. Let's put it this way. New York City is made up of hundreds of ethnic neighborhoods. Who would dream of tearing these down? They give the city a character and sense of history and tradition as well as a resource for the present and future as nothing else can. Change is good but it shouldn't be accepted as a blank check for the future. As long as residents, immigrnts, business persons, and interested Canadian Chinese who so desire, have a say and hand in shaping, creating yet maintaining the history and character of Vancouver's Chinatown, I say keep Chinatown. I felt happy there,in a place where I felt I could relate, be accepted, belong. I think a lot of us might feel that way and I think that's a powerful motivation and rationale for advocating for Chinatown.

title: If I could give it a negative score I would.
reviews: We walked to Chinatown from the lookout over Vancouver. WOW, so that's where all the homeless and negative factors of the area gather. The streets were lined with vagrants and park areas full of homeless people's campsites. Filthy and smelly it was! Do not go there.

title: Chinatown all over
reviews: This iconic Vancouver site is beyond your regular Chinatown. It has local shops with traditional oriental produce, kitchen items, food and memorabilia. It also has its famous gardens. Vancouver has the largest Chinese community outside China, and that presence is evident not only here, but everywhere.

title: The slums
reviews: Did not expect China Town to be full of homeless people with visible drug use. Was not like other China towns. Only nice place was the Dr. sun yat sen Garden however the other half of it requires you to pay. Reconsider going. Heaps of herbal stores however.

title: Filled with homeless people
reviews: Sadly, this is currently a dreary area with numerous homeless people, many of who are begging.  There are whole blocks of these sad people.

title: Shocking.
reviews: Appalling level of homelessness in this area. We followed the guidebook advice, looking for some great Asian cuisine for our evening meal, and stumbled naively into some post apocalyptic nightmare of homelessness, drug use and mental illness. Each filthy stinking street corner we turned had more and more people gathered in groups, and the bustle of Gastown when we circled back to reach it was such a welcome sight. How much danger there actually is to the public and the tourists, I'm unsure, as most of them were so far gone. It's tragic and terrifying and it's a social problem bordering on being out of control. But don't take your kids for a walk down there.

title: Not quite what we expected
reviews: We have been to China Town in San Francisco and expected more of the same since Vancouver has a strong Chinese history.It was ok to walk through while avoiding Hastings Street as we were warned about.

title: Do not visit.
reviews: We walked this way after wandering Yaletown and had planned to find a place to eat.  Our 2016 Lonley Planet guidebook had some ideas, but I have to say I would never walk through this neighborhood again. it was a sad display of drunk, drug-addicted people, some half-naked arguing with police, peeing in alleys that stunk of urine and just a very unsafe feeling neighborhood in general.We hightailed it to Gastown as fast as we could.

title: Stay away
reviews: Avoid this place like the plagueFilthy place full of druggies ,hobosSpent 1 hour there which was 59 minutes to longWould be the worst place I have visited

title: Be careful
reviews: I recommend to drive through this place. If you are not careful and ends on hasting street, you will regret.We parked car at meter parking, only found it doesn't work after insert two loonies. Walk around and got out of there as fast as we could. Strange characters, stain and bad smell.Just skip this place.

title: Avoid this area
reviews: I was just totally unimpressed. Homeless and beggars everwhere, no real restaurants except Floatas. Mostly dried food stuffs for sale on the street. We found a bakery, but it was cash only. Being American we carried no Canadian cash, so ......

title: REALLY NOT WORTH A VISIT
reviews: A very rundown area with very little to see or do.  We spent about 30 minutes before finding a restaurant that looked halfway decent.  The restaurant was Floata Seafood, and it was quite good but a little pricey.  Once we finished lunch we left Vancouver's Chinatown (never to return).

title: You Can't Go Home Again
reviews: Today we walked through Chinatown after eating in GasTown. I was taking a photo of a mural when mt wife asked 2 cops what else was there to do in or near Chinatown. Last time we were in Vancouver years ago, Chinatown was a great and safe place to visit and have a meal. Today we saw so many strange characters staggering all over the place, some in wheelchairs, some using canes, all under the influence of alcohol and other drugs.  I guess this is another example of you how can't go home again. Today Chinatown holds nothing of interest and is not a place to visit unless you are looking to buy drugs. It has been taken over by street people and drug addicts because this is where the social services are located.

title: Avoid like the plague
reviews: Vancouver's China Town is by far the worst suburb of any city I have ever been to. I walked here 5 minutes from Gas Town with my family hoping to find a nice Chinese restaurant only to stumble across probably a hundred or so homeless, drunk and drugged up people in a rundown area. Absolutely horrendous place. Can't believe you're not advised to keep away. Stay well away.

title: celebrating retirement
reviews: What a sad, rundown place. Very disappointed.rotting garbage on street, plus discarded needles (drug users) strong smell of pot.plenty of homeless people, would not walk after dark.not much to see. Not a safe place. not worth visiting

title: Pretty big letdown, lifeless, least vibrant Chinatown we've seen
reviews: I grew up in NYC chinatown, and the one thing I can say is, its never been boring, weekday or weekend (fuggetaboutit). Thats why I was so looking forward to trip to V Chinatown. We walked from downtown to Chinatown. Cool stuff, the arch is lovely. I kept telling my wife, wait till we get there, just wait. We soon start seeing some Chinese stores, but every other storefront looks boarded up and vacant.. hmmm. There is a conspicuous lack of people, not just Asians, very few people on street at all. Some homeless folks shuffling around. We finally got the famous Floata restaurant for some dim sum which was ok, but my wife and I were the only folks under 50 there. It reminded me of a dying town, eking out its last few years in squalor/decay. We went to a few stores and struck by lack of merchandise and customers. Really disappointing. Contrast this with NYC or San Fran where you feel the hum and bustle and vibrant energy. Avoid unless you are really dying to see this sad spectacle. A block or two away from Chinatown and you hit a pretty horrific stretch of what seems to be a homeless/vagrant camp. Sheesh

title: Not much to see here
reviews: Apparently this is the second biggest Chinatown in North America. Well that maybe - but there's really not too much to see - and it's on the edge of some quite unpleasant areas. Not one of my 'must sees' in Vancouver.

title: Faded Gem
reviews: It's a disappointment to see Chinatown today in the current state. The energy faded drastically in 2 decades. It was a great place to visit before the homeless and druggies invaded the area. Causing shops to close down and decrease tourism. Explore the place well and you'll still find some neat and great places. Don't enter east Hastings street as it isn't part of Chinatown and where all the druggies gather.

title: More needles than noodles
reviews: A horrendous place - run down, squalid, depressing and it merges with a slum area blighted by druggies. Vancouver Tourism - wake up and get this sorted. My son described the people in this area as the "walking dead". Get out of here as fast as you can.

title: Enjoy going to all the shops!
reviews: I love Chinatown. There are so many shops and great bakeries with Chinese pastries and fresh vegetables at cheap prices. You also can have a great dim sum or Chinese food for dinner.

title: A Place that Foretold the Future
reviews: This is a historical parts of Vancouver and one of the larger Chinatowns in North America. Little did the original residents of Chinatown realize that one day around 40% of Vancouver residents would be of Asian descent. Thus there actually are many Chinatowns in Vancouver. This Chinatown has done an incredible job of using signs and plaques to describe the signifance of certain buildings or the contributions of its former residents. In Chinatown you'll fin the world's skinniest building. It is a delightful place to visit.

title: The gardens make it all worthwhile.
reviews: The smell of the gross dead fish here was hard to take.   Dried out shrimp etc.  I don't know how one could eat such stuff!  The place was nice to walk through if you could handle the smell.  I liked the chinese designs on the buildings. Nice for a walk and to see something different.

title: Interesting Experience
reviews: Walking around Chinatown was fairly enjoyable.  Lots of shops and friendly people.  We enjoyed looking through the merchandise and buying some items. Overall an experience that would recommend while visiting Vancouver.

title: Terrible
reviews: As locals say:"Go if you want to see hobos.It's dirty" This is VERY accurate, it smells, run down and unwelcoming. There are bums everywhere. Over all sad/depressing. I would not walk down here at night. Thank goodness Chinatown is within  easy walking distance of Gastown, skip Chinatown and just stay in Gastown.

title: Cleanest Chinatown of all the ones I've seen.
reviews: This is the cleanest Chinatown that I have ever seen. Shops have a lot of souvenirs at very low prices, and produce stores have some fruits that are not readily available in the USA. Even parking was a breeze.

title: Not Nice to Visit
reviews: This is supposed to be the 3rd largest chinatown in this part of the world but it is really pathetic looking. More like a neighbourhood slum. Not vibrant at all. Not worth visiting unless you wish to dine at some of the eateries here.

title: Pretty Cool
reviews: It is well a Chinatown - lots of spices lots of things to see - some are cheap some are not A word of advice - stay in Chinatown premise and don't go East going to Hastings for your safety

title: Didn't like it at all
reviews: Enthousiastic reviews in several travel guides, but very disappointing to us; a lot of empty shops and a strange atmosphere. Maybe we missed it....

title: Quiet town
reviews: Stopped by from the Hop on Hop off bus, after coming from Granville Island. Was apprehensive as we read about the negative feedbacks, but it was not as bad as mentioned. You should have walk and count the number of homeless people on Granville Street and then compare with Chinatown's. So I would say its worth coming to Chinatown, walk through a cultural town and experience the Chinese culture. Only feedback is that there are no crowd unlike other Chinatowns we seen on other countries.

title: Depressing, slum-like.
reviews: This sad part of glorious Vancouver reminden me old Bowery, home for the hopeless, homeless and the mentally disturbed. We were expecting a "usual" chinatown, typical of many great metropolis of the world. Instead we  found miserable dwellings, closed-down shops and lots of homeless people. There were no signs of a decent Chinese restaurant. Nearby - perhaps it wasn't even in Chinatown - we found a military museum-like institute which looked very interesting, but it seemed to be permanently closed. If you are a visitor in Vancouver, save your time and energy - don't go there!

title: Very sad
reviews: Walked through Chinatown today after visiting Granville Island. There may be many worthwhile sites inside the buildings, but we were depressed by the amount of hurting people (none Chinese) we saw hanging around sidewalks and alleys. I would skip this part of town

title: Taken aback by numbers of homeless
reviews: So glad I went in daylight think would have been positively scary at nightRun down not pretty quite a different vibe to Gastown and Downtown I agree with other reviewers  avoid it

title: Very Depressing
reviews: Before my visit, I was told Vancouver had the best Chinese food so Chinatown was a must for dinner. I'm a native New York resident so I've seen the good and bad of a great city.  But what I witnessed in Vancouver's Chinatown was disgusting.  Dozens of homeless people occupying 1 city block and groups of junkies taking drugs out in the open in daylight.  We got out of the area as soon as possible.  The worse part is that Gastown was only 2 blocks away filled with beautiful shops, restaurants and tourists.  There were no police in Chinatown but tons in the pretty part of town.  Very sad...

title: Rundown, full of seedy people and not lively
reviews: Give this a miss.If you want to eat good Chinese food, head over to Richmond. There is literally nothing here - no cabs, no normal people on the streets but lots of drunks and druggos.There are only a handful of shops selling cheap goods or souvenirs.We did not feel safe here and got out as soon as we could!

title: Seriously...don't GO NOT safe
reviews: I had wanted to go here for a while and it's only a few short blocks from gastown district. So my parents, me and 3 kids (15,12, 3yrs old) decided to go. I thought it would be a cultural experience... well it was! But in drugs dealers, drunks,  foul smells and people on drugs. We got almost 1/2 block towards the place and turned around about as fast as we could. My teenager witnessed a drug deal right next to her, my saw son a prostitute (well I knew it was one!) And my mom hid her jewelry and so did I.   So so not safe for kids or anyone really. Bars on all the shops windows and drunks all over,  the smell could knock you down. Not safe during the day/down right dangerous at night.  Not worth it.. spoke with some local shop owners in Gastown district and they said the crime there is VERY bad. Muggings, theft, drugs. I felt safer in Columbia South America than here...

title: Don't bother
reviews: We were there in the evening and didn't find it very interesting.  If you want to see Chinatown go to NYC or Melbourne, Australia.  They have nice stores, food, shopping.  Much better and safer feeling. August 2014.

title: Down and outs in Chinatown
reviews: During our first evening in Vancouver, we decided to visit Gastown and move onto Chinatown in hope of a Chinese meal. OMG we were in for a bit of a shock, we were confronted with around a 50 metre stretch of sidewalk completely overrun with vagrants/ homeless/ druggies and that was just on one street. Apparently the authorities want an inclusive/ diverse range of residents in the city. Needless to say, we were pretty intimidated (all six of us) and after a short walk realised that we weren't in a Chinatown that we'd experienced in London, Birmingham, San Francisco etc.

title: Good place to eat
reviews: A typical Chinatown with a beautiful gate. The area is filled with life and people. Many restaurants to try and all very traditional, but more contemporary places are popping up!

title: Good and bad
reviews: I would say that most these places have little to no interest in tourists. However, my husband and I stumbled into one that wasn't just trying to sell us something, but teach us about what they had. I was extremely impressed with these two individuals and it is just the experience we were looking for. We found the diamond in the rough.

title: Cultural aspects fused with modern dining and shops
reviews: Chinatown is ever changing to welcome new shops and services to the area. A great look into the history of Chinatown can be found all over the street as the city of Vancouver has placed monuments, maps and statues depicting the events and people that have influenced the town.

title: Pass on the guidebook recommendation
reviews: Decided to walk thru and wish we had not. Out of the way and not much to see or do. It was even hard to get a taxi out of there ...

title: Not A Standout Visit - Better Chinatowns About
reviews: Having visited a fair few Chinatown's over the globe I was interested to check out Vancouver's Chinatown when in the city. Having just spent 3 days in Victoria I thoroughly enjoyed the Chinatown there and had high hopes for the one in Vancouver.In all honestly I was quite underwhelmed by it, there just didn't seem to be much there or going on other than the gate and a few signs. Having walked there from Gastown yes you do come across a couple of streets such as East Hastings St of which is known to be an area for homeless individuals / substance users. So if you do want to visit and think you would be uncomfortable / uneasy with this I would recommend walking from Granville St direction rather than from Waterfront. Or having said that simply get the SkyTrain? It is not a threatening area and my partner and I walked through there at 7:30 when there was next to no one else there as well as 16:30 when it was busy.If I were to go back to Vancouver I wouldn't consider it to be a "must do" area, I personally found the Victoria Chinatown much more intriguing.

title: Nothing to see or Experience
reviews: Maybe its because I've seen and been to so many other Chinatowns in other cities that i'm kind of disappointed in the Chinatown of Vancouver. Nothing to see, nothing to eat and generally not a lot of life.   Just some old buildings that you can probably cover by car or by walking through.

title: Something different
reviews: Chinatown is a different pace than other neighbourhoods in Vancouver. A little older but with plenty of character.Some good restaurants, but my favourite thing is the shops. Great place to find some cool deals. Wouldn't call it a must see neighbourhood but it is worth walking around and checking out.

title: Not worth the visit
reviews: The area is dirty, many homeless people and is very decadent. There are many chinese products stores but seems to be for locals, not really a touristic attraction. We went there expecting to find some good chinese restaurants but there aren't. There are two or three restaurants in the area but none of them caught our attention.

title: Lots of funky grocery stores and some tasty bakeries
reviews: I really wanted to enter through the ornate gates, like in SF. But I guess we missed those. We walked around on a rainy afternoon and saw hundreds of bizarre mushrooms, fruits, dried shrimp and lots of other foreign foods,  Couldn't any CDN $ from ATM, so we bought a little hum bao with our $USD.  The baos were enormous.  Filled with bbq pork. Delish.  Equal in size to about 3 buns at home.  We strolled around and ended up in a fun antiques shop. Some good looking eateries, but we were here in between lunch and dinner.

title: Weird experience part II
reviews: Connection to my Gastown review. Chinatown was a bit of a letdown. When we walked from Gastown to Chinatown, things got weird. Within half a block of the main Gastown alleys, the situation degraded rapidly, and we stumbled upon a large collection of people who were clearly serious drug users. I am not sure if we wandered through a needle-exchange zone or what, but there were about 100 people from all walks of life concentrated on a small street corner and it was clear that these folks did not feel well. No violence, no threats, just a feeling of uneasiness. Caught this family of four (with 2 young kids) off guard. Would have appreciated some sort of "warning" I guess. Spent the next two hours explaining to my kids what we had just wandered through. The walk to Chinatown was not really worth it in hindsight. The gate was nice and we found an authentic restaurant which we really enjoyed, but connecting the dots between Gastown and Chinatown on foot was a mistake. Would have appreciated a warning of some sort, my bad.

title: Hard to witness the Decline!
reviews: This entire section of historic Vancouver is getting smaller every visit.First trip was in the late 70,s and the changes in this cultural gem is sad to watch.One positive is the summer night markets which are great.The day to day volume of bustle is way lower every visit.Still a must see when in Vancouver with some great dining and shopping spots!

title: Meal??
reviews: After leaving the BCPlace watching the rugby 7s we decided to go to China Town for a meal. After going through the ornate gates we could find nowhere to eat and the  area was not too good. We decided to turn left, which was the first mistake. going down the road and left again we found ourselves among a decidedly dodgy set of people. It was obvious that there was a lot of sleeping rough in the doorways and just along the road was the drug overdose facility. Such a shame that the area is advertised and yet so run down.

title: Druggie Central
reviews: As someone who used to live in Vancouver, I'm not exaggerating when I say that China Town is druggie central.  In fact, Main and Hastings (which is only one block away) is the worst part of Canada as far as drugs go.  Since it's chinatown, the local Chinese go there for whatever they need.  However, the locals who aren't Chinese try to avoid this area as much as possible.  China town itself has some cool stuff, but it's really a pity that it infiltrated and surrounded by the worst sort of people you can imagine.  High crime and massive drugs abound.  I also used to work in a bank and was told that the branch in Chinatown got robbed a lot, which doesn't surprise me, considering the area.  I do like the Chinese gate though.  If you're visiting Vancouver, there is no need to visit Chinatown.

title: Vagrant town????????
reviews: After going to see Gassy Jack, we walked up to have a look at China town. It wasn't a very nice area. There were a lot of vagrants on the streets and some seedy looking activities going on down the side streets. I felt uncomfortable there, not scared, but left the area pretty quickly to get back to a better area of the city. Wouldn't recommend this area.

title: Not as bad as described here: you need to be in right area
reviews: Chinatown IS NOT full of junkies as most say here. (Like these users) the first time I've gone there, I missed the boarders of where to go and where China town ends and walked right into the bad neighborhood of Vancouver  (which is east hastings). If you want to have a fun time, you need to know where to go.  Make sure you always avoid northern main street and East Hastings. Stay between the edge of hastings and the park by Keefer street and you'll be fine. Then it's great. Many interesting shops, the garden is great and a nice mixture of city views and Chinese vibes.  Check out the spice stores and your senses will explode :) Keefer bar is nice for drinks afterwards. Try acme cafe for a great lunch!If you ever feel like you are in a weird area and it's losing the Asian charm, feel free to ask some locals for the way. Ps. Living in Vancouver has taught me how important it is to "see junkies" sometimes.  It's a City with many homeless and drug addicted people, because it's one of the most expensive cities to live in in the whole world. You can afford to take a trip here? Go to east hastings and learn how great you have it.  Seriously, I have not heard of any tourists being hurt in that area. Stay in a group, do it at daylight and be nice to the homeless and you'll see how these are just people in need. It's just part of the experience. It's okay to be freaked out when you see someone shoot heroine in front of you. But it also teaches you so. Much.

title: Not worth the effort
reviews: This area has completely fallen off the radar and not wirth making any special effort to go there....the best chinese food is in Richmond.....take your pick of any restaurant there, they are all good.

title: We could not find what we expected...
reviews: When we have heard that is big and good , we wanted to see China town ... But we could not find what we expected.. The china was uninspired and dirty ...

title: 2 days in Vancouver
reviews: Coming up to Chinese New Year and in Vancouver for 2 days. We walked to China town at night for a meal and a look round - BIG mistake - do NOT go there. The other reviews are correct - it is dirty, seedy, run down and lots of iron mesh/ gates on windows etc. If you stray too far south as we did you end up in East Hastings - seriously bad !! Full of down and out / druggies - not a nice place at all. We kept on walking as fast as we could to get out of there and back into one of the many very nice areas in Vancouver. Great city but avoid Chinatown at all costs.

title: HORRIBLE
reviews: We got mixed reviews on whether to go to Chinatown or not, but were bored one day and decided to give it a try. It was the WORST decision. The area is beyond gross. The windows are filthy - the awnings are gross. Nothing is clean. There are homeless people everywhere. We saw throw-up on doors, pee on the streets, and even feces matter. We witnessed several drug purchases and people using right on the street. It felt extremely unsafe to be walking - and that was in the middle of the day. The stores are so gross, I wouldn't even think about eating down there!!! DO NOT GO.

title: Don't go
reviews: It was mid winter and 10 degrees below normal.  Could barely fine a place to walk into to get warm.  Nothing to see, nothing to do.  If you want to see something, don't go here.

title: Soulless
reviews: Compared to other Chinatowns in San Franciso, London etc. the Vancouver Chinatown is a place of desolation, boarded up shops, those that were open did not look really welcoming, rubbish and gulls everywhere, it just had no soul. We could not even identify where it started and it had absolutely no flair. We were approached by quite a few beggars and tramps and people were shivering in the cold and hanging out in dorrways and bus stops shouting and swearing. The only haven was the Chinese garden

title: The area Vancouver wants to forget about
reviews: It is sad that this historic area is so run down and desolate. You can literally tell where the city's modern development ends and Chinatown starts from the architecture - it is that stark. Several streets of shops and restaurants but you can barely tell the difference between the few which are still trading and those that have been closed for years.It is a real shame and - in global city terms - a black mark on Vancouver's otherwise great image. The whole place screams of poverty.Note -I wouldn't buy/eat from some of the local roast meat shops - many were serving cooked meats from one counter and then selling raw meats from an adjacent one! How does this pass any sane food safety procedure???

title: They deserve the present status!
reviews: Forty years ago when I first moved to Vancouver this Chinatown was the happening place for new immigrants. The longing for Chinese food drew us there. The shopkeepers, mostly from Toisan in Guangdong province, were busy and proud of their businesses. However they looked down on us new immigrants mainly because we didn't contribute to their cultural investment. You see, historically they went through a lot! Discrimination, molestation, alienation these Chinese suffered greatly from suppression by the WASPS!Give them the right therefore to be rude to newcomers. But newcomers speak with their pockets. So when alternatives popped up in Richmond and Burnaby, these newcomers disappeared from Chinatown. I was one of them. Today Chinatown in Vancouver is no longer Chinatown. There's nothing I can call Chinatown there. So, if you want to see Chinatown don't go there! You'll be disappointed. Instead go to Richmond where great food awaits you!

title: Great little area right in the heart of town centred on Gas Street
reviews: Quite a lot of Chinese restaurants.. Good for your dim sum brunch or afternoon breaks.  Gets busy on the wekend

title: Historic Entrance, However!
reviews: We wanted to take a stroll through Chinatown and went through the main gates. It reminded me of some of the great sites we did experience & travels in China. However it was sad to see the homeless people walking on the streets, while on drugs! Suggest to anyone do not go out on your own, especially in the evening hours!!

title: Rundown and dilapidated
reviews: We were looking forward to seeing the second largest Chinatown in North America. Unfortunately it did not meet our expectations. I can only assume previous good reviewers visited the area as part of a formal tour or some years ago. We visited on a November weekend on our way to the Dr Sun Yat-Sen garden (which incidentally was well worth a visit.) Most shops and restaurants were closed and there were many homeless people with very blatant drug use taking place. Not a nice place at all, we both felt very uncomfortable and concerned for our safety.

title: Authentic China experience
reviews: Many cities have a China Town for tourists which can be a collection of fake plaster temple dogs and plastic Buddahs next to a takeout festooned with with red paper lantens. Chinatown Vancouver is the real deal. Entire streets are filled with Chinese grocery shops and steaming restaurants selling all manner of Asian delicacies. Not a European in sight. I came across a shop preparing fishjust like old Hong Kong. Beautiful Chinese fine art and jewellery is for sale in upmarket stores and you can still eat American if fried duck and noodles is not your taste.Not to be missed for those seeking an authentic Asian experience.

title: Vancouver China Town was an interesting walk!
reviews: Due to the fact that I walk everywhere when I travel, walking to, and through, China Town in Vancouver was a worth-while experience.  The major points of interest…the Chinese Gate, the neon sign in the Plaza, the community centre, the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese Garden, and the Monument of Canadian Chinese…were all worth visiting.  The Chinese stores were full of unusual and interesting items and foods.Yes, the area might look seedy, and you’ll see homeless people around, but you’ll find homeless people in Vancouver no matter where you go.

title: Go for a walk through and enjoy a great meal
reviews: Take the local bus (excellent transportation in Vancouver) and get off near the Gates to China Town. (Pender I think) Walk among the locals, visit the street markets with a plethora of interesting and unusual edibles and choose a lunch spot.  Also walk through Sun Yat Garden - beautiful and contemplative and must be beautiful during flowering season.  I wish I had left myself more time for Chinatown - 2-3 hours at least.

title: Disappointing
reviews: Chinatown in Vancouver is basically a slum neighborhood - depressing with lots of homeless/derelicts. But it has a large number of Chinese businesses - including restaurants, which seem to be popular.We were disappointed.

title: avoid
reviews: We visit Toronto on a regular basis and China town there is always a place we make a beeline for with its fantastic shops spilling their wares out onto the paths the delicious smells and vibrant colours and friendly people. Chinatown in Vancouver is the complete opposite. It was dirty, unkempt and very seedy. We felt very unsafe there and there were lots of homeless people hanging around begging, you had to even step over them.  Definitely avoid this place it is a cloud in an otherwise beautiful city.

title: The worth Chinatown ever!
reviews: Not worth the visit. Dirty, run down, a lot of homeless, junkies. Frightening! No commerce, few not to good looking restaurants!

title: Not your typical North American Chinatown
reviews: Run-down, soul-less area of town, just a short step away from Gastown and the buzz of Water Street. There was little eveidence of it being a 'Chinatown', no bright lights or spirit. It was the only place during our Canadian tour where we felt unsafe, with unsavoury street-dwellers rowing and drugs paraphernalia openly for sale. Apparently there is a big vagrant problem due to the mildness of the Vancouver climate compared with interior Canada. I don't think there's any real risk going to that part of the City, but nothing to draw you there either.

title: Really clean Chinatown area - used as "China" in many TV shows and movies :)
reviews: actually I visited in August 2012, not August 2016 - really clean Chinatown area, very Chinese, so maybe not much to do but look around if you aren't Chinese - interesting and fun!

title: Junkie central in a beautiful city
reviews: Beware of the area around Chinatown - East Hastings St. Vancouver has a major drug problem and most of it is centred around the corner of East Hastings and Abbott St., on the fringe of Chinatown. While not particularly threatening the presence of so much human misery can be a bit depressing.Otherwise Vancouver is a beautiful city. A tip for casual travellers is to take a ferry from Horseshoe Bay to Bowen Island or Langdale for Gibson's Landing - beautiful scenery on a nice day.The market on Granville Island is well worth a visit with a return walk over the Granville Bridge offering great views.We found Gastown a little disappointing with fewer restaurants than we expected - weekends become very busy and booking ahead makes sense.

title: Don't go!
reviews: Got off the hop on bus looking for a place to have lunch. Everything looked 'seedy' and run down. We passed many vagrants and homeless both in side alleys and the main road. Mentally ill were numerous as they talked to themselves. We were not at all comfortable there and ended up eating at the airport. One and done!

title: Moderate Sized Chinatown; Moderately Scenic
reviews: I have visited Chinatown's in many, many cities in N. America, including the one in Victoria. I recently walked the length and breadth of Vancouver's old Chinatown (I say old, since many of the newest sleekest and swankiest buildings in Vancouver are also owned by the Chinese). Much is as in many other Chinatowns...specialty food shops catering to residents, trinket and gift shops and a number of locally owned businesses also catering to other Chinatown residents. This one was of moderate size, but overall, I found it somewhat unmemorable except for the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Chinese Garden area. That was very nice and perhaps unique...but the many blocks of sidewalk we traversed were of limited general interest, but relatively clean and felt overall pretty safe in the daytime. Worth a look see if you've got time for a stroll, but I personally didn't find a great deal of scenic or culinary import on my visit.

title: Visit to Chinatown Vancouver, British Columbia
reviews: Purchased a day pass on the local transportation system. We took a train from the Waterfront Station to the Chinatown Station three stops. The area around the train station was clean the buildings were modern. We walked about four blocks to Chinatown. The buildings were old and not as clean as around the train station. We made some purchase in the local stores the prices were very good and the staff were friendly.

title: Sketchy
reviews: We walked through Chinatown in the hopes that we would come across the best Chinese food we would ever eat. Upon walking through the gates, it is not very attractive or appealing. There is a lot of grafitti on walls and buildings and young people hanging around in groups (gangs). We walked a long distance and had difficulty finding any Chinese restaurants. We stopped at a sandwich shop and asked if they could recommend a good Chinese restaurant. We were told "there is not a good Chinese restaurant in Chinatown"! They recommend we go out out of Chinatown to find good Chinese food! We were tired of walking and hungry so we walked about 10 more minutes and walked into a Chinese restaurant. To tell you the truth, I did not take note of the name because the food was less than mediocre. The fried rice was flavorless, the spring rolls were supposed to be pork but were filled with some kind of bad tasting meat mush. The pork ribs were mostly bone and fat. We left quickly so we could be out of Chinatown before dark! It's not worth your time!

title: Faded and jaded
reviews: Reached here by the Hop On/Hop Off bus and apart from the Dr Sun Yat-Sen gardens, there's really no need to go there.  The gardens themselves are peaceful and pleasant, with some free areas and some areas you need to pay to enter, but Chinatown itself was lifeless and drab.  To be generous, perhaps we were there at the wrong time (weekday, late afternoon).Not even the gardens would justify a special visit to the area.

title: Would avoid
reviews: Have visited China Towns all over the world and have loved everyone of them, so was looking forward to Vancouver. I have never felt so uncomfortable.  It is so run down, lots and I mean lots  of homeless. We passed an alleyway full of down and outs and junkies.  Could not get out quick enough.  Visitors beware.

title: A éviter
reviews: Not a very nice neighbourhood. The poorest area of the city. We did not feel safe. We wanted to go find a restaurant and left quickly. Interesting architecture.

title: Sadly now Skid Row :-( go to Richmond instead
reviews: This is very sadly now a very poor and potentially dangerous place.  Although there are still some good Asian restaurants here you are much better to head to Richmond.  I don't know about the actual crime statistics but I travel a lot and to many poorer countries and I felt very unsafe here.

title: Could use a freshen up!
reviews: While we thoroughly enjoyed all the little shops, the area itself could really use some freshening up. Lots of filthy buildings, broken sidewalks etc. Has lots of potential...love Chinatowns!!

title: Looking a little tired.
reviews: The entrance to Chinatown is fantastic, beautiful.  Beyond this, its a bit grubby looking but the shops are great.  I bought all my souvenirs here, they really were half the price of gastown!  Had a traditional Chinese meal, very reasonable and so tasty.  We made our way to gastown from here and there are a lot of homeless and drug addicts but they didn't bother us, just walked on by so didn't feel uncomfortable.

title: Needs regeneration
reviews: Wandered around  China town today and my wife felt quite uncomfortable. Many homeless and drug addicts about. It was Labour day and the place seemed closed and empty. We eventually came across the park and Chinese garden which was ok but not really worth the effort to get there.We've been to many many China towns across the world and this was the most disappointing by far.

title: Unfriendly place full of people down on their luck
reviews: This is the underbelly of Vancouver in all its unbridled glory. You will see homeless and drug addicted people carrying out their lives as best they can. Don't go expecting to see Chinese culture, this is education on the poor and destitute. The inhabitants never bothered us, just ignored us and carried on with their day. I would strongly advise against taking small children. Avoid this place if the above experience is not what you are after.

title: A Great Day in Chinatown
reviews: We just returned from a terrific trip to Vancouver! I plan to post a trip report soon, but I really wanted to write this post today in case anyone was contemplating visiting Chinatown while in Vancouver. We actually really enjoyed our our guided trip to Chinatown! I highly recommend visiting Chinatown with a guide because you will view it  as so much more than a run down area.  We had just taken a terrific Granville Island walking tour with Erik through Tourguys.com (pay as you think it's worth type of tour) and decided to take a chance with the Tourguys two hour Chinatown tour. It was a terrific tour!  Erik, an award winning film producer of documentaries about British Columbia, led our tour and  he was so knowledgeable and interesting to listen to.  I could go on and on and about how great of a guide he was. The tour started in the middle of downtown, and we walked all the way to Chinatown. On the way to Chinatown we learned about Vancouver's history, architecture, murals, etc. Before we entered Chinatown, Erik explained the history of the area; it is not a history that the people of British Columbia are proud of  because Chinese were treated terribly and lived in horrible conditions.  I won't go into the detail here, but you can read about it online. As we walked through the Chinatown streets, Erik discussed Chinatown's present condition, its architecture, historic buildings/sculptures/people, etc. and what is being done to improve the area. During the tour, we were able to view the streets as areas of history and progress instead of viewing them only as a run down part of town. On the tour, we also walked through the serene the Dr. San Yat-Sun public park .  After the tour, we wish would've had enough time to visit the the Dr. San Yat-Sun private garden (for a fee) and the taken the guided tour.  Instead, with the little time we had left, we went to a restaurant Erik pointed out on the tour and enjoyed a take-out of delicious steamed buns and  apple turnovers. We had a very interesting, educational day in Chinatown and I highly recommend Tourguys as a tour company!

title: Local Neighborhood - Chinatown, Vancouver
reviews: We went to Chinatown.  Its a smaller one and has its variety of local Asian cafes.  Its more a place to live than to visit.  The Sun Yat Sen Garden is in this area.When comparing it to the Chinatown area in San Francisco where I live close to, I find it average. I did like the dragons on the street signs and the colorful Panda banners.

title: Bring A Broom
reviews: There was four of us and because I love Chinese food, I convinced the others to come. It was on our Hop On Hop Off bus route so no big deal. BUT real dirty. Quite a contrast to the rest of Vancouver which is so clean. Hard to convince anyone to eat at one of the local restaurants with so much dirt around. I did and I shouldn't have.

title: Not a spot for visitors
reviews: Look at the tourist maps, Chinatown is a short walk from the bottom of a Water street in Gastown. That walk is one you should  miss.... homelessness, evident drug use and and the feel that a lot of the area was closed down and barred up. If like us you were in search of some great Chinese food.... head up to Robson street instead.

title: makes no sense - to avoid
reviews: it is a small Chinese quarter close to Vancouver Downtown East; the quarter is quite small and without peculiar attractions (only the Sun Yat Sen Garden is a interesting place); be careful : do not walk from Gastown to Chinatown ; it is only a couple of blocks but it is homeless area and looks dangerous.

title: It's Alright
reviews: My wife and I took a walk through Chinatown. It is not overly large, but does give you a sense of a community. The Garden near the entrance is very pretty, but that really is it for sights. There are many shops, but must do not have items for tourists. However, they are neat to stroll through and I understand that Chinatown is not meant to cater to tourists. by far the best part of Chinatown is the opportunity to enjoy some delicious food.

title: A Neighborhood, not a Tourist Attraction
reviews: There is an area of Vancouver noted on maps as 'Chinatown' where a high concentration of residents of Chinese descent are clearly maintaining their heritage.  It is not a clean tidy Disneyland type tourist attraction.  It is a neighborhood.  There are a number of produce and meat stores that cater to the residents' preferred ingredients.  They are in small mom-and-pop storefronts, not a tidy Safeway store.  There are cooking utensils sold that are not found in Bed Bath and Beyond.  There are small clothing stores selling items not found at the mall.  There are many traditional noodle eating establishments.  I didn't see any restaurants catering to the tourist looking for sweet and sour pork.  The Chinese Cultural Center is clearly a space for community functions.  The gardens in the center are obviously an oasis in the midst of busy, crowded urban streets - equally an oasis for tourists tired of the noise and crowds found on most Downtown Vancouver streets.  Chinatown is a neighborhood.  They don't appear to have any inclination to cater to tourists.  This is their home.  If you are looking for culture on display, this isn't it.  If you are looking to see how one faction of the city lives their daily lives, take a walk through their streets and appreciate the diversity that makes Vancouver the city it is today.

title: East Vancouver
reviews: There are a few Chinatowns in the area, but this one is the only one with the nice gates and nice garden, and also well known in the whole area. In some places you can find very good and cheap Chinese food, but I would not advise to go and visit, It is a poor area with some crime and not very healthy places. It is an interesting experiment and visit if you don't care about the environment.

title: Worst Chinatown ever visited
reviews: We went there today, because we wanted to visit the Sun Yat-Sen garden. The garden itself is beautiful, but outside the garden white walls, there were lot's of homeless people and people taking harddrugs in the open air, especially at the Pender street. After seeing the garden, we wanted to go away as soon as possible. Worst Chinatown ever visited.  If you want to get there anyway, don't walk from Gastown. Best take the skytrain.

title: Disappointingly lacking in interest
reviews: We had expected more from the title; this barren group of streets is lacking in any character or interest to a visitor - except for the Dr Sun Yat-Sen Garden. We were told that many of the Chinese families had moved out.

title: Don't waste your time
reviews: I will not waste your time with a long review, don't go! It is a run-down area with dingy shops and a few cheap restaurants that I would not eat in. Enough said!

title: Just 2 streets long. But loads of shops and history of the area
reviews: We saw the smallest street anywhere, and later learned that it was the narrow street that Mel Gibson rode through on a motorcycle with Goldie Hawn in the movie Bird on a Wire.Can't remember the street name. Over all was displeased with the number of homelesspeople there on the streets, but some places have more than others.

title: A bit of a dump
reviews: We went to Vancouver's Chinatown to visit the Keefer Night Market - using an old guide book. Since this I think it's must have declined quite a bit. There is still some interesting architecture especially the entrance gate and of course the Chinese Garden is a must visit. But there is also lots of tramps, drugs use and we did spot a cross dressing prostitute. Avoid at night (unless any of these things interest you!)

title: Chinese and homeless
reviews: I find it always interesting to range through different parts of a city and Chinatown is definitely a variety but the number of homeless people is depressing. If you have been in Chinatown NY you can easily skip the visit. Although the Chinese garden is really nice!

title: Huge Chinatown
reviews: Beautiful Chinatown with a lot of shops and reataurants.  Covers a lot of area - second in size to San Francisco.  Don't miss Dr. Sun Yat-Sen  Classical Gardens - there is a charge for this.   We has lunch at Flota Seafood Restaurant which had authentic Chinese food, not American Chinese.  It is located on the third floor of China Town Plaza.  It has some shops on the first floor.

title: Worst Chinatown, which I have seen
reviews: Plse avoid this part. There are very dirty places here and Chinatowns in London, SFO or NYC are more attractive. It is a waste of time to go here. Dirty, dangerous.

title: Be Careful
reviews: Too many homeless people and shuttered stores. It is touted as the second largest China town after San Francisco but it has gone way down hill. We got off the trolley and got back on the next one that passed by. It doesn't feel safe.

title: Great early evening ealk
reviews: I enjoyed walking around Chinatown, it is beautiful! However, I want all travelers to known that it is near a dodgy part of town that I would not suggest. He street to be careful around is E. Hastings street. You can get from Chinatown to Downtown and back while avoiding this area but going to Gastown serves a problem.

title: Mixed
reviews: The number of homeless people was scary . Even local people as they provided information on catching the city bus directed us to a corner "that might not be so uncomfortable"    Enjoyed the Chinese garden and Happy house Chinese food delicious

title: Unpleasant
reviews: We had been told that we would find some of the best Chinese food in North America in Vancouver's Chinatown. We were very disappointed. The area is very rundown and felt threatening to us.  There were Chinese shops and a handful of restaurants, but we will not be going back. An area to avoid

title: An experience you can do without
reviews: Caution!! Do not go there.  Chinatown has been taken over by the homeless and destitute.  It is run down, dirty and unsafe.  I visited on a Friday afternoon.  Most things were locked up and there were no restaurants that I could see.  I hastily retreated from this unsavoury area, never to return.

title: Go somewhere else
reviews: Vancouver tourism sites on the internet may have led you into thinking that the Chinatown is worth a trip, but you'd be wasting your time. When we were there in July 2016, most stores were shuttered down. What was worse was that it seemed like the place had been taken over by hordes of homeless people half of whom had already passed out at 11 o'clock in the morning. In fact, this was the only place not too far from downtown Vancouver where we saw a police officer patrolling the streets. The place must have seen better days. What a shame.

title: First Chinatown Ever
reviews: This is the first China Town we ever visited and not quiet sure if this is how they are supposed to be. We went right in the afternoon and didn't really feel very safe except while in the mall in the vicinity.Definitely not a place to venture out during the night.

title: Not sure it's worth the risk
reviews: Went on a bus tour and jumped off to have a look . Wow it's not like any other Chinatown I've been to tbh . Sparse and rundown . There are a few shops and restaurants but it's not the most appealing of areas and I certainly wouldn't like to be here near dark . We certainly didn't linger nor in Hastings which was fully worse .

title: NOPE. NOPE. NOPE.
reviews: More like homeless town. Definitely not the place you want to go with family or even alone. It's filled with homeless and junkies.  All the buildings look old. Unless you are fan of the Chinese culture and yoy can't go without looking at old and ugly Chinese buildings just avoid especially if you are walking.

title: Scariest place ive ever been
reviews: I mistakenly took the viaduct and went through Chinatown...this was the scariest place I've ever been. Hundreds upon hundreds of homeless people everywhere and they're not friendly! It goes on for 5 blocks, I was absolutely afraid. I've never seen anybody smoke meth before, now I have so you know I can take that off my bucket list. There may be a section more north that isn't as bad but I wouldn't go anywhere in this direction ever again to even find out.

title: Avoid at all cost
reviews: This place is nothing like any other China Town we've visited. It's run down with junkies walking about and trading in full view. Frightening is the only word to describe and shocking. Many homeless sleeping rough and evidence of drug taking everywhere. We couldn't wait to get out and felt very threatened. Avoid at all cost

title: Not many things to do
reviews: When you read Vancouver reviews, they often say to pass a day in Chinatown and Gastown, but honestly I don't think it's a must-to-do. The only activity with children to do is the Chinese Gardens. It's not really a nice place. There's many homeless people. Sometimes there was people saying we shouldn't continue to walk because it was as a rough place. Later I learned it was the only place that the homeless people could go. If you have free-time, this s really not the activity you should do.

title: excellent walking tour
reviews: if you want to experience chinatown, this is great.  we have favourite stores that we visit when we are in vancouver. we discovered a cool store on keefer street.  i think the address is 268 keefer street.  on the second floor there are cool shops.  we like to look and buy trinkets.  usually we park at keefer and columbia.  parking is free for the first 1/2 hour and then $1.50/half hour.

title: Excellent Place
reviews: If you go to Vancouver you have to go to Chinatown. It is great to see, of course you are simply hearing from my point of view. But it isn't a place that I would only go once. I love going when I go to Vancouver. I love the store owners there...well I enjoy talking...and they have always been friendly. I have even bartered with one this time in a fun way. Here You will find everything you love about traditional Chinese culture. Even if you don't believe in the Chinese Zodiac, it is "cool" to look into it and talk to them about it, learn something about it. You can buy something awesome on East Pender Street...trusssst me..."Usually, people regard snake as a cunning and sly animal, which likes hanging out in darkness. In fact, this animal is also a symbol of wisdom and wit."Go shopping at the Chinatown Flea Market on Keefer Street. Great Deals!!! There is always the Chinese Tea to buy or medicines and lots of jewelry if you like that. Of course Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Chinese Garden, a must go to once. I want to take my daughter there, to see it.So much in Chinatown and lots of places to eat.LOVE IT!!!!

title: Nothing special avoid Hastings Street
reviews: Having gone to many Chinatowns throughout the United States, this Chinatown was nothing special.   Hastings Street appears  to be the refuge of the homeless population.

title: Don't go
reviews: This is the scariest place in Vancouver, a place where all the down and outs gather we went expecting to find the usual collection of restaurants and vibrant Chinese shops but even the tumbleweed has moved on...DON'T GO!!!

title: I expected more!
reviews: We went here expecting a lot more of the culture but all this area really offered was one stinky store after another.

title: Tropical fruits galore
reviews: If you want to taste your favorite tropical fruits such as jackfruit, lanzones, rambotan, lychee, mangosteen ,  mango , and many more then visit Chinatown, you will find nice bargain nice quality souvenirs, of course made in China. ..hahaha

title: In decline
reviews: Sadly, most of this area is a series of run down shops and restaurants.The city has a serious problem with homeless, unemployed, drunks and druggies. The solution seems to encourage them into this part of town where they litter the streets with both themselves and their detritus.However, do try Sai Woo's restaurant, an oasis of style and good food.

title: Sad
reviews: First thing I noticed was that there seemed to actually be fewer Chinese people here than elsewhere in the city. Seemed to be just down and outs everywhere, some very sad sights for a Saturday morning. Didn't feel aggressive really, just sad and disturbing more than anything. To be avoided.

title: Sad, it isn't vibrant at all
reviews: It was really sad to find a Chinaton without people, not many shops, I was hoping to find a wonderful place full of live but it was the opposite, and in one moment it felt dangerous as there were drunk people near this place.In my opinion, don't waste your time, there are better attractions in Vancouver, and if your are looking for asian food, you will find it every where.

title: not the best
reviews: dont expect china town as in san francisco as this is a much smaller version - interesting but i wouldnt make a special effort to visit - supposedly the largest in north america but that really doesnt alter the fact its quite small

title: Disappointing
reviews: The area of Chinatown is full of numerous mentally ill and drunk homeless people walking around and laying next to buildings.  The restaurants are spread out.  Due to all of the homeless walking around we picked a place to eat as we were tried of people asking for money.  Not impressed!

title: Oh dear
reviews: Like a few other reviewers (which I didn't read pre visit - damn) we are seasoned travelers, have been to Chinatowns all over world and are not remotely wimps.  But this was awful.  Taxi dropped us off and we wandered the area full of drug addicts, shut up shops and general grubbiness.  Even if we had found somewhere that looked ok I wouldn't have been comfortable eating there.  On the upside  we found another taxi to take us out of there.

title: Very disappointing and disturbing
reviews: Should have read the reviews before going to Chinatown.  Dirty, smelly, and just not a place you would want to visit.  Maybe taking a paid tour would have been better, but my advice is just stay away; unless you want to observe the seamier side of Vancouver.

title: Largest historic Chinatown in North America.
reviews: Immerse yourself in the eastern culture of one of the largest historic Chinatowns in North America. Enjoy authentic chinese cuisine, enjoy new discoveries in the variety of unusual smelling markets, shop in any of the many oriental stores,  appreciate the entry gates and designated heritage buildings, or relax and enjoy the koi ponds and classical gardens of  Dr. Sun Yat-Sen. Chinatown is home to the Sam Kee building the narrowest commercial building in the world on the corner of the Pender & Carroll.  Although  two storeys high, it is only six feet deep. Centred on Pender, and Keefer streets it is bordered by Gastown & Downtown Business District to the west, a residential area to the east,  and the Downtown Eastside ( Main street and significant social issues )  to the north.  Vancouver's growing social economic problems are evident as your reach these boundaries. The younger Chinese business population is moving to Richmond.  Should you adventure to the fringe areas  ensure you remain very alert.  Many other reviewers are  commenting on these fringe areas.  It is a non-violent area but if  you find yourself uncomfortable saying " no " to panhandlers please take a guided tour rather than miss this historic attraction.

title: Huge
reviews: Vancouver has a huge Chinatown. Plenty to see and no shortage of restaurants and shops selling all sorts.

title: Not safe. Not what you want to see
reviews: I've been to many Chinatowns all over the world and generally love the food bargains and hustle bustle. This was a horrible experience. Only a few shops stretched out over blocks of vacant buildings. The only redeeming qualities are a restaurant serving amazing steam pork buns and a beautiful Chineese garden with Koi fish. It is small but free. I was told that every rock in the garden was brought over from China. There is a large amount of homeless persons but even more drug addicts. I'm streetwise but do not suggest anyone to visit this area with out your radar on full alert.

title: Avoid Chinatown
reviews: Avoid Chinatown. Not worth it. I've heard that it used to be a lively, fun place but it certainly is not anymore. It's very shady, and Hastings street (the dodgy street) spills into Chinatown. It's dirty, and it smells awful, and there are no attractions that are worth seeing. Please do yourself a favour and don't go.

title: DO NOT GO HERE
reviews: This area is grubby, run down, and dangerous. It's very close to East Hastings Street and VERY easy to accidentally end up there. Do not fall in to the tourist trap and especially not on your own, with kids, or at night. The drug abuse in the area is prevalent, and it's a horrible sight to see. Do not go here.

title: Great Experience for all ages.
reviews: When I arrived I felt that I had left the USA and entered another world. Some of the shops sale the same things, but you can find a few that have some unique and original items. Give yourself plenty of time to take in all the sights and experience Chinatown with all your senses.

title: Despair in evidence !
reviews: Sad in so many ways. Drugs,decline and drunks! Chinatown should be a gem in the life of Vancouver- an international magnet. However, for the seasoned traveller it is a place of caution and despair. The contrast between the Alaskan boats and Chinatown could not be mor stark !! Actin needed urgently.

title: Do not go! Far from safe
reviews: Immediately upon arriving in Chinatown we were approached for money... No big deal after all coming from London we're used to that. But there so so many doped up people there, syringes on the floor, broken glass... It seriously did not feel like a safe place at all. We expected in to be busy and vibrant, and it was anything but. I couldn't get out of there fast enough...  An awful place.

title: Canadian Chinatown
reviews: This Chinatown is quite small, compared to others we've seen. We checked out the little streets and alleys and found some interesting shops and photogenic nooks and crannies. While in Vancouver, this area can easily be explored in a couple of hours, so you can plan your day seeing the other sites in the area as well.

title: Too many freaks, beggers and poverty on the streets
reviews: I can only compare Chinatown Vancouver with Chinatown, New York, which i visited earlier. There it was a clean, vibrant, busy place and i felt very safe. Had some good food there as well. In Vancouver i was not feeling comfortable. Poverty, drunks, beggars and drug addicts roam the streets. The restaurants and shops didn,t appeal to me either. I left within an hour.

title: Not a good place to go
reviews: If you are a tourist in Vancouver this is not worth a visit, it smells awful, there are lots of homeless people and drug users in the area, you will be approached by aggressive panhandlers. There are a couple of good Chinese restaurants there, and some not so good.  The stores can be interesting but overall not a nice place to go compared to other Chinatowns in other Cities

title: Okay Place for a Walk
reviews: We were surprised to see the number of homeless and the number of homeless that would try to intimidate you.  I've traveled plenty, however my children were not accustomed to dealing with the homeless.  Quick walk through Chinatown to see the architecture and some of the stores is plenty. Not a great to do list item with kids.

title: New businesses in Chinatown are very good!
reviews: Over all, it's very shady area, but there are new business that are bringing this area up a notch. I love New Town Bakery (which is a old business here but newly renovated a few years back), El Kartel - a coolest clothing boutique in Vancouver. If you want to look good in casual clothes (for travelers, best rain gear, coolest sunglasses and head to toe fashion), also showcasing local artists and designers. A great destination - right around the corner of Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden. In the same block, Bestie is a stylish casual eating place, speaking of stylish, there are MANY cool furniture makers in Chinatown, selling their handmade furniture. The Keefer Bar is cool for your birthday night out kind of thing! So don't dismiss this part of town, there are a lot going on!

title: The right balance between the old and the new tangible and intangible aspects of Chinatown
reviews: It is one of the top tourist sites in B.C., and it serves as a powerful symbol of the important place of Chinese Canadians in our shared history. Visit one of the world´s largest Chinatowns and appreciate the collection of 12 designated heritage buildings and tales that unfold the drama and link to the life of early Chinese pioneers. The Chinatown site is under a  revitalization project to preserve Chinatown's unique heritage while bringing new life to the community. We must ensure not to lose BBQ meat shops, fresh produce stores and restaurants like Phnom Penh and Newtown Bakery, and keep visiting beautiful gardens like the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese Garden; let´s also keep the spirit and the “intangible character”  of this special  neighbourhood, worth going to. We should breathe the fresh life into the Chinatown community, with all its economic and social benefits!

title: Aw, So Sad!
reviews: Too bad! Grew up in Vancouver, loved to go down to Chinatown..yummy food, great little funky shops, good vibe, great produce and fish markets above (east of) Main Street. So sad to see it run down, empty shops, no spirit! Nothing to shop for, no weird curio things to look at, it's just a wasteland. Even 'revitalised' Chinatowns in all the major US and Canadian cities have more energy, more buzz, than this sad place. Guidebooks say to go to Richmond for the Chinatown Experience, but Richmond is all 'new', no history, not what you'd call a historical, authentic, old time Chinatown. So, forget about going down to Prior & Powell Streets, try to find parking, only to be disappointed.

title: Don't bother
reviews: It's really not worth going too. Very small, only a few shops that serve the local Asian population. No decent restaurants and borders onto east Hastings street which you wanna avoid. P.S watch out for drug syringes lying around the streets.

title: This place sucked
reviews: If you are expecting a Chinatown like San Francisco or New York, please brace yourself for considerable disappointment.  This area was vile and infested with a lot of homeless people and beggars.  Enveloping the area were even more homeless people and prostitutes.  There were not that many shops and the ones that were there all looked the smelled the same.  This is seriously not a place where I would take friends or family to visit.

title: Really, really bad
reviews: This is -the- worst Chinatown that we've been to.  We live in Milwaukee and frequently visit the Chinatown in Chicago....it's so much better!  The San Fran CT is light years ahead.After staying in Victoria over the weekend and enjoying their Chinatown, we took the ferry over to Vancouver.  During the boat ride, we spoke with a Vancouver local.  He suggested that we not go to Chinatown and especially not at night.  I was pretty surprised and couldn't believe that a Chinatown area would be so dangerous.  I brushed off his advice and decided that he just couldn't be correct.Today, we walked from our hotel near Stanley Park east down Pender which leads directly through the Chinatown arch.  We immediately noticed how run-down the area is:  so many open storefronts, litter all over the streets, homeless people...not just homeless but crazy doped-up people.  Walking along, we smelled pot numerous times but worst of all we noticed a guy with a lighter, spoon, and needle...maybe crack or heroin?  Also, you'll frequently smell the sweet fragrance of public urination.It was around lunchtime and we expected to find some good restaurants.  Can you believe that there are no more than six or seven restaurants...not a one with a decent menu and all requiring cash payments only.  We were so disappointed and my wife (born in Chongqing and worked in Dongguan) was literally scared and disgusted.  The interesting thing that we noticed was that there were only elderly Chinese people there...no young or middle-aged people.  Basically, it seems that the middle class Chinese population has left Chinatown for dead.  So incredibly sad.

title: Has gotten a lot smaller.
reviews: We use to love going to Chinatown each time we visited Vancouver, but the last visit was a little disappointing.  We use to be able to spend the whole day in Chinatown with so many vendors and things to see.  Now the number of interesting vendors has decreased dramatically and there is not much to see or buy.  The last visit lasted us about less than an hour and we were done.

title: Sketchy Are
reviews: I've been to Chinatown in LA, NYC, Frisco, and Seattle and this one by far was the most run down and overwhelmed with homeless people. This China town has great potential but it needs some elbow grease. I don't recommend walking around there anytime after 8pm.

title: Nice arches, but that's about it
reviews: Currently, there is road construction happening in the area of Vancouver's downtown Chinatown. The stores are open during the construction. We found there to be not much to see in this historical part of Vancouver. One will find more variety for shopping in both restaurants and goods if they take the Skytrain or drive out to the suburb of Richmond. One of the comments of the downtown Chinatown is that it is in an undesirable area. Yes, this is very true. However, take the time to perhaps take a guided historical walking tour. Here you will learn about the early days of Vancouver. Do take the time when you are in Chinatown to check out the narrowest commercial building in the world --- the Sam Kee building. It is located on the corner of the Pender & Carroll. Although it is two storeys in height, it is only six feet deep.

title: Sad part of town
reviews: until Vancouver can address the homeless and down and out on the streets in the area then Chinatown will dwindle to nothing. very dirty and tired - if you are determined to go then go - maybe a local can help

title: Bad area
reviews: As soon as we entered we encountered many people begging and people living on the street. This didn't make us feel very welcome or segure.

title: Don't bother
reviews: Vancouver is awesome but the Chinatown is far from that. We happened to be staying nearby so I strolled through one day and was pretty unimpressed. Dr. Sun yat sen park is really pretty and tranquil but any further and the area becomes undesirable. I was hoping to find some cheap produce or some fun shops but did not find anything good and just wanted to get out of there.

title: Very dirty not much to see
reviews: There wasn't much to see or do very dirty I didn't care for it there is a garden that is nice but it closes at 5 a lot of antique and vintage stores wasn't to far to walk

title: The place where you can get all you want
reviews: What I love about Chinatown is that you can get all you want. Food is excellent, the markets have a great variety and and there are thousands of stores.

title: Not much to see.
reviews: Do not go on a sunday. Nothing to see.  A lot of the stores were closed. Has a very old and neglected feel. Probably all the chinese now lives in Richmond. If you want to experience real chinese shopping, go to Richmond. This is waste of time.

title: Hhmmmmm.......
reviews: Not what we expected. Looks very run down, nothing special. Been there before noon and most places weren't even open. It's a quiet large area but it was really nothing special.....

title: No big city should be without one!
reviews: Really great to see this east meets west thing in most cities around the world, but it is just all the more so here, I am no truly extensive traveller, and am of the opinion there are other western cities that have a strong architectural and cultural crossover than Vancouver, like San Francisco for instance, but for me this is it, as I travelled around this city, I saw more people from the Pacific rim than I would see at home, lots of influences around the city, not just China town.I really enjoyed visiting Vancouver and chinatown, just wish I had more time for the city.

title: Still interesting after all these years
reviews: Sure Richmond and crystal mall have lots of Chinese shopping and bustle but the old Chinatown has a feel for days gone by. Not the hustle of former days but the nostalgia of when u jostled yr way down the street and hawkers and smells hit u like a ton of tofu. If u grew up here u can still recognize the clan association bldgs and the familiar cafes many of them gone like our parents

title: Chinatown tips
reviews: Chinatown has a very interesting history, but if you are not interested in history or old buildings you may find that there are not many shops or attractions to see.
