We do walking tours of Chinatown (vancouverwalks.com) and here are a few tips to get the most out of your walkabout. 1. do a bit of reading about 1911 Chinese revolution and Sun Yat Sen before visiting to understand why he is such a big deal in Chinatown.2. do not go on Monday during the winter because the Vancouver Chinese Cultural Center (VCCC) and Sun Yat Sen Park are closed3. do not go after 6 pm in the evening because most of the shops will be closed4. visit the VCCC if you can, both floors, it is free and interesting5. visit the Sun Yat Sen park, it is free but you will be charged for the Garden6. look in shops for things like unusual shark fins and lizard on a stick7. Bamboo Village has opium pipes and unusual things tucked away in the back (e.g. Chinese Army helmets)8. try some food, steamed bakery items are popular9. be aware of your surroundings, it is a non-violent neighborhood but there is a bit of property theft so keep an eye on your stuff10. you will be approached by panhandlers but if you just say "no" firmly then they will not trouble you further. If you give money to one of them you will likely be approached by others.11. afterwards take the Skytrain to Richmond from Chinatown Station and visit a mall to get the modern Chinatown experience

title: A little uninteresting...
reviews: I went to Chinatown later on a Saturday morning and found it to be a bit uneventful.  I expected there to be a market or something but I couldn't find one and a lot of the shops were closed. I went to the garden and it was a nice little oasis in the city. The area is very easy to get to via bike lanes in Vancouver. I was told that Chinatown is dirty, but I didn't find it much different from other streets in the city centre of Vancouver. I have also heard complaints of feeling unsafe there but I never had this issue either. Not sure if I would go back again.

title: Vancouver's Chinatown is in dire need of renewal
reviews: Chinatown as we now know it is only a few steps from being a slum.  Gone are the bygone days when neon lights, fancy signs and every day merchants reigned Pender Street.  It's absolutely shameful how Vancouver's Chinatown has been permitted to to fall into such shameful disrepair.  Travelers be aware that the Downtown East Side is not the safest place to roam.  Be aware also that Vancouver's sister city of Richmond also boasts a Chinatown.

title: Not what we expected
reviews: Chinatown is easy to find, but not what we expected.  Nice walk but we did not stay very long. Maybe we did not find the busy shopping area.

title: Very Disappointing
reviews: I was so excited visit Chinatown after visiting Chinatown in other cities. First of all there was construction everywhere which made it impossible to get into some shops. That being said, don't bother going. There is nothing there. I kept walking, looking and hoping to find the good area and there simply wasn't one. My husband kept wanting to turn around and go back because the place felt so unsafe. It was full of homeless people and drug addicts. The only place that was interesting was the Chinese Cultural Center. We did find a little place to have a cup of hot tea and a pastry. If in the area I will not return to this area.

title: a must-see destination when in Vancouver
reviews: Vancouver has the biggest Chinatown in Canada. I have been to London's Chinatown once, and this time, i did go to visit this Chinatown in Vancouver. There are varying Chinese characters on the doorplates of houses and shops on both sides of the street. I have a feeling that I'm in China when i came here. Along the streets, there are traditional Chinese medicine pharmacies, butcher, fish &vegetable shops, dried seafood shops and grocery stores. All the restaurants are full from 11：00 am to 14：00 pm, people like to chat with family or friends while having a cup of tea and dim sum( Go early! ). I like the atmosphere.

title: Good things must be hidden
reviews: I've been there a few times and simply could not find anything picturesque or interesting, and fine Chinese restaurants I always find elsewhere.

title: Worst experience ever!! Stay clear ....
reviews: Was excited while walking there to see China Town thinking it would be vibrant like Sydney and London...but was a shocking experience...full of homeless people, druggies and it did not feel safe...though only a mile away from center it felt very unsafe.Please stay safe if you happen to visit there and do not speak with strangers...keep your valuables on guard and try not to go there at night.Nit an experience you want to take back home from your experience!!Jay

title: Do a tour then explore Chinatown!
reviews: Did you know that Vancouver's Chinatown is the largest in Canada? Did you know that the red lamp posts within Chinatown designates Chinatown proper? Did you know that Chinatown is a tourist attraction and a thriving community? If you don't know all the answers, then I highly recommend taking a tour of the area and then exploring Chinatown with knowledge and insight. I recently enjoyed a tour of the area with Judy Lam Maxwell and her Historical Chinatown Tours. Please see her listing for more info or search Chinatown girl Vancouver.After the tour, I gained an appreciation for the area. It's past, present and future. I could view the buildings with greater architectural appreciation. Look at the neon with new found love. Enjoy the bakeries, BBQ pork shops, and fruit & veggie stores knowing that this is a working neighborhood full of history, culture and people. Walk into the herbal shop to smell the ginsing and admire the dried mushrooms and strange sea creatures.Yes, I noticed that many of the store fronts are empty. But I also noticed that the area is being revitalized. Developers are saving the Victorian buildings and turning them into galleries, businesses, nouveau restaurants, reclaimed furniture stores and more. Mixed in are the traditional souvenir shops and older Chinese people living in the community. There are social clubs and people's lives hidden behind the doorways. But how can you expect to learn if you are just walking around aimlessly? Knowledge is power people!In my opinion, Chinatown is colourful, clean and exciting. On a Sunday afternoon, I did not feel threatened or scared. I highly recommend walking along the main streets of Pender and Keefer. Explore the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Park (it's free) and pick up some fresh steamed buns from Maxim's. Enjoy the sound of the Chinese language and the people. But I highly recommend you take a tour first.Please view my photos as it will give you greater insight into this rich historical area.

title: Loved it
reviews: Really felt the culture closely there. Many do not even speak English. Loved to shop there and going through many stores.

title: Quite run down
reviews: Whilst walking from Gas town to the Chinese garden, I took a stroll through china town....which was a very quick stroll.Immediately got bad vibes around the place and the people looked pretty rough. Popped into a cute Chinese tea shop but would avoid this area in future!The Chinese garden would cute though!

title: Wet Sunday in a very scary place
reviews: I would positively not recommend this place.  It is not a place for the faint hearted. If you are on the street and not homeless you are in a minority. Even during the day. This place has so much opportunity but has been sadly mismanaged. I was very nervous and on my guard. The shops are too spread out to every feel as though you are in a china town. Went to Richmond about 10 miles down the road. No atmosphere but good shopping for food.

title: Chinatown as ever alike in all cities held Chinese businesses
reviews: A two and a half hour drive from Seattle take us to Chinatown Vancouver. As they are all alike we could see many Chinese restaurants, groceries, souvenir shops ect.In fact, since the Chinese from Hongkong immigrate to Vancouver, they bring all the best chefs and movie stars & other careers people to Vancouver - that make Vancouver named as having the best Cantonese restaurants in the world.Then the house market rise terribly, although Chinatown community is shrinking - still that is where the Chinese do business mostly. Dr. Sun Yat Sen garden is another nice attraction to visit.

title: Huge Chinatown
reviews: Lots to eat and look at, so big, you need to go there few times to go through most thing.So many tourist tasting tour, we didn't join any, simply walked around.  Very interesting!Dr Sun Yat-Sen Park is small with Chinese garden characters.

title: All the Chinese businesses
reviews: A little disappointingly, this is no longer the Chinatown community where people live their lives, but so more to find in Chinese shopping. Tea, herbal remedies and food, food, food! Explore and enjoy. Find a good guided tour and hear the stories of old rough Vancouver :)

title: True Chinese Experience
reviews: Chinatown is slowly shrinking as a large part of the community relocates to Richmond and other areas of the Greater Vancouver District, Chinatown still has much to offer tourists and locals alike. Find great deals on produce, see traditional Asian apothecaries and discover Dim Sum, Peking Duck and other delicacies. Vancouver is know for some of the best Chinese food in the world and Chinatown is a great place to hunt it down. See Dr. Sun Yat Sen gardens as well, and then head out to one of the many restaurants for true Cantonese, Szechuan and other regional Asian foods. Enjoy the custom designed street lights, peace gates and wandering the streets admiring the beautiful Chinese characters that decorate the signs and transport you to a small corner of China.

title: Too close to undesirables
reviews: Quite quirky and is by all accounts second only in size to the Chinatown in San Francisco which I can testify to being much larger, however be warned that to stray in the wrong direction and you will be confronted by drunks and druggies. If you plan on visiting! Only do so during daylight hours and keep your wits about you at all times, reverse out of the place by the same safe route.Do your homework before entering, go armed with an area map.

title: Huge Chinatown
reviews: Vancouver's Chinatown is huge, an interesting place to walk and shop.  We found a lot of unusual items for sale plus everything we were looking for.

title: Very Good
reviews: This china Town consist of 3 blocks. They have very good deals with t-shirts and other tourist items. They have excellent restaurants.

title: Avoid the area
reviews: We walked here from Gastown late in the day expecting to find a nice Chinese restaurant for dinner. Instead we walked into the middle of an area inhabited by druggies shooting up and drunks. We tried to find a cab but obviously the cabbies steer clear too so were grateful when a helpful member of the police force helped us by calling a cab. He and his partners were keeping an eye on the druggie activities and "talking" to a few of them. He suggested that we were only on the edge of Chinatown but from what we could see the area was nothing like what you see in other vibrant Chinatowns around the world. Don't go there!!!

title: So Vibrant
reviews: Loved Chinatown  so much to see and do and everyone so helpful.  Had a great time seeing old and new buildings and so much to buy and enjoy.

title: Not a bad place to grab a quick bite
reviews: I wouldn't make a habit of it but if you're hungry on the way back from Gastown to the hotels of Vancouver, this is a perfectly adequate place to grab a quick bite.  The ready made entries at the steam table were particularly appetizing and there's a wonderful fruit market to boot.  There are things missing that one would find in a western market (couldn't find any melon; usually Asian markets seem overflowing with them).  Coffee selection was a little odd, too.  But it's a step up from fast food and sure to satisfy.

title: Don't go!
reviews: We thought that visiting Chinatown was going to be a great cultural experience , the truth is that place is very weird , it's quiet , intimidating , and near the night you'd start seeing drunk people and strange stuff , if you want to see the chinese garden , go early in the morning , becuse it's already closed by night.

title: Interesting but once is enough
reviews: If you plan to stay in Vancouver for a few days - maybe you should give Chinatown a short visit. It's very interesting (especially if you do not have a Chinatown in your area). Many food and spice shops - we were not that used to the smell. Very crowded. We finally found a place to park on one of the less busy streets (we couldn't find a parking place without parking meters. There is a car park if you prefer).We never revisited during our 10 day stay.

title: Devolution but still good
reviews: Vancouver’s Chinatown is the second largest in North America, after San Francisco’s iconic neighborhood comprised by those with Chinese ancestry. I had the good fortune to visit Vancouver 18 years ago, in 1997. The phenomenal growth throughout the rest of downtown in almost two decades astounded me. Skyscrapers next to English Bay remind me of Hong Kong. Visiting Chinatown was an easy walk from the Granville Street hotel. But that growth seems to have caused a demographic shift. Chinatown property owners resisted skyscraper development choosing instead to keep things the way they have been for decades: small buildings adjacent to sidewalks that border streets. Lack of development may have attracted the homeless and drug addicted population, though I saw that sad aspect only on side streets.  I advise enjoying Chinatown sights only on Main Street. Use the same sensibilities you would in any large city’s borderline community. NEVER wear gobs of jewelry and flash cash when traveling. Do you really need to impress anyone with a dozen credit cards or Rolex watch? A safety suggestion for any large city: If you feel threatened, walk into the street while checking for traffic. I did this on New York’s Park Avenue one evening.Our 39-member tour group of mostly elderly people (meaning we felt safe and were not bothered) had several stops in Chinatown during our 3-day stay in Vancouver, Chinatown’s Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden included. That Zen-like garden and the history we learned about how Chinese immigrants were instrumental to the development of the West Coast of Canada and America made me realize the mega cities lining the Pacific Ocean would not have occurred otherwise. Our tour included lunch at Jade Dynasty restaurant. I highly recommend the Dim Sum at Jade Dynasty. It was in Chinatown 18 years ago that I came across an idea: Use porcelain chopstick rests to place knives at a more formal dinner. I give a set of these to hosts when invited to dinner. Each host has appreciated the idea, and the tablecloth isn’t stained.

title: Nothing special...
reviews: Chinatown Vancouver is nothing special and we did not stay here for very long.  I have been told that the area can be rather seedy at night and there are some very poor areas adjacent.  I do not think we would have missed anything had we not seen Chinatown and I would not rush back.

title: Do not go!
reviews: We walked along the sea wall , passed the cruise ship area , and through Gastown to get there.  If we knew what awaited us , we would not have visited.We passed drug addicts with needles beside them , down and outs , and the dreadful Hastings Road.  Do not visit this awful place.  Full of people selling items which were strange to put it mildly.  The Police (thank goodness) were evident in this area.We eventually found the centre of China Town and walked round , realised it wasn't for us and tried to get a taxi.  No luck-- not one taxi would stop.  Luckily we managed to get a taxi in Main Street outside the law courts , as it dropped some one off.DO NOT take children to this area.  I really mean it.  The language from the locals was awful.We have been round the world 3 times and visited many "China Towns" our advice is give this one a miss!

title: Classical Chinese garden
reviews: Situated In the heart of Vancouver's Chinatown you will find the Classical Chinese Gardens.  Apart from this I personally wouldn't visit Chinatown. So many beggars and rough looking people. Was glad to get back to the City as I didn't feel very safe there.

title: I love Chinatown!
reviews: I love Chinatown and when we come to the city once a year on our shopping trip I always spend one full day there. The shops are full of wonderful things and are not expensive. My favorite shop is the one with the singing merchant. He is located on Keiffer upstairs in a large building. He makes me happy to hear him sing while I shop!My favorite bakery is across the street from him and I love walking around checking out all the different things there. plenty of wonderful places to eat at , lots of historic buildings to see.

title: A place not to go
reviews: I was first commented by a taxi driver, when passing through this area, that there are drug sellers on the street. and not recommend to go there in the night. Although there are a lot of Chinese restaurants. And then, when my family would like to passing a cross light, walk in the area, a local residence gave us alert again. He asked us if we are tourism, yes, we are. He strongly recommends not crossing and going into the area, as there are dangers ahead. we are scared.

title: Not as bad as everyone says it is.
reviews: We went down to check it out, with great uneasiness about just how "bad" the neighbourhood would be.  I wouldn't take kids, but it is definitely safe enough for adults to walk around.  Interesting to see some younger hipster type businesses moving in and revitalizing the neighbourhood.  The garden is an awesome place to check out.  And the international mall is super cool, it has some stores great for browsing.  One store is like an upscale dollar store, with EVERYTHING imported from Japan.

title: A nice part of Vancouver
reviews: We rented a bike and it was very nice to ride on the bike in Chinatown. It's not very big but it's a nice experience.

title: Some Nice Mice, Too Many Rats
reviews: My review title is not about real mice nor rats (nor any reference to Chinese reverence for Rats as in "the year of the rat").  Rather I speak of the famous "mice" as in Michner's Alaska....the old Athabasca grandmother's advice to her grandson to not miss nor forget the mice...so important to see and notice the great little things in places such as Chinatown Vancouver.  Take your camera...detail photos abound.  Regarding the rats, lots of down-n-out places and locals here too.  This part of town could be wonderful like in San Francisco IF the Vancouver city fathers blitz it like they have the great nearby Gastown area.  Hint, hint Vancouver and local Chinese leaders.

title: The gates are the prettiest gate I have ever seen in the US....
reviews: Chinatown is very unique here. With all the Chinese coming in drives to work the railroads there are many communities.....the garden here is the first one built out of China, everything, every tool by hand.

title: Do not recommend if you don't know the area
reviews: We thought we might find a place to eat in ChinaTown, but instead we encountered a detour because they were working on the streets, and the detour that we took ended up near a huge homeless Mission with hundreds of people standing outside and a homeless person trying to give us directions for money.  We did not feel comfortable at all, and I do not recommend this area for people who are unfamiliar with it.

title: Small and Dirty
reviews: I have lived in Vancouver all my live and have ventured into the "china town" area a lot. The only attraction for me ( being non-asian) would be the Sun Yat Sen gardens. I find the people on the street to be extremely rude, they will walk right into you without saying sorry, they spit on the streets, and tend to be very bias if you aren't Asian. This isn't a onetime thing, and an every time thing. Unless you have a specific reason for going there, like you wanted some kind of ethnic food or something special from a store, it's not worth the time or effort.

title: Under construction - Stay away form this place
reviews: Due to construction work in the street the place was empty. We were unable to take photos in the streets.The only quiet place was the Chinese Classical Garden. However when we wanted to use their restrooms they sent us to another location in Gastown

title: Great Asian markets & restaurants!!
reviews: A must-see in Vancouver!  Lots of markets with all kinds of foods and goods. Plenty of shopping for the tourists! The people were very friendly.  Make sure you check out the gardens!

title: Whats happening here?
reviews: We wanted to visit a Chinatown to see how it is after so many years.We were disappointed cos it seems small. There were not many restaurants and we could only eat at one small restaurant. The tim sum was not up to our standards.There were also many homeless people around. There was a guy who seems to be on drugs as he took off his top and walk unstable on the street.Not the Chinatown I would like to see in Vancouver.We are still wondering what is happening to this place.It seems like a dead town to us when we compared to busier Chinnatown we had visited.We walked into a Sun Yat Sun Garden.  Very quiet too.There are some produce stores and a few shops selling souvenir and that is it.Not much happening here. Disappointed.

title: Not worth a visit
reviews: We walked from Gastown to Chinatown for some Chinese food. What we found was a dirty part of Vancouver with trash on the sidewalks. Every where we walked we found homeless people in groups and begging for money. We promptly headed back to Gastown. I would not trust going to Chinatown at night.

title: Avoid
reviews: This is not a nice place and I did not feel safe walking around here even during the day.  It is a world away from the money and wealth of down town Vancouver.  I could not believe the amount of beggers and homeless people in this area, its the other side of North America you see on the news regarding the level of homelessness but it was a shock to see it in such a vibrant city.This is not a Chinatown Vancouver can be proud off!My advice is to stay away!

title: Not worth visiting
reviews: The Chinatown in downtown Vancouver is not worth visiting. Small, run-down and not much to see.  There are some restaurants, stores selling knick knacks and stores selling dried herbs and food. There's nothing in the way of fresh produce from what I could see. There are also some unsavory blocks right near Chinatown so be forewarned as you walk around. When I was previously in Vancouver, the hotel concierge told me how to get to Gastown easily from Chinatown. Unfortunately, this time it was an unexpected visit and we walked through a couple of sketchy blocks.

title: Not sure why it is called China Town.
reviews: Got off the skytrain at ChinaTown station thinking we would experience Chinese culture. What we saw were the homeless. Not ma y restaurants..

title: Very run down and felt unsafe
reviews: Despite our guide book listing this as an exotic part of town to visit we were very disappointed. There are a lot of homeless people and we saw people dealing drugs so it felt unsafe. Even the Chineses businesses still there were mainly herbalists or tacky gift shops so I wouldn't bother visiting this area.

title: Large and bustling Chinatown
reviews: A large Chinatown but less of a tourist destination and more of a real working and busy Chinatown neighborhood.  Plenty of good restaurants, the Sun Yat-sen gardens, and the train station are all located in this area close to Vancouver's East side.  Not as clean or as picturesque as the West End or Yaletown, go hungry to Chinatown and grab a meal.

title: I do not recommend downtown Chinatown in Vancouver
reviews: I was very disappointed with Vancouver's Chinatown.  The concierge did recommend to visit.  The area is so worn down and you and your friends do not feel safe there.  There are some rough parts if you go down too far.  We went to the bakery store and the service was not good and sometimes rude.  Anyways, the newer Asian community near the airport (Richmond) was 100% better.I did provide my feedback to the hotel concierge of not to recommend downtown Chinatown as a tourist attraction. It does not come close to NYC or San Francisco Chinatown.  Just some honest feedback.

title: Jump for Joy Photo Mural in New Location
reviews: The Jump for joy Photo Mural has been removed from its Chinatown location aka The Wall of Joy is now located on the West wall of The Arco Hotel at 81 West Pender Street (facing Abbott St) AND it's double the size of the original!

title: love Vancouver
reviews: I love everything about Vancouver.  There is always something to do and see here.  The weather is great and people are friendly.

title: AVOID
reviews: Intimidating place, people injecting drugs in door ways, did not feel safe, not recommended! Do not visit alone or at all!

title: Where are the Chinese people in Chinatown?
reviews: Made the mistake of going there one late afternoon - hardly any place was open, and the food choices were limited.Full of creepy people and the streets smelled of urine everywhere, we really did not stay too long. One of the saddest Chinatowns I have been to. Not recommended at anytime of the day.

title: Bit scary and unnerving
reviews: I went to China town with a couple of friends whilst exploring Vancouver. We left Gastown which was great but a complete contrast to Chinatown. It was dirty, intimidating and a bit distressing; we actually saw a woman injecting drugs in an alley. It's a great place to demonstrate why your kids should stay in school but that's the best we could say. #zombieappocolypse

title: Unsavory, little to see, unsafe
reviews: We'd anticipated that a stroll around Chinatown followed by a nice dinner would be a lovely way to spend our last evening in Vancouver. Armed with the Chinatown tourism brochure, we eagerly set off around 7.30pm on Friday evening with our 10 year old daughter in tow. I'm pointing out the day and time to be quite clear that in Chinatown anywhere else in the world, you'd expect a bustling, vibrant atmosphere full of dining options. Vancouver Chinatown was almost deserted, and scary, and weird. We were followed for a few blocks by someone clearly mentally ill, approached by pan handlers and saw very few people apart from those. I'm well traveled and rarely feel unsafe and uneasy - here I did. We found a Chinese restaurant with a couple of tables occupied and ate there, served by cheerless staff. Food was fine. We then left Chinatown as quickly as we could. The comment from our daughter? 'I'm glad we left that creepy place'. This is not a location for families or for tourists. Perhaps it's different in daytime but I would steer clear.

title: Like Most of Old Vancouver, Authenticity has Largely Vanished
reviews: Once upon a time Yen Lock's restaurant was the most authentic eatery in Vancouver's Chinatown. Here you ate at a round table with others, only chop sticks and basic food. Today, aside from barbecued ducks hanging in shop windows, the restaurants have become trendy and expensive. Chinatown to-day is clean--gone are the rooming houses and back room gaming houses (they've all probably moved to Surrey).  But it is still fun to wander and tourists still love to take selfies but there is a tepidness to the area that belies a once intriguing and thriving Chinese community.

title: Ok China Town.
reviews: It is not a great china Town. There are some nice sights. The gateway on Pender is neat. There are some quaint streets.

title: Poor chinatown in food option
reviews: Good neighbor but poor on food. Was there on subday on open fairy but just activities and no food. At least ate a wonderful Guioza at a restaurant in food square, cheap and great

title: Do not go
reviews: If I could give no stars I would!/we walked from west pender to east pender. What a world of difference! This China town is an utter disgrace - dirty, smelly, full of tramps druggies and weird people.  We walked with our 6 and 8 and if I had know how bad it was I would stay on the w pender side!! Was looking for food and found only one that didn't remotely felt unsafe. Went to the Chinatown plaza and omg.  The air was stale and felt like a scene off resident evil where something was coming off a corner!!!Our cabbie later told us Richmond is indeed the place to go if one wants abiy of Chinatown. Wished I read the reviews!!

title: Vancouver ChinaTown
reviews: Had been looking forward to visiting Vancouver's Chinatown and I wasn't disappointed.We visited on our own without a tour guide. Store owners and individuals that we met while there were all very friendly and made our visit fun and interesting. Definitely bring along a camera and comfortable shoes.

title: The best Chinatown in North America!
reviews: Chinatown here in Vancouver is simply the best! On my opinion the best Chinatown in the entire North America. So lovely!

title: Dirty and kinda scary with younger kids
reviews: This is a very huge china town but it's very dirty and fairly scary watch what's going on around you or you could be another statistic. lots of homeless and beggars on the street I went here expecting a big outdoor market like every other china town around the world I have been to their was nothing. Lots of shops and restaurants. We are at one place and it was very good the jasmine restaurant had dim sum 5stars other than that not worth your time

title: Chinatown in Vancouver.
reviews: Super interesting tour of Dr. Sun-yat Sen's home and gardens.  We were there in time to see the gathering and feeding of the koi.  Our guide did an excellent job of explaining the Chinese culture and symbols.  Highly recommend.

title: Not too impressed
reviews: Vancouver's Chinatown is very large with tons of markets to visit.  However, the markets all seem to sell the same thing - the usual produce, groceries, oriental goods - but nothing really extraordinary.  There were many restaurants but none that compelled me to walk through their doors. I got the impression that this Chinatown was not the foodies mecca that I expected - nothing like NYC or San Francisco which is packed with interesting places leaving you wondering how you'll be able to try something from each and every store/café.I'd skip this place and spend more time in Gastown - or better yet, head to Granville Island and the Granville Public Market for a true foodie's paradise

title: OK
reviews: Didn't really stop to have a decent look around but the whole area seemed pretty dirty and not very lively like most China towns, however I could be wrong and have just visited on a quiet day etc.

title: Not worth it. Terrible place. Scary !!
reviews: Only drugs all around, a very dirty place. I highly recommend to avoid this degradeted place. I still am thinking how can Vancouver Tourism Center keep recommending it.

title: A piece of history, intact
reviews: Vancouver's Chinatown has a long history, as well as its neighboring Japantown. Chinatown is accessible by bus. If you drive you may want to park in a parkade on its border (near Gastown). Many venues are generational long timers. You will find everything from apothecaries to butcher shops, duck bbqs, produce, rice merchants, chinaware, and more. So much to explore! Also lot's of great hole in the wall restaurants and cafes. Are you a tourist? This is definitely a great half day visit. Be careful of Main and Hastings...a bit dicey for safety.

title: Horrendous
reviews: Not really sure how this place is an attraction, nothing unique or special about the area only people selling and taking drugs on the street. If you want to go I would recommend using google street view as it would save you a lot of time and effort.

title: scary. would not recommend
reviews: I like it because they have some pretty good authentic restaurants there, and they all taste really good. However, it is a scary place! Derelicts congregate there, the streets are dirty, stores are also a bit dirty, and there are a lot of people there in rush hour. Don't go there in the dark as well, as  the buildings will block off all available sunlight, and it gets a bit scary there. Most stores there are Chinese medicine stores, with some Chinese souvenir stores. There are some great attractions (BC place, Science World) bordering the outside of Chinatown; I would recommend going there instead.

title: Chinatown
reviews: Chinatown is located close to East Hasting one of the largest homeless place area. However, if you don't mind this and would like to explore foreign restaurant and find great deals product, that's where you should go. I love to go there but not too late at night by yourself.

title: SAve your vacation travel time - skip Chinatwon
reviews: FRankly, what a disappointment.  The shops were not unique.  The place was shabby.  There were very few people walking around on a Sunday afternoon.  I thought with the large Chinese population there would be a nice variety of things to do and eat.  Not so .

title: Authentic and old
reviews: If you appreciate "real" Chinese food, and you are not afraid of dark streets in a very old part of the city, you will enjoy Vancouver's Chinatown.  We found it dark and dirty, with quite a few shuttered businesses and abutting the very rough "skid row" section of town. This is not Disney - it is real Chinese.  Several in our party were looking for popular "American style" Chinese food.  Not there. You won't find kiddie menus either.  This Chinatown is not an "attraction."  It is a historic part of a gritty downtown. If you want real Chinese food and don't mind getting your shoes dirty, don't miss it.  Otherwise...

title: No interesting! only fear...
reviews: we always like to visit China town in almost big cities when we travel to. China town in Vancouver was really a bad experience, there are not many tourist but alot of strange types of people running on streets, it is dirty around and it gives a bad feelings when we are on the way. Totally different as soon you walking to Gastown or down town Vancouver. I will recommend my friends or any one who are fan of Asian, if nothing to do there, should stay away this china town. It is nothing fun there!

title: Chinatown
reviews: Walked around Vancouver Chinatown. A number of new buildings and shops are popping up. Old buildings are still around. Tourist attraction.

title: Not a good place to take children
reviews: We had good memories of visiting Chinatown in Vancouver from about 20 years ago as children so decided to take the kids there when we were back in Vancouver in July.  It was nothing like we remembered it.  Everything was so run down and we had to step around needles on the ground in numerous places.  We were there just after lunch but there was not much to look at.  There were restaurants and a few stores but most of the stores were just food stores.

title: Historic Chinatown Tours with Judy Maxwell
reviews: There is a very interesting side of Vancouver's Chinatown that travellers and even its local citizens know little of.  If Dim Sum and a very fascinating historical tour of Vancouver's Chinatown is your cup of Chinese tea, then Judy Maxwell is your Go-to-Gal to contact. She will take you on a very informative two hours' day tour. Comfortable walking shoes and appropriate weather-wise clothing is recommended.

title: Nothing really special unless you are looking for Chinese restaurants in Vancouver
reviews: I went to Chinatown on my 2nd day visit in Vancouver after visiting the Gastown.  Chinatown and Gastown are next to each other.  Nothing really special unless you are looking for Chinese restaurants in Vancouver.

title: Go to Richmond!
reviews: I'm a local. If you want the "Chinatown" experience, ride the Skytrain into Richmond. Near the Aberdeen, Lansdowne, and Richmond-Brighouse stations is where you'll find the largest quantity of Chinese restaurants in Metro Vancouver. It's also where you'll find the best restaurants.There are also a couple interesting Asian malls worth checking out, such as Parker Place and Aberdeen. If you visit in the summer, I recommend going to the night market near Bridgeport station, which is also in Richmond.

title: It's ok, does not compare to San Fransico's.
reviews: For being one of the largest Chinatown's, this one is a bit of a disappointment.  The garden is good.  The shopping is ok.  It's dirty and at times stinky.  This section of town is better if you go earlier in the day.  The shops close early and it's not the safest part of town to visit in the evening.

title: the second chinnes town in amerca , after Sanfrancisco, many chinnes people you can feel in chinee, also at UBC
reviews: you can feel in chinee,  but  you can speak  english and comunicate, is  wonderfull  ,  and  learn about  they tradition

title: I Have Seen Better
reviews: We arrived late in the day and many shops were closed.  It is a rather depressed area as it was when I visited 15 years ago but there was very little activity and very few stores were even inhabited.  It is worth a trip to stop by if you have time to see it but no need to spend much time.

title: China town is worth avisit whether you eat there or just sight see
reviews: I love every single part ov Vancouver . It is a city I could live in !Also China Town is worth a visit. Really worth a visit.

title: Chinatown in Vancouver
reviews: It is a big area but we went too late in the day. We went around 6 and most shops were closed. It was fun to drive around the streets and see the shops from the car. They looked rather old and run down. I am not sure it would be that safe to walk around there. I heard the Richmond Chinatown was better.

title: Poor and smelly
reviews: Not much to see and do here. It is near a very very dodgy area of Vancouver (East Hastings) so you will see quite a few "characters" around here. Keep belongings close at hand.

title: Not so good.
reviews: I like to visit China towns all over the world, and this one is not very good. It's touted as being very large, but size is not everything!There's a few shops close-ish to the Sun Yat garden, but not a must see in my guide book.

title: Seedy, crowded but authentic
reviews: It's surprising how small this Chinatown is, given the depth of Vancouver's roots - roughly 7 blocks by 3.  Lots of tea shops, small restaurants, etc.  But almost everything is pretty dilapidated.  Pavements are very narrow so groups should split up or spread out; it seems pretty safe, despite the throngs of homeless people during nice weather..

title: A great garden in a not so great place...
reviews: The park and the garden is a great place to visit, beautyful and peaceful! However, the rest of the Chinatown seems to be a bit dangerous. There were used needles and blood at the street. I wouldn't visit it on my own or late at night.

title: Avoid it. There is nothing here and it is pretty sketchy
reviews: Having been to the Chinatowns in Toronto, San Francisco and New York, I can quite confidently say you do not need to visit this Chinatown. It's a rundown area of the city which is surprising considering how expensive real estate is. As a tourist, you do not have any reason to go here when there are so many other (Safer) places to be.

title: not a good part of the city
reviews: we walked through gas town which was great and very touristy but as soon as we entered china town it turn very seedy with lots of homeless

title: Not....San Francisco China Town....
reviews: Sorry, but will have to say I was disappointed with Vancouver's China Town District.Seemed dated and needs to be cleaned up a bit.  Ride the bike a lot in the area, and was not impressed.

title: Typical chinese area
reviews: Nice area to walk around and a number of good chinese reataurants and dim sim places to choose from and others with a wide variety of Asian goods.

title: Chinese area
reviews: great place for authentic Chinese food and GREAT VEGGIES in their Chinese markets...fresh and nice place to go shopping I love this part of Vancouver BC...very close to Gas Town....only a few blocks away

title: Run down Chinatown
reviews: After an enchanting visit to Capilano Suspension Bridge, my daughters and I walked to Chinatown from Canada Place.  At first, we saw charming shops that reminded us of our hometown Austin, Texas until we reached the rundown and dirty Chinatown.  We    wanted to get away and started walking towards Gastown and ran into streets filled with homeless people.  Until then, we were under the impression that Vancouver was some kind of an utopian place.  What a rude awakening!  It made us so sad.   If you are visiting for a vacation, stay away from Chinatown and the Gastown area.

title: Stay away
reviews: No cool little shops or authentic Asian food. A very derilect part of vancouver that has very little going on. Saw used needles all over the place and a lot of homelessness.  Avoid this place, especially if you're used to Chinatowns like they have in Oakland and SF where I'm from

title: It smells like....Hong Kong
reviews: Coming out of the city you enter Chinatown through an arch. Going deeper into Chinatown and you'll smell the flavours of all kind of spices...it brought me back to Hong Kong. Maybe it was not only the smell, but also the Chinese writing..

title: THIS AREA IS A DISGRACE!!!!!
reviews: Described in various tourists brochures as "Canada's Largest Chinatown" I can only say I hope the smaller ones are 200% nicer.We are Chinese food lovers and were astounded to be dropped in the centre of "Chinatown" by our cabbie on our first night in Vancouver.We wandered around for 45 minutes trying to find  decent restaurant, eventually settling on the Yuppy establishment of Bao Bei (see separate review)which is as Chinese as my Canadian Grandmother.We were confronted by numerous street people demanding money and as sorry as we feel for these poor souls, wish they weren't allowed to roam around presenting a type of menace to tourists and locals alike.Taking a cab back to our Hotel the driver remarked as to why we were out in that area at night.Someone recommended Floata for Dim Sum (see review), so we went a few days later which was quite OK - all dishes good. But were again surrounded by poor street people who seemed to have set up their very own market along some of the streets.Too late really for us to go a few times, but a helpful TA writer - Robyn - kindly advised us to go to Richmond where the "real" Chinatown is situated.Maybe the Tourism Authorities and the publishers of the glossies could lend a helping hand and not write up the old Chinatown as some sort of miracle rebirth and direct us lost food lovers to the bright lights of Richmond??Paul

title: Wish I'd read the reviews before going
reviews: I wish I'd read the reviews before visiting this part of Vancouver. Having been to Chinatown in many other cities, and having heard about how multicultural Vancouver is, I thought this Chinatown would be bustling with restaurants and shops and culture. How far from the truth. Although the gardens were nice, I would gladly have missed seeing them to avoid the walk there and back! The streets are dirty (unlike the main tourist areas of Vancouver which are very clean), I didn't feel safe at all (we ducked into a shop at one point as there was a man who seemed to be following us and as we had our rucksacks on our backs, we didn't feel safe having him behind us), and it was very run down. I'm annoyed that the tour guide we'd had for the main part of Vancouver on the previous day had recommended visiting the area - it was the only reason we'd gone there as we had some spare time one afternoon. I wish we hadn't :-( It's not a place for tourists and I would avoid it at all costs.

title: BEWARE
reviews: I am not a visitor, I have lived in Vancouver for nearly 15 years. This is a warning for tourists coming to our city. Vancouver's Chinatown is not your typical big-city Chinatown. Do not come here expecting nifty little shops and restaurants or interesting night life. This place is run-down, old, dirty and dangerous. If you were to come visit here, have a specific destination in mind. The gardens are beautiful, and there is some low-rise office buildings around here. But I would NOT recommend coming to Chinatown to just "walk around". If you are a tourist and are looking for this kind of old-town Vancouver experience, I recommend you stroll the streets of Gastown instead. If you are looking to see the rough side of the city, I suppose it is a study unto itself. But for your typical cruise-passenger or tourist, I would warn you to be wary of this neighbourhood before visiting.

title: Recommend the city tour
reviews: Took the city tour when in Vancouver waiting for a cruise ship.  Fun tour, good to see more of the city.

title: Little China in world's major cities
reviews: Yeah, there's Chinatown in almost every major cities. Even back home, we have Binondo as the oldest Chinatown in the world. So we make sure to drop by at Chinatown in the cities that we have visited (from Singapore to Kuala Lumpur) not much for the food but for other stuffs, e.g. souvenir items (well, if you're trading low quality for good value).

title: BE VERY CAREFUL
reviews: We walked from our hotel (not very far) with the intent to visit Dr Sun Yat Sen Park. BEWARE - this is not a nice area. Lots of homeless and men with lots of open sores due to AIDs and literally saw a young woman shooting up in one of the alleys. We were on the main street to the garden. I would not recommend going there unless you are with lots of people and it's daylight

title: Nostalgic
reviews: Like many downtown city Chinatowns across the states, the Chinese have moved out to the suburbs and all that is left is the unique architecture and herbal stores interspersed with the occasional Starbucks and drug stores.  The dragons atop the lampposts and the signage is nostalgic - but like everything else go during the day and avoid the Hastings Street homeless crew.  They are aggressive pan handlers who do not like tourists.  We took a short walk down memory lane and snapped a few pictures of the changed streets just to see the changes.

title: Not A Place To Be Proud Of
reviews: This is a tough place to visit with lots of homeless, druggies and hookers everywhere you look. Not very clean but the one bright spot is the Chinese Gardens which are an oasis among the desolation. So much more to see in this wonderful city but Chinatown is not one of them.

title: Chinatown Vancouver
reviews: Pretty trashy area.  Was hoping for a tradition china town was not up to expectations.  Tried to find a decent place to eat but not much of a selection.

title: The worst Chinatown I've been to
reviews: My husband who is Chinese Canadian wanted to visit Chinatown and have dinner there. We took the bus with my 2 year old. Nobody warned us how bad it was. On the bus as we got closer and closer I grew more anxious seeing the homeless druggies and prostitutes on the streets.It wasn't a couple here and there it was chaotic, like what I picture prison to be. I didn't want to get off the bus. I think the bus driver sensed my reaction as he told us where to get the bus to gas town. I really thank god for him.We agreed to go directly to the gardens then to gas town.The gardens themselves are pretty and scenic a nice respite from the surroundings.We were told we could walk to gas town but I didn't feel safe.I've lived in Asia for 6 years and I consider Vancouver Chinatown a disgrace. Compared to SF, Toronto even edmonton Chinatown it is the worst I've seen and so disappointing as we never even had dinner there.

title: Vancouver should be ashamed of them selves.
reviews: blocks and blocks of chinatown area are overtaken by folks living on the streets  (not a few but hundreds and hundreds ) making blocks not accessible.Police are there but the mass of humanity... many appear to have been ravaged by drugs is not a positive statement for the City Elders and government.THe worst aspect is the overflow of these masses of folks is spreading into other parts of the city.  Folks panhandling sleeping on the street and disrupting commerce does not bode well.  THe city needs to have a plan that extends beyond keeping folks in one part of town.  Everyone we spoke to   from cab drivers who say they will not go into nor take people to the area to other tourists (like ourselves) who stumbled on the area shared our perspective that the city was in a spiral that changed our perspective on what we all had an image of a wonderful city that is now on a path of future avoidance by visitors due to an apparent unwillingness to deal with a "problem" that will eventually have to be addressed.Please help these folks on the streets resolve what you can ...but save your city from what is clearly becoming very bad press for future tourists.

title: Disappointing visit to Chinatown
reviews: Maybe we just went at the wrong time of day (Friday arvo) but I was very let down to say the least. We walked a couple blocks around Chinatwon off Main St, found the gates at E Hasting but that's about it. Couldn't even find a decent bakery to buy a sesame ball. Glad we ate lunch on Robson St before visiting since everything seemed pretty much closed. Not much atmosphere.

title: Chinatown, Vancouver, British Columbia
reviews: My husband and I just returned from a trip to Vancouver and we rode to on off trolly. Chinatown was disgraceful and alarming how they let the filth, young strung out girls crawl around and still beg for money for drugs or prostitute themselves (at one's own risk of a disease!). What a pig stein. Never saw such sadness in a Chinatown in all I have visited. Wouldn't even think of eating there. Never got off the Trolly. Gas town is close to the cruise ship district so wasn't quite as bad. I'm appalled, the city doesn't reel in the crime, prostitution and drugs gone wild! So many high rise condo's they have lost the coastline and the over all beauty of what was once a beautiful controlled city. No plans of ever returning there.

title: Very Authentic non-touristy Chinatown
reviews: This Chinatown is no tourist trap an no shopping extravanza.  It is both modest and authentic. We toured the Dr. Sun Yat Set Classical Chinese Gardens. We did the free version (right beside the for fee door) which was lovely.  Then we went for lunch at the T&T grocery store which was fantastic and inexpensive, and then for acupuncture and massage (at 20 East Pender) right in front of the gardens.  The soft-spoken, gentle doctor of Chinese medicine is enough reason to go.  I had pulled a muscle in my thigh and I left feeling wonderful with no more pain.

title: Pretty ordinary
reviews: I've been to a few in different cities and have only ever found one to be clean and pleasant (Yokohama) and yet I keep going back. This is typical and was a little rundown and tired - lot's of litter in the streets.

title: First time visit impressive
reviews: We walked around Chinatown checking out the various shops, stopped for a great lunch, then toured the museum and temple gardens. Lots of character here. Worth a visit.

title: Not enough flavor here...
reviews: Amazing that Vancouver has the 3rd biggest Chinese community in North America and this Chinatown has no flavor. Wide streets, few interesting things to see.Between Chinatown and Gastown a lot of homeless people, very vocal with people walking, you do not feel safe in this area... Mainly at Hastings and Carrall...

title: A mini-vacation
reviews: I've been to a few Chinatowns around in North America and I like this one because it is actually used by the local Chinese, not like some places that are just tourist traps.  It has interesting stores, good restaurants and lots to look at.

title: Kind of a sad looking Chinatown
reviews: I am kind of surprised at Vancouver's Chinatown, especially given the Asian immigration to Vancouver - perhaps the center of Chinatown has moved to Richmond or elsewhere, but as where it is today, Vancouver's Chinatown is kind of "odd", in that while it has predominantly Chinese businesses , it seems to lack the typical vitality of "Chinatown" found in many places across the globe. I may have missed it but I didn't see lots of eateries or fresh food markets, which are 2 commonly found businesses in a typical overseas Chinese area. I passed by in the afternoon, and again early morning, on different days but the streets were not bustling - where has the people gone to, I wonder? Also this Chinatown is small-ish, consisting of only a few streets - and in a neighborhood, for one who is unfamiliar with this place, probably would not be comfortable venturing about, after dark. It is a couple of blocks south of E Hastings, a very different place from say, W Hastings near Canada Place!

title: Worst Chinatown in the world
reviews: I like Kent's Kitchen, some of the restaurants there and supermatkets, however, and this is crucial, the street is adjacent to East Hastings Avenue which is full of drug addicts. They literally spill over into Chinatown every so often making the lives of the Chinese residents and visitors a nightmare. I wish the city of Vancouver would sort this out as it's such a shame!

title: A real chinatown, not Disneyland
reviews: Sorry but the negative reviews of Vancouver's Chinatown really miss the point.  It's a real neighborhood where people really live, work and shop.  There are real Chinese groceries and restaurants, although as gentrification takes they're becoming less and less.  I LOVE Chinatown and would recommend any visitor to give it a chance -- go to New Town Bakery and get a steamed bun, visit the Sun Yat Sen Garden, buy some tea, just enjoy a truly authentic place before it becomes Chinatown in name only.  I take the bus/walk through the neighborhood all the time and love the energy, even just watching our Chinese seniors do their shopping.  If you want a sanitized Chinatown go elsewhere.  If you want to experience a true ethnic neighborhood with an amazing history, I urge you to go there with an open mind.  If you're interested in the history of Chinese Immigrants in Vancouver  (which is really fascinating) there are guided and self-guided tours.  I would also add a visit to our "Japantown" is also worthwhile.  Much of that community is gone but there are a number of historical buildings.  Self-guided tour maps can be found here http://www.vancouverheritagefoundation.org/take-a-tour/map-guides/

title: Average, when you eventually find it
reviews: Sorry to say but this is definitely the worst so called ChinaTown we have visited. When compared to NYC, SF, Sydney, London it is a poor shadow. Apparently, we were explained to by Vancouverites, all the good stuff has moved to the "burbs" like Richmond etc. We had looked forward to a good yum cha but found nothing interesting. Maybe there are only 2/3 streets worth looking at but that is it. Oh, & by the way, in no way choose E Hastings Street to return to the CBD as we did unless you want to witness the end of the world as we know it. DON'T ask questions, just avoid it, OK ?

title: A real, functional, Chinatown
reviews: People work and live here. It's not just a tourist attraction. Some of the stores are really high-end, and others are not; everything is a mom and pop store, and there are a lot of hardworking people here. You can find many treasures, from food to teas to home goods, and many at very good prices. Chinatown is an area in transition -- just north toward Gastown is an area where there are a lot of homeless people, but Chinatown itself is seeing a lot of development and growth yet still feels like it might have 30 and 40 years ago. It is becoming a blend of Chinese immigrants and new Vancouver development, which is charming and enticing. To get to the trendy Gastown on foot, especially if you're a lone woman, head west a few blocks first on Pender or Keefer, then turn north on Abbot, before you head north out of Chinatown. That way you avoid the edgier side of Hastings Street and can feel more comfortable. Chinatown is quiet on Sundays, so make sure to go other days of the week. And check out the Keefer Bar, the Chinese garden, and the wonderful tea shop on Main Street.

title: "It's Chinatown"
reviews: But don't forget it, Jake. This is not a "dangerous" neighbourhood, for heavens sake. I am nearly 60 years old and feel perfectly ok even in the sketchier spots on Hastings that seem to scare some. Yup, there are some homeless, some junkies, and a bunch of down and outers on Hastings. It's a densely populated area with lots of foot traffic.This is a neighbourhood in transition. Some of the older generation of Chinese still lives here, there are some Asian BBQ, vegetable, rice, trinket, etc. shops, too. But, what's happening? Unions Street has a lively, young bar scene. The Sun yat-Sen garden is lovely even on a rainy day. Some of the architecture is elegant, some historical. Lots of young shops and young people trying thei hands at business.The Phnom Penh restaurant is so good.I love Chinatown. It's evolving, bringing together different cultures, different businesses, and becoming, or again becoming, one of the liveliest neighbourhoods in the city.

title: Pretty big, but otherwise average
reviews: Given Vancouver's asian population, it's no surprise that it's Chinatown is fairly large. I'd agree with other posters that it can be a little sketchy but really, I never felt unsafe there, at least during the day. Vancouver in general seems to have a very visible homeless population but I never felt intimidated or in danger, maybe because I come from a city with a very visible homeless population too so maybe I'm used to it. The Chinatown here seemed like most other Chinatowns in major cities, nothing really special but if you want to check it out don't be afraid.

title: Chinatown
reviews: I didn't hate it as much as some of the reviewers here seem to. The area was a little rough but I am still glad I experienced it. It is the only Chinatown I have ever visited so I don't have anything to compare it to. However, I did pick up a few items and had a great meal.

title: Don't waste your time, very unsafe and disgusting area
reviews: Absolutely a disgusting area that has been completely taken over by street people, drug addicts and the like.You will not feel safe, there is nothing to see or do unless you like the smell of urine

title: A bit dodgey!
reviews: If you want bargain for souvenirs, this is a good place to shop. Other than that ... go somewhere else. There's a lot of homeless people begging for money here.

title: Bad area, nothing special.
reviews: Do not come here. Plain and simple. The area is really bad and honestly this Chinatown doesn't offer much. It's near gastown so defiantly go to gastown and avoid Chinatown

title: Heroin addicts everywhere.
reviews: Scary place to be during the day.  We saw strung out heroin users.  We went to check out the garden area and another drug user freaked out and accused us of trying to take his picture.

title: better do something else
reviews: There is really nothing to see there. There are only a few asian shops and restaurants most of them were closed .I didn't have the feeling of entering a new world and i had this feeling before in  other chinatowns. I would say if you're planning to go there i would decide to do something else :-) its not worth the time.

title: Not a great place to be
reviews: We walked through Chinatown a few times in the mornings and it's dire to say the least. Coming from Chinatown in London, I can't even compare. There is no hustle and bustle, it is not safe, it's not pretty and you shouldn't go there at night. My resounding memory of this place will be an elderly Chinese resident staring out of a dirty window, of a filthy, dirt encrusted shack that houses the elderly. Not a happy memory.

title: Very disappointing
reviews: I was much looking forward to visiting Vancouver's chinatown but overall, it was a very disappointing experience. It's terribly run down and quite dirty in parts. It attempts at tourist attractions are all poorly maintained or in a state of disrepair. I didn't see any decent looking restaurants which was a bit of a surprise. As one other reeviewer wrote, there wre quite a lot of dodgy looking people loitering in certain parts. Not at all recommended - don't waste your time.

title: Its all gone now
reviews: I remember growing up here.Chinatown was alive ,a lot of action,great resturants and dozens and dozens of stores to browse thru.Over the year the Chinese population has moved out to Richmond and though there is a large Chinese ppopulation there it is sprawled out.As for the actual Chinatown is only a fraction of what it once was.You still have the Sun Yat Sen Gardens and a few other things but dont expect to see a full blown Chinatown like SanFransisco

title: A Wok around Chinatown - fantastic experience!!
reviews: Bob Sung of "A Wok around Chinatown" took us on the most fun and interesting walking tour of Vancouver's Chinatown. He is a 4th generation Chinese and shared with us the rich history of this part of the city. We stopped in at really interesting stores and enjoyed a delicious dim sum lunch. Bob is knowledgeable, personable and has a great sense of humour. I learned a lot about the rich Chinese culture and highly recommend this tour if you want a really great experience!

title: Most unpleasant
reviews: Compared to Chinatown areas in other cities around the world this one in Vancouver is well below the standard. Lots of dodgy looking people loitering on the streets, run down buildings and a generally unsafe feeling. Quite a contrast from some of the neighbouring districts.

title: Should have been better prepared
reviews: We spend half an hour or so walking around Chinatown.  It was neat to see the different architecture and the diversity of the people walking around.  As we hadn't really planned ahead, we didn't really know where the best place to eat or shop might be.  I think it was fun to walk through, if your stay is long enough, but it would not be my priority.

title: Small Yet Interesting Chinatown
reviews: We were disappointed that Chinatown was so small but we still found it interesting to walk around.  Reminded me of some of the other Chinatowns I saw in Malaysia, Thailand and Hong Kong but obviously a lot smaller.  Chinatowns throughout the world have cleanliness in the western sense as a secondary concern. I just like the authentic Chinese feeling I get in these locations and the feeling of the differences in the Chinese culture from our western culture.  This is one of the reasons I love to travel.  It's to experience these differences.  This Chinatown has easy parking and easy walking. Interesting shops, restaurants, tea shops and small Chinese grocery stores to wonder through.  There are some good restaurants and food stalls and a small Chinese botanical garden.  The afternoon is a good time to visit. Parking in metered parking along the street and some small pay parking lots are available.

title: Quite dirty, and felt unsafe
reviews: Although one of the most advertised attractions in Vancouver, the area is not more picturesque than it is shaggy and dirty. Nothing special to visit: just a couple of shops easily found in any Chinatown. Plenty of beggars, and drunk people even in the early afternoon. One of the worst kept neighborhoods in the city

title: Not that Interesting
reviews: If you have never been to a "Chinatown" in a city, then this is probably worth a visit. On the other hand, if your have visited neighborhoods like this in other cities, you might want to give this one a pass. It has a small mall and lots of stores selling traditional Chinese items (herbal medicine, vegetables, fruit, etc) but it is not as dynamic as other cities. Apart from having the world's thinnest building (The Sam Kee building at 8 West Pender Street) and the Sunyat Sen Garden there is nothing remarkable about Vancouver's Chinatown. The neighborhood is isolated from the Gastown neighborhood by some pretty nasty streets that don't appear to be all that safe to walk through. There is a stop on the HoHo bus route if you really want to get off and look around. It really won't take more than 30 minutes to see the area unless you visit the Sunyat Sen Garden.

title: Very disappointing
reviews: My wife and I were very disappointed in Chinatown.  Being that there is such a large asian population here, we expected to have a thriving chinatown.  Instead it was very dumpy and have very few things open.

title: God awful neighbourhood!
reviews: Having visited calgary,Banff,whistler and now Vancouver we wanted to do something cheap and interesting so we chose this self guided tour of Chinatown. Do not go to this area in the dark!! Certainly don't take a lot of money or your children! The Main Street area was full of drug users, prostitutes and homeless nut cases. Stay well clear. Very disappointed

title: Not at all worth the effort
reviews: We had read some of the reviews on here prior to our trip to Vancouver, but had been recommended to visit it by a friend, despite warnings about the surrounding streets.We had expected the usual hustle and bustle of a touristy Chinatown, much like the one in London, but instead found very little evidence that we were in Chinatown, despite the faded flags proclaiming that we were! We had intended to find a cheap place to eat but there were very few restaurants at all, and most looked a bit dodgy. We did find the Chinese Garden - see other reviews for this but well worth a visit - but top tip: do NOT walk from here to Chinatown and then to Gas Town. Very, very dodgy streets filled with homeless/beggars/people of dubious intent. We felt very conspicuous and uncomfortable. In the end we just found the nice part of Gas Town and ate there.

title: Beware Chinatown Vancouver
reviews: I am a proud western Canadian who has been to Vancouver several times on business. This was the first time in many years that I actually was there on vacation and had the time to take in some sights with an American friend. I apparently need to be more in touch because Chinatown was a place I hadn't visited in 30 years. What a huge mistake!  Within a block of walking into Chinatown, I felt very unsafe and I am generally pretty trusting. The further I walked, the worse it got. My fault for not being more informed but SHAME on the bus and trolley companies for promoting Chinatown so much when 1 wrong turn can get you in trouble!!!! I made that wrong turn. What about all the elderly tourists that aren't aware!! DO NOT GO past the gate!!!

title: Interesting: visually, culturally, historically
reviews: We've visited Chinatown during two of our three visits to Vancouver in the past 17 years. The first time it was self-guided and it was interesting: visually, culturally, historically. The second time it was part of Erik's City & Lynn Canyon Tour (http://www.hihostels.ca/westerncanada/1933/hi-vancouver_central_erik%27s_tours.hostel) from Hostelling International's Vancouver Downtown hostel ... wow!

title: Love Chinatown in Vancouver
reviews: There's a tiny chinese bakery called New Town that makes filipino chinese pastries, to die for.  That's it.  Whenever I travel to Seattle, I make the 2+ hour drive to Canada, just for their buchi and apple tarts.  Secret's out.

title: Stay Away
reviews: One wrong turn could land you in what I describe the scariest street in Vancouver.  Drug addicts and homeless line the sidewalks on Main St.  There were many!  I was beyond scared while stopped at a stop light. Quickly drove thru Chinatown.  Very dirty.  Pease if any of you plan to visit, be extremely careful.  Do not visit this area anytime after dark.  Stay safe.

title: Jump for Joy! Photo Mural is worth the trip!
reviews: Chinatown’s vibrant neighbourhood is rich in culture and home to some of Vancouver’s top restaurants, cafes, bars and retail outlets. Vancouver’s Chinatown is universally appealing to tourists and locals alike through its abundance in fascinating history, striking heritage buildings and world-renowned delicacies.What caught my eye is the awe-inspiring photo mural located in the laneway of 161 East Pender. This vibrant, lively mural adds a splash of color into this derelict area and promotes a sense of community. Chinatown, and the world in general, needs more joy! This project goes above and beyond serving that purpose. Whilst exploring through the cultural neighbourhood of Chinatown, make a stop at the Jump for Joy! Photo Mural and you won't be disappointed!

title: Not Much
reviews: I guess I am generally less impressed with Chinatowns since visiting Hong Kong and China but...this area didn't seem to offer much other than size. It is quite a bit larger than most but it doesn't contain much interesting. Spend your time elsewhere in Vancouver.

title: Chinatown, vancouver, canada
reviews: The chinatown in vancouver is situated at east pender street. It has a mall with many shops and restaurants. There is the parade during chinese new year period. Enjoyable and memorable

title: Very Disappointing
reviews: Don't bother making a beeline to this place. Very uninspiring place to visit. Was expecting a Chinatown akin to San Francisco or even London. A few shops selling Chinese groceries is about the best you get plus lots of homeless folks. Not worth it.

title: Little Historical Interest In A Diverse Area of Vancouver.
reviews: Passing the First Nations building with the Frieze & totem pole above the roof I arrived at the Entrance Gates to Chinatown continuing up Pender Street to Main St. Chinatown has existed since 1885. There is a mix of architectural styles with very few of the original building remaining. Some streets have their names in both Chinese & English. At one section on the pavement I saw the Chinese Horoscope embedded.If you look carefully at the few remaining historical buildings such as the 1889 Wing Sang Heritage building, the original is blended well with the newer additions.Best Visit is to the Dr Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden.

title: Simply stay away!!
reviews: After a very pleasant afternoon visit to Granville Island we thought it might be nice to finish our day with a trip to Chinatown for a walk and dinner, as you might in many cities around the world, especially with such a large Chinese community. The taxi driver dropped us off at the main gates and the further we walked into Chinatown the scarier it got with shops shuttered and dodgy people everywhere. We tried to find a bus out but in the end we managed to flag down a sympathetic taxi driver who helped us escape a very unpleasant experience. Maybe its ok during the day but definitely stay away in the late afternoon or evening.

title: Too Early?
reviews: I was not dazzled by Chinatown, but I may have been there a little too early in the day.  It may liven up closer to the evening time...?

title: My goodness... bad neighborhood!
reviews: We visited the Chinatown without prior knowledge that it's right next to the notorious Vancouver east side that's considered one of the bad neighborhoods. We started noticing some homeless people but pretty soon the whole area is full of them. One was even harassing a couple of guys waiting for the bus and they eventually called the cops, which arrived minutes later. We didn't feel it's a dangerous place to be, just unpleasant to see the whole area being so run down and full of homeless people loitering, can't be helpful to the tourism. For this reason, public restrooms at McDonald's or Tim, etc. are all locked with cctv guarding the doors!

title: A lot of history...
reviews: Chinatown has a lot of little shops and stops that are very worth seeing.  The tea shop on the corner of Pender & Columbia is a perfect throw back to old Chinese way of sipping and tasting different teas.  These folks are experts in tea tasting.  A little up the street you'll find the Old Time Bakery, they are known for their Apple Dumpling Pies; the recipe is 5 generations old and was sold to them by a tea shop that has since closed it's doors after being in Chinatown for over 6 generations!  A little further up Pender in the alley just before Main Street you will find the most amazing mural of Jumping and Joy.  This impress wall is over 9000 sqft and a new addition to Chinatown.  Don't let the activities of the alley put you off, it's worth seeing the whole wall!  Cross over Main Street to the East and you'll find a variety of grocery shops and herbal shops.  Stop into any of the herbal shops and tell them what ails you....they will have a herbal remedy!  Cross over to East Georgia where you will find a great new spot for a great coffee at Matchstick Coffee Brewers then if you like cross the street and have a brew at the old English Pub...funny location but great pub and nice natchos!

title: sordid area, lots of homeless people
reviews: Compared to other Chinatowns in other US cities this is the most sordid quarter I have ever been. Although I was visiting at 3pm many shops were closed. The whole area around Keefer/Pender/Main St. was dirty, ugly and run-down. Chinatown is adjacent to Downtown Eastside which is the area in Vancouver you definitely should not visit. Hence you will meet a very high amount of homeless and junkies strolling around in Chinatown. Not worth a visit.

title: Dour and Seedy
reviews: We are used to the brightness and liveliness of London's Chinatown.Vancouvers Chinatown was very different. Although there was an inexpensive museum on the history of Vancouvers Chinese population, the area was very run down and definitely not a place to stay around too long. The Sun Yat Sen gardens are beautiful - but try not too look too closely beyond the bushes as you may find needles and drug abusers.If you want Chinese markets - I'd recommend Richmond, and recommend avoiding this part of town.

title: Should be struck off as a tourist 'attraction'
reviews: We walked through China town via the public park that borders the Dr Sun Yat- Sen Chinese garden.  The park was nice, but nothing outstanding, but given the TA reviews of the Sun garden we opted for the free version! We them entered China town and were totally underwhelmed.  Druggies, drunks, vagrants on almost every corner.  Virtually nothing to see part from very run down shops and eateries.  A VERY uncomfortable 10 mins trying to find something to appreciate about the area.  Having not enjoyed the experience, we moved on to Gastown.  We would not recommend anyone to visit China town unless your are on a tour bus, and even then it would not be worth the fare!  Come on Vancouver, you need to clean this area up and work with the local Chinese residents to make something worthy of the city and the Chinese legacy. Our worst experience in any of our many sight seeing 'tours' on our extensive travels.

title: The Chinese garden is nice but not worth $14.00/p.p.
reviews: Nice garden, took about 1/2 hour with the tour. Big fish pond... planned nicely, but really $14 a person? I expected more.

title: Chinatown is dead!
reviews: All the negative feedbacks about Vancouver Chinatown are pretty accurate. Chinatown has lost its charm in last couple decades. Most of the shops are closed. The atmosphere is sad and pathetic to say the least. The only saving grace is perhaps the Dr Sun Yet-sen Classical Chinese Garden which was built for the EXPO 86, still the homeless and drug addicts would sneak in and take advantage of the bamboo shade and serenity to do their business. There isn't a decent Chinese restaurant other than cheap eat like Hon's Won Ton House and Kent Kitchen that you pick food items and pair up with rice, noddle etc. Avoid corner of Hastings and Main. Don't be fooled by its name as Carnegie Centre is where the local homeless, drug addicts, thieves, thugs etc gather outside. NEVER use the public washroom outside the Centre because it is a smelly hell hole. Drug addicts pass out on wet and dirty floor. 100 block East Hastings is the ugliest street in Vancouver. Despite real estate developers are trying to build apartments blocks in Chinatown this is not going to save the situation. NEVER park your car along 000-300 East Hastings even in broad daylight. Sorry there isn't anything good, safe, attractive about Chinatown in the eye of a Chinese like myself. I only go there to buy Apple Tarts at New Town Bakery (148 East Pender Street).

title: We felt like we had stepped into the streets of China!
reviews: We gazed, we relaxed in the garden, we made friends, we dined and spent a great day learning and shopping and filling up! This is a great place to visit!

title: Waste of time
reviews: Found this Chinatown a little scary with numerous homeless and less desirable people. Don't think I would waste time visiting here. We did manage to find one place where we had lunch which was reasonable.

title: Avoid this "attraction" if you can
reviews: As a local, I would say that the only places worth a visit are the Chinese bakeries. They sell cheap and delicious pastries, buns and other snacks. The souvenir shops and clothing stores sell low quality things from China and they always have those "on sale" signs out. You can get better deals at the dollar store (on Main St and Pender) if you want to grab some postcards or magnets. As for the big mall "International Village", you can use the washrooms here and go to Yokoyaya, the Japanese dollar store. There's a theatre upstairs which is cheaper than other big theatres. Other than that, the shopping scene is pretty sad. There's air conditioning in the mall though! The Asian supermarket T&T, next to International Village, sells Asian snacks, drinks, hot food and groceries.

title: Not Very Nice
reviews: Vancouver's Chinatown is pretty much a disappointment.  It is unfortunate that it borders East Hastings Street, which is overrun with people who have some real nasty issues.  But fortunately, there is not that much spillover of those folks into Chinatown.  However, Chinatown still does not have that much to offer.  There are a handful of restaurants that look like they might be fun to try, but I have not sampled any of them.  On the plus side, I walk to Chinatown about once a week so that I can pick up some barbecued pork buns from one of the bakeries there.  On the weekend, there is a fair amount of activity, but most everything is locked up by 7 pm on weekday evenings. One unique feature is that there are more stores that sell dried whatever (fish, fungus, nuts, vegetables, mushrooms, anything you can imagine) than any other Chinatown that I have been in.  I walked around one block, that means 4 blocks of walking, and counted 10 stores filled with all kinds of dried stuff that all looked pretty much the same to me.  For the life of me, I can't figure out why there is a need for all those stores. Other than what I have mentioned, there are a few run down tourist junk shops and a few Chinese food shops.  It is not a very nice area.

title: So scary we didn't get out of the car
reviews: After breezing through Victoria's Chinatown, we thought perhaps we'd explore and even eat in Vancouvers. NOPE.  Run down, dirty, and fairly unapproachable, most of the businesses seemed poorly maintained and nothing welcomed us in.  Maybe we'll do San Francisco.

title: Great Cantonese Food
