reviews: Yes, its a typical Chinatown, if you want good Roast Duck and Pork, you will not go wrong. So glad the people speak Cantonese, it felt homely

title: Typical Chinatown
reviews: Vancouver has a large Chinatown and a very large Asia population. Chinatown in some areas especially off east Hastings is dirty  and occupied by homeless people. Go during the daytime and walk through the shops and there are some fine Chinese restaurants.  There are amazing Chinese restaurants throughout Vancouver and you don't have to go to Chinatown. The walk between gas town and Chinatown has a few homeless shelters so be away.  Richmond is the new Chinatown and has modern shops and amazing restaurants

title: Dragon dancing and freebies on Canada Day
reviews: I had a visit to this Chinatown on Canada Day and there was abit of festivities happening such as the traditional dragon dancing and people giving out free canadian souvenirs (little flags, temporary tattoos, stickers) and as a tourist I thought that was a very idea lol. My uncle took me around to see the beautiful garden which was full of people taking photos so it was hard to get our own (i have forgotten the name but had a big lily pond with big goldfishes), we also had some yummy chinese buns at one of the bakeries and went vegetable shopping. I didn't see any homeless people at all.

title: Avoid - scary, no character, just awful
reviews: We had driven through China town on the bus during the day and whilst it looked quiet then, we thought that perhaps at night it would come alive with bustling restaurants and lots of local character. WRONG!! The 4 or 5 streets were 2 or 3 deep in homeless people, wino's, drug addicts, prostitutes. I lived in Peckham for 5 years. I have been to NY and travelled all over the world. Never, have I felt so threatened. We had to run into the road at one point to avoid the attention of beggars. This place needs to be taken off of the maps as a tourist attraction right now. if you are a tourist you will stand out like a sore thumb with a sign "mug me " above your head. and no, I am not exaggerating. it was like a scene from The Wire.

title: Scarytown!
reviews: I was so excited to visit Chinatown in Vancouver, and wow...what a major disappointment!  I've been to Chinatown in NYC, I've been to Chinatown in San Francisco.  This place didn't come close to resembling those.  It closer resembled the hood with a slight Asian twist.  I think the area may have had its day, but no longer.  My best advice is to stear clear.  Not worth your time or your nightmares.

title: It's a Real Chinatown
reviews: Granted, much of the vibrancy of Vancouver's Chinatown has been lost to Richmond and other areas of the city and there are some bad areas, however if you want a real Chinese experience in North America this is still a great place to go. Many Chinatowns around North America have been commercialized and Westernized to the extent that you're not really in a different place anymore. In Vancouver's Chinatown, you definitely are. It feels foreign, strange and exotic. And the food! I love it!

title: Chinafrown
reviews: Visited Chinatown in the early evening and found the majority of the shops and restaurants gated up like Fort Knox. My eight year old was terrified by the cast of characters we encountered... From ladies of the night, drug addicts and    the mentally ill, there was nothing positive about this experience. She was so mortified that any mention of Chinatown got her upset. Not a great start to our vacation.

title: Color, Bargains, and Culture
reviews: Something for every one.  Shopping for all tastes. Great place to get a deal.  Food from restaurants from fancy to plain as well as many interesting grocery stores. Make sure you have plenty of film in your camera.

title: Like being inside a Zombie horror film
reviews: "They are scaring but not dangerous" locals say. Do you want to see if that is true ? Dozens of homeless, drugadicts, mentally ill people. All of them together in few blocks. I was about to go by night ( a brochure carelessly advised to visit night market there ) Fortunatelly I read Trip advisors reveiews and decided to go during the day. Nobody tried to approach me but  it was more schocking that expected. So if you decide to go,  never by night, with no children,  and consider it a symphatetic experience about the other side  of a beautifull city.

title: Stay away
reviews: There is nothing in this Chinatown.  We also went a block off of it to try to get into Gastown.  Ended up in skid row.   Non stop junkies.  I had to take my 11 year old by the hand and plead with her to not let go.  Stay away from here.  Would give this a zero if I could.  There were no restaurants, just cheap wig shops.

title: This is Chinatown? ???
reviews: Having visited many of the Chinatown areas all over the world I was super excited to visit vancouvers one N we read that there was  a night market between 7-11 every Friday Saturday and Sunday . So we got there for about 730 for markets and Chinese dinner to be shocked!!!!! First of all everything was closed..... All of the bars/shops and restaurants! And no market!!! We later found out due to building work the market has been cancelled until finished which has should be another year....!! But I can honestly say it was a scarey experience visiting Chinatown with homeless drug users laying on the street/ hookers on street corners & a sense of danger in the air.We tried walk back to downtown vancouver but ended up on East Hastings street and this got even worse!!! Jumped on nearest bus to get out!  For anyone planning a visit to Chinatown and the reviews have not put you off then DO NOT visit at night.... Visit in the day and get a taxi in and out!

title: Larger than I expected...
reviews: I expected a two, three block Chinatown like the ones in Las Vegas or Portland, but this one was about six blocks by six blocks of Chinese faux architecture, with fruit and vegetable markets, restaurants, and herb apothecaries, tea shops, and the like.  It does not bustle, but people go about with tourists here and there.  There is the Sun Yat-Sen garden nearby, but Chinatown now seems more of a relic of a bygone era of the first Chinese wave of arrivals.  I can't vouch for any restaurants, but I did enjoy my walk around the area.  What was a little shocking is that one block north of Chinatown is Hastings Street, which is basically the skid row of Vancouver, the dregs and drugs of the city; strangely, it does not seem to affect Chinatown.

title: Losing grounds
reviews: Vancouver's Chinatown used to be the destination for everything and anything Asian in the City. With the explosion of Asian-oriented stores in other parts of the City, and the growth of the Asian community in the City of Richmond immediately South, Chinatown has lost much of it shine. While it may still attract some visitors - it is within walking distance from Downtown - those looking for authentic and higher-quality Asian food and goods risk being disappointed.

title: Edgy Ethnic Experience - A Walking tour of Chinatown by a Local
reviews: Full Disclosure: I am a Vancouverite of 22 years and have worked in Chinatown in the past.  I've walked these street many a time and eaten pretty much everywhere.If your idea of a tourist destination is 5 star hotels, fine dining and porter service take a pass on Chinatown but if you are the kind of person who wants likes adventure travel and want to see the real character of a historic place this is paydirt.Chinatown is a place in flux - has been for a while.  It is no longer the hub of ethnic life it once was since the Chinese have moved to the 'burbs like others who are upwardly mobile.  What is left is the physical memory of a refuge for Chinese who found themselves ostracized by broader Vancouver society.  Long since these dark and sad beginnings of the turn and early parts of the 20th Century, however, Chinatown is one of those places that has real character and the stones themselves tell stories.Geographically, to the north you find the poorest zip code in Canada.  Hastings street is not where bright-eyed tourists want to be as it is populated by drug dealers and stumblebums.  It is eye opening though.  The Carnegie Community Centre at Main and Hastings used to be the posh centre of Vancouver, but now it is the epicentre of a down and out neighbourhood.  To the west past Carral street you'll find gentrification and the sportsplexes of B.C. Stadium and Rogers Arena. There is a great Asian grocery store (T&T) at Abbott and Keefer as well as the International Village Mall near the skytrain. There is a skate park and playing field along Expo Blvd.  If you keep on expo going south you will reach Science World.To the south is Prior Street and it is the southern reaches of Chinatown.  There is a small Jimi Hendrix Shrine at Prior and Main. To the east is residential buildings.  It's not really worth wandering past Gore Street, aka, church row where the First United Church and Christ Church of China serve the neighbourhood.So where are the good spots?The Stroll: There are fruit and vegetable markets, fishmongers, butcher shops, pastry shops, apothecaries (go in and check out the dried lizards, seahorses etc.), tea shops up and down Keefer and Pender.  You would pretty much see everything by going down both streets between Abbot and Gore.  It looks like Chinatown and smells like Chinatown.  The buildings that will really bring you back to the day, however, is on Pender between Main & Columbia.  Just look up and it will take you back a hundred years to the "tongs" or family associations.  The Sun Yat San Gardens just a few steps further on Pender has a free walled garden area worth looking into and is quite nice.  You can pay to tour the garden house part of the site if you are so inclined.  Check out the narrowest building in Vancouver on Pender and Carral on your way to the Welcome Arch further down towards the west.  There is also a monument to the Chinese Canadian Soldiers who served in the Canadian military during the wars at Columbia and Keefer.  These guys paved the way for the Chinese to finally become citizens of Canada.The Food: Massive lunch Dim Sum place at the Floata (in the big building at Columbia and Keefer). If you like Asian style tea joints (serving fusion style western and Asian) hit up Maxim's (Keefer & Gore).  Try the beef tongue spaghetti.  Asian style diners are everywhere but I recommend Kam Gok Yuen (on Pender near Keefer).  My favourite, however, is the always busy Cambodian restaurant Pnom Penh on the southside of Georgia between Gore and Main.  I highly recommend their chicken wings, butter beef (rare beef smothered in cilantro, garlic & oil), beef on rice or lemon grass chicken on rice.  If you crave a western meal, Save on Meats is on Hastings and Meat & Bread just a bit beyond Chinatown - both are great!Chinatown is great for an edgy cultural experience.  Take a stroll and have a snack or some lunch!

title: Enjoyable
reviews: I enjoyed my walk through Chinatown. We have nothing similar in the area I am from, so it was interesting to see the Asian influence in Vancouver.  I did come across some people begging for money while in Chinatown, but never felt I was in danger. The best part of Chinatown is definitely the Classical Chinese Garden.

title: Don't go to Chinatown!
reviews: Chinatown was advertised as a tourist attraction .  Very irresponsible  to send unsuspecting tourists to this area.  We went to Gastown which was a nice area .  We then headed to Chinatown.  We very quickly realized that this was a bad idea. Many homeless people and drug addicts.  We quickly got out of there.  Saw the Chinatown arches...but no Chinatown.  Just a run down, very  scary and unsafe area  that is not for tourists... Unless you are a tourist looking to buy drugs

title: Better days are behind it
reviews: We had heard about Vancouver’s Chinatown and made a point to schedule time to walk there from our hotel. It was a bit of a walk and we were tired from exploring Canada Place, so we decided to drive there instead. We drove down Pender St and turned giddy when we saw the ornate gate with Oriental motifs. The giddiness turned to shock as we drove under the gate and further down the street. Many store fronts were closed; many seemed permanent. The streets and buildings look unkempt and only the occasional pedestrian could be seen. We decided not to stop and instead turned the car around… onto Hastings St. Not a smart move; this area which is a block away from Pender is most unsavory.There really is no reason to visit this Chinatown in its current state. It is sad that even the sizable Chinese population in Vancouver has moved to South Vancouver and Richmond. Hopefully the city and its denizens will recognize the potential this area has, and revitalize it. I’ve been to the Chinatowns in S.F., L.A., and N.Y.C., all kitschy but with vibrant communities. Vancouver’s is not in the same league.

title: Slipping away....
reviews: Visiting after a two year's absence was very shocking.  Many of the vibrant businesses are gone now, many empty stores.  For once it was easy to get a parking space!  The Night Market has relocated to Richmond, where is apparently where all the Asian business has gone to.  It's such a shame as there is so much history in this area, and it looks like the city is just letting it decline.  One block is being torn down to raise new multifloor apartments/condos, and that's probably what will happen to the entire area eventually!  It is sketchy in the area, but if you go during day hours and stay around the open businesses, it'll be fine.  There are still "jewels" there like the Sun Yat Sen Classical garden which we always love to visit.  And the Flota Restaurant & Hon Restaurant are still there.  We're just so sad to see the change!  Please, Vancouver, save this neighborhood!

title: Disappointed
reviews: Apparently this is way past its prime. We were shocked that it is located next the a large homeless population. We didn't realize that this situation was that visible in one of the more prominent cities in North America. It made our visit to Chinatown (which is usually a pilgrimage site for many Chinese/Asian families) a little distasteful. It dampened any shopping, eating and sightseeing experience in the area and would probably avoid it in the future.

title: Not worth it
reviews: We were in gastown and decided to walk to chinatown. Do not take hastings,  it is a really bad area in vancouver.After going through hastings (and praying we would make it through not getting robbed or into a fight), chinatown was upsetting. It was not busy, it looked run down, and it was not in good shape. Not worth it at all!The chinese garden was nice but vancouver has other parks that are nice and in a better area of the city. If you choose to go here, go in the daytime and not through hastings.  Take a cab, drive or the hop on off bus. Do not walk...I would not recommend others to go here.

title: Great !
reviews: I like Chinatown . Here in Vancouver you can find some good Restaurants . And go to the Chinagarden , and Chinese Culturalcentre . There is also a Museum . Great Places to visit !

title: The World's Worst Chinatown?
reviews: We ran the gauntlet of Hastings St to get to Chinatown from Gastown, only to be disappointed by the blandness of it all.  Not even worth the walk.

title: Skip this "Attraction"
reviews: I was very excited to visit Chinatown just to be very disappointed. Filled with mediocre restaurants and gift shops. Many Chinese grocery stores with exotic items for sale (well, exotic to me, like a dried Gecko to make tea, good for back pain) This was probably a nice place to visit 10 years ago, not anymore, believe me when I say you will not have your "fix" of China after visiting this place. The central point of Chinatown can be found at the corner of Pender & Carrall.

title: Not friendly and a sketchy area
reviews: The shopkeepers were not friendly at all.  We felt very unwelcome.  The area was very questionable.  It is not somewhere I would visit again.

title: Best to see from the Hop on Hop off Bus
reviews: For us we observed Vancouver China Town from the Hop on Hop off bus. If you wish you can jump off and experience the hustle and bustle of this place but equally you can stay on the bus and move on whilst observing the usual trading that goes on in China Towns

title: Skip it
reviews: Dirty, run down & smelly,  don't waste your time!  We went during the middle of the day and felt unsafe.  In addition,  not much to see.

title: Very tired
reviews: In need of a lot of TLC. no real atmosphere. Lacks the character one would expect based on visits to other Chinatowns around the world.

title: OK, but not on the sacle of china town in NY or SF
reviews: We like visiting China Towns, somewhere we read that this was one of the biggest in North America. Not so, at least not impressive so. Much better the ones in NY and SF. Disappointing.

title: Not much to see
reviews: It was all very ordinary and I was expecting a bustling area full of tightly-packed stalls and shops selling Chinese food and crafts. I have been to other Chinatowns (eg Bangkok) where it is just that and is a real experience. If you don't get round to visiting Chinatown you have not missed anything.

title: I love Chinatown!
reviews: We always go to Chinatown when in Vancouver, the excitement from the people around you and the stores! I love the flea market! The Gentleman upstairs I have nick named the singing merchant. He is so friendly and always sings!He enjoys his job and it shows I love it! We also hit the little tea shops for tea and dessert. A wonderful place to go thank you!

title: very disappointed
reviews: The best Chinese food is no longer here.  If you want good Chinese food, go to Richmond. Ever since Vancouver built the Safe Houses for drug addicts, Chinatown has become an unsafe place to visit for tourist and families.

title: a bit disappointed
reviews: may be I was expecting something like San Francisco Chinatown. it was a bit small.  we had some Dumplings and were very disappointed. food  was very blend.The place was still buzzing with lots of Chinese shoppers and  spices and other  stores . It looks like this part of the city is a bit run down, home shelters are very common in this part of the town and people wander around without aim. .

title: Small Chinatown
reviews: I love the dumplings here in Vancouver Chinatown. The price is cheap and good food. They have night market Friday and Saturday during summer time and have some shows. Where they highlight karaoke night, karate performances by 2 different karate school one in Vancouver and the other was in Richmond. One can also find cheap souvenirs. For t-shirt you have to look for the size for the shirt may say XL but is actually L. I gave an average rating for it is not a good neighborhood. Most of the Chinese merchants are leaving this place and is moving to Richmond or some of them do business here but live in Richmond for this reason most of the stores are closed early around 6pm except the restaurants.

title: Small Chinatown
reviews: My wife and I just visited San Francisco a couple of months ago and were surprised to see how much smaller Vancouver's is in comparison.  Do not wander east of the area because the area is very shady with many destitutes.Ed K.Ed K.

title: Vancouver Richmond Chinatown.
reviews: Vancouver Chinatown is the oldest. Interesting from an historical standpoint, it has seen better days, Richmond has a very large Chinese population with a score of malls and shopping centers which cater to Chinese (Mandarin and Cantonese) speakers. There are east Asian restaurants: seafood, dim sum, Cantonese, Mandarin and Sichuan, also Vietnamese, Japanese, Korean etc. Amazing variety of everything. In the summer there are two night markets, full of small shops and eating stalls. Very authentic.

title: Ehhhhh...
reviews: I am always curious how does Chinatown look like in other cities and this one was just disappointing like other reviewers had mentioned. I didn't think it was that bad, but it was. I felt like a minority in that area (coming from a city where Asians are everywhere!). There weren't many people (I'm used to crowds), it seemed very depressing to me =/  I didn't bother looking for any souvenirs and I am all about bringing something back home with me whenever I go to places. This is just sad, really.

title: A bit of a letdown.
reviews: I suppose I'm a bit spoiled with the great Chinatown in Victoria... The food and shopping in Vancouver's Chinatown was average, at best.

title: Boarding
reviews: It was dirty, food was not that good. Not worth the drive from Seattle. I been to Chinatown I'm San Francisco and it was thousand time better.

title: A short walk from down town!
reviews: This area is interesting.  There are some pretty great Chinese and tea shops but there is also alot of up and coming small businesses that are an extension of Gastown.  It might seem a bit scetchy but it is certainly not unsafe.

title: New Town Bakery
reviews: Lunch was great! We come here almost everytme we visit Vancouver.beacuse the steame buns are incedible. It's always busy for a reason.

title: STAY AWAY! Go to Richmond City Centre
reviews: Vancouver Chinatown is in Downtown Eastside, the most notorious area in Vancouver for drug trade, prostitution, and crowds and crowds of homeless people. If you do have to visit, be sure to stay safe! The most disgusting crossing is E. Hastings St & Main St.Anyway you can find lots of cheap but nice Chinese and Vietnamese restaurants in Chinatown. And the Dr. Sun Yat-sun Garden is pretty for Non-Chinese. Even for Chinese people, it's amazing to see such a big and traditional Chinese garden in North America. Try going to Richmond City Cetre for a completely different view of what the "Modern Chinatown" is like. Richmond is the largest "Chinatown" in North America. You'll get very amazed if you go there! Almost everyone is Chinese in that Canadian municipality.

title: A big Chinatown
reviews: This is a big Chinatown where we had an early Chinese dinner, yummy. Some parts of the town are beautiful while other parts are not. We were caution that to stay safe we must keep to the main street, which is beautiful and full of shops and eateries. It is worth visiting this Chinatown.

title: Sketchy
reviews: Dirty, smelly, falling apart both the buildings and the people. Clearly a lot of down and out and sick looking people. Having visited Chinatown in both New York and San Francisco, I was looking forward to a treat. Not so much. We had given ourselves four hours to sightsee and eat we cut out after two. Did eat at the only restaurant that seemed to be open. Waitstaff definitely not interested in our business but we did enjoy our dim sum (my son declared it the best Chinese food he had ever eaten). Picked up some calligraphy supplies in one very festive shop. The shopkeeper was actually pleasant and made small talk. Two bright spots in an otherwise dismal experience.

title: okay area
reviews: We went to Chinatown here in Vancouver as we didn't have anywhere in our itinerary. We are aware that one need to be careful if we want to see it. But off we go, we visited the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Garden and it turned out to be worth it, I made a review about this garden. Then we looked for the best siopao and apple tarts they are boasting about, the New Town bakery and we were surprise that there were Filipino products being sold there like puto(rice cake), palitaw, and the siopao although its Chinese bakery and resto but we were there to just buy the baked goods, originally just to buy the siopao and apple tarts we ended up buying the BBQ bun and the you tiao. There were Filipino newspapers as well, saw adobo in their menu too.

title: scary
reviews: We walked along one road on the way back from the cinema in April on a dreary early evening and along 1 road there were a hundred or so drunken down and outs.  It was quite scary to walk along as a family with children under 12.

title: The worst China Town I have visited
reviews: China Town in Vancouver is in a very bad area of town. The actual China Town area is fairly derelict and at night not a pleasent area to walk around. Most shops were closed up or boarded up and the area did not offer up any restaurants. If you venture one street away to East Hastings you are faced with a street full of homeless people and you really do feel for your safety at night. Vancouver really has a problem in this area of town and it is not safe or pleasant for visitors. There is a lot of work to do if this is going to be a tourist destination again.

title: Fortune cookie say: Avoid this place
reviews: I'VE been in a number of Chinatown areas and this one in Vancouver is in a class of its own as the worst of the lot by a country mile.Apart from the fact I've seen more vibrant life exhibited by a dustbin, this place genuinely you made you wary.Impressions weren't helped by being almost immediately approached by a wild-eyed raddled woman in her 60s. She sported long white hair and a full black cocktail dress at 11am as part of a strident approach to beg a dollar off us. We ignored her as did several other pedestrians as she ran first up the street and then down it, importuning anyone who came within range.Now we'd done our homework and knew it was a dodgy area for drug addicts, prostitutes etc, but even we were surprised by this upfront welcome.The more you looked the more you saw. Skeletal men who seemed to have trouble recognising if it was day or night with others only prevented from falling over by the building they were propped up against.It could be so different because we really liked the little clasical Chinese garden there while some of the craft areas were also worth a look.Sadly the main look being given was over your shoulder to make sure of personal safety and we didn't really relax until our Big Bus arrived to whisk us away to Gastown, an area claimed to have its own problems but which seemed like paradise when stacked up against Chinatown.In short, think twice before going there.

title: Walking Dead do exist near this area!
reviews: Zombies!  Beware of zombies!  Chinatown in downtown area of Vancouver is located in a bad area of the city!  Located near East Hastings where all the homeless roam is bad for outside visitors to the city!  You will see homeless with shopping carts, drug dealers, prostitutes...and even the "walking dead!"  But within Chinatown there is the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Park some nice pastry shops but I think the area like East Hastings are scaring the tourists away!

title: Horrible! I've been to the big cities on 5 continents and Hastings Street
reviews: Hastings Street is by far the worst smelliest scariest sad place I have seen on five continents ! I'm including Mumbai  India here too.  Drug addicts. Prostitutes etc. sad!

title: Dangerous
reviews: Chinatown can be a dangerous place to go. We jumped of the big bus tour and went one way straight into crack town, every city has its areas where you need to be careful. Normally you can find out the less desirable areas and avoid them. I would recommend that Chinatown and the neighbouring streets are avoided. There are plenty of other safer areas to explore.

title: Tough to find the right restaurant
reviews: We were hungry so walked into one that was extremely busy, thinking it must be good. Turned out that the customers were all tourists that their tour guider sent there. Wish I could remember the name, sorry. Next time we'll ask a native for a place.Also, to walk from here to Gastown, we went along Hastings St. Very entertaining if you want to look at the druggies, beggars and hookers.

title: Emerse yourself in Chinese Culture
reviews: Always enjoy a stop here,all the shopping for unique Chinese decor,teapots,bamboo,rattan,teas,everything you would find in China!The pricing is great and friendly hosts. Enjoy authentic Chinese food,Dim Sum and much more. There is also a beautiful Chinese Gardens nearby and in the mornings see many practicing Tai Chi.

title: A big disappointment
reviews: Having read the tourist information we had relatively high expectations of Chinatown.  Like a previous reviewer we visited Gas Town first before walking onto Chinatown.  The difference between the two is striking - Gas Town is clean, tidy and you feel safe as a tourist whereas by comparison Chinatown is dirty, tatty and feels anything but safe.  As we walked through it we passed a number of unsavoury characters sprawled on the floor.  We visited the Chinese Garden which was nice but after this we decided to leave and take the Sky Train back to Canada Place.  I would not recommend visiting, especially if travelling with a family.  We had thought of eating there one evening but after seeing it during the day will now not bother.

title: Not much to speak of
reviews: I didn't find Vancouver's Chinatown much more special or different from other Chinatowns we've visited. The shops were all selling the same touristy things, and there wasn't much in the way of architecture to look at.The New Town Bakery is worth seeking out as is the garden.

title: Do not take your kids!
reviews: I agree with the other reviews.  We walked from GasTown (clean and touristy) to Chinatown and got totally shocked.  Homeless drug addicts everywhere.  In our haste to get out of the area we went from Bad to Terrible and walked to Hastings street.  I never seen so many drug addicts, beggars, and prostitutes in my life.  That is saying a lot!  Our two kids were in shock as we walked from one side of the street to the other to escape.  It was scary, like a scene from the Walking Dead.  In our haste we took the first bus in any direction to get out.  Do Not Go and do not believe the flyers!  Read the reviews on this site.

title: A fun walk, but not the greatest part of town
reviews: We created our own walking tour of Chinatown based on information I'd found online.  We visited the Millenium Gate, the Winds of Change mural, the historic alleys, the West Han Dynasty bell, the Sam Kee building, the China Gate, the Zodiac Mosaic, the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Gardens (rated separately), the giant abacus, the neon Chinatown sign, and the monument to the Canadian Chinese.  It was a nice walk with a lot of history, but parts of Gastown and Chinatown were pretty rough and rundown with a lot of homeless looking characters moving around.  I would only recommend Chinatown if you are comfortable with this sort of environment (a confident independent traveler), and if you have little kids I'd recommend staying away.

title: A wet firecracker
reviews: My biggest complaint with Chinatown is this: the only shops that seem to be bi-lingual are the ones that sell clothes or home decor. There were several shops selling a plethora of intriguing dried goods and/or produce, but ALL the signs were written in Chinese.  I'm sure if I had any idea what these things were, I'd've walked out with an armload.  I felt quickly like an outsider who'd be snubbed for asking.

title: Chinatown Vancouver
reviews: Don't waste your time.  I read so many things about Vancouver Chinatown.  I walked there and thought am I in the area they were talking about - it was nothing and not safe.  There was no bustling area that I could see.  The smell of urine was everywhere from the street people sleeping on the sidewalks.  I was there at 10 am in the morning and was shocked.  Never, never walk on Hastings Street, you can cross over it, but don't walk on the street.  Act like you know what you are doing and don't bring anything that you may be sorry to loose.  So many wonderful things to do in Vancouver, this should be removed from the list for a tourist attraction.

title: A Typical Chinatown
reviews: There's really not much to see at this Chinatown unless you don't have one in your city and haven't been to one in SF, LA, NYC, etc.  There is a limited number of restaurants, and the good ones have lines and waits.  The night market is okay, though not very big, and the neighborhood itself isn't overly clean nor does it have much a view.

title: Not that bad
reviews: My experience here was nowhere near as bad as most of these reviews. I have lived in many Asian cities, so my expectations were tempered. First of all, this is not a "touristy" Chinatown. If that is what you are looking for, stay away. It is, however, what I would expect from an inner city working/small business area where many of the proprietors also live. It reminded me of out of the way areas in Hong Kong.  My main reason for going to this area was to find various Asian herbal medicines/remedies and tea. The Asian section of the city near whereI live (SeattIe) is expensive for these types of items. I was not disappointed in what I was able to find in Vancouver's Chinatown. Found all of the herbal medicines/remedies I was looking for and found loose leaf Pur-eh Tea prepackaged in a 1lb box from China at $6 CAD. That is an extremely reasonable price. The tea, when brewed, turned out to be good quality. In summary, if you are looking for the touristy, restaurant experience, this is not for you. If you know what you are looking for and are a bargain hunter, it is worth the trip.

title: Sketch town
reviews: I walked around a bit because I was in the area to visit Dr. Sun Sat Park but soon I realized there was nothing really interesting there.  Sketchy and run-down.

title: Stay away at all costs!!
reviews: Me and my family decided that a trip to Vancouver's Chinatown would be a good choice because from our experience of Sydney's Chinatown which is bustling, full of tourists and good restaurants. We however were shocked when we went to Chinatown in Vancouver. There were barely any restaurants, the only ones were dirty and unclean. Barely any tourists. But the worst part was that the whole area surrounding Chinatown, is a slum area. We did not feel safe despite the fact it was only in the afternoon. We saw hundreds of homeless people on the street, the worst street being east hasting street. AVOID AT ALL COSTS!!! Will not recommend to anyone.

title: Concrete Ugly Area
reviews: As there are so many Chinese people we thought this would be a vibrant colourful area. We took the hop on hop off bus tour and stopped off here. How wrong we were, after visiting the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Gardens (waste of money!) we wandered around this ugly concrete sprawl of cheap shops – nothing like colourful noisy, energetic Chinatown in London and it borders on the most horrific crack cocaine controlled drug area so be careful which street you choose to walk through to get to Gas Town

title: Chinatown, Vancouver - Do not go there!
reviews: Chinatown was part of our On-Off bus tour, but we regretted going there the moment we left the bus.  Sadly, it is grubby, run-down, shabby etc.  It looks unhygienc and is very unappealing.  We felt sorry for the people who live and work there.  Surely something could be done to improve it for their sake.  Vancouver has many wonderful places to visit, but Chinatown is not one of them.  Avoid it.

title: Nostalgic and cultural experience
reviews: Give Chinatown a try.  I was going to skip given the reviews but I found lots of interesting shops there and lots of deals.  I like the Hong Kong mom and pop shops and being from HK myself I found the experience nostalgic.  The streets can be run down a bit. There is some construction of new buildings.  It would be a shame if they do not revive Chinatown in some way.  I took lots of photos.

title: Not for Tourists
reviews: This is NOT a tourist spot so don't bother!  It's everything others have described: dirty, smells, homeless location, drug activity, old & run down buildings, and scary yet it's a great place to buy traditional Chinese home remedy herbs and to enjoy a delicious meal!   When we visit Vancouver, this is a MUST for us to eat dim sum at HON's and Maxim's for pastries (both across the street from each other).  We found Sundays are best to visit because it's less crowded and there is street parking close to where you want to be.  The parking lots are unattended and doesn't look secure so best bet is to park on the street where there is a flurry of folks.   Customer service is not the servers priority but if you can deal with it, you'll enjoy a great meal in Chinatown.

title: Do not go at night ...
reviews: This was not worth the walk. Very dirty and old. Would recommend taking bus and be careful which streets you go on.  Do not go alone! There was a Friday evening craft market on Keefer street which was interesting, had a music group.  No cheap or unique things that I wanted to buy.  We did not see any restaurants that we wanted to try.  Asked a security officer about safe route back downtown and he said to definitely take the bus and not walk after dark!

title: Don't waste your time!
reviews: One of my "must" visit places on my vacation.  Worst Chinatown I've ever visited! It's  expensive with rude, RUDE servers. NO need to speak or understand Chinese, the three women servers' body language and snide looks said it all. Adding more insult, she gave me the wrong order. The food was crap, stale. I dumped all of it. It was the worst dim sum ever!! Unlike other districts, don't waste your time and effort at this Chinatown. It's dirty and you don't feel safe at all. ZERO stars would be more appropriate except the small garden is there.

title: Just Okay
reviews: I've been to several different Chinatown's in the States, so I had a certain expectation.  This was my least favorite experience for sure.  It's incredibly dirty in Chinatown so unless you have a recommendation for a restaurant, you may want to avoid them.  The stores are mostly crowded with cheap items meant to attract tourist, I'm assuming - but these places were mostly a turn off for me.  There was one called "Arts and Crafts" near the Asian Gardens that we liked though, so that was a nice exception.  And another called Zodiak (I think) right in front of the garden that was clean and you could walk in and turn around without knocking things over.  We won't go back here though.

title: Very dirty
reviews: Walked to here after picking up attraction leaflet from information centre.  Passed someone sitting injecting drugs  whilst on way visiting first point of attraction.  If time is short & there is an alternative attraction to view I would suggest opting out of Chinatown.

title: Love the gateway
reviews: I love the gateway, however, other than Dr. Garden, boring.Not enough of an ethnic feel when we walk down th narrow sidewalks. Would better to close off the street as pedestrian area. Would give the area greater charm and allow shoppers to enjoy the place more

title: Deceiving and a shame the neighbourhood is so rundown
reviews: The guidebooks are quite deceiving about Vancouver's Chinatown.  It is very sketchy given that it is so close to East Hastings (the roughest place in Vancouver).  I made a quick trip with a purpose - buying some tea. I would suggest you avoid the place unless you have a predetermined objective.  There are too many other good things to do in Vancouver.  All that being said, the city really needs to put some thought in what it wants its Chinatown to look like.  It is very unfortunate that Canada's west coast capital/asian gateway doesn't have a more vibrant and interesting Chinatown.

title: china in canada
reviews: very pleasent the biggest china town in canada.lots of nice restaurant serving typical asian foods.it's like a trip in china

title: kerching, kerching, kerching Chinatown!
reviews: Kerching, kerching!Yep, that's right...Chinatown is all about business and cash registers making that familiarkerching sound!There is brisk business being done here, which is nothing new, as the chinese people in general,like he east indians here in Vancouver, are natural business peoples..and good luck to them, too!I for one wouldn't want to be siting behind a shop counter like them, for more than 10 hours a day.It's damn hard work, and all praise to people who can put up with it.Back to Chinatown....it;s located right next to the downtown eastside core, home to a lot of peoplewith addiction and social problems, but show me any modern city which hasn't got these problems!There are a plethora of stores, selling anything from roast duck, to octopus, to lobster, to crabs,or dim-sum, dried seaweed, medicinal herbs, remedies for anything from a blocked nose toarthritis, and above all, guaranteed walk-by of some of the most colourful and varied peoplein Vancouver.I regularly come here whenever I'm in Vancouver, which is about once a month. And you know what? I always seem to find something, or someone interesting every time.You can spend anywhere form an hour to half a day here, and if you get fed up with people watching,pop down the street into an oasis of peace and calm, the Dr Yun Fat Sen oriental gardens. There you canwalk around to your heart's content, stay as long as you want. The place is priceless in the peace and tranquility it brings to the area.Transport is no problem--the Skytrain station is less than 5 minutes walk away, buses are a dime to the dozen, as they say!Plenty of places to eat, too....I highly recommend a chinese restaurant based on Keefer St and Gore!Before I sign off...and I think the staff at TripAdvisor wouldn't mind me saying so, I am a freelance writer and write for websites, local papers, online forums and local companies in Seattle and Vancouver. I can be contacted through these posts of mine! Thank you.

title: China Town Supermarket is great for Meat shopping!
reviews: My husband & I buy our crab & fish at the Gar Lok fishmonger on Georgia.  One day we wandered around and found the Chinatown Supermarket on Keefer across from Hons.  We bought chicken wings and pork chops.  They are much less expensive than Granville Island where I usually shop.  They were great so we went back and tried their tenderloin.  We bought a fairly large piece for $30.  It too was great - better than what we get at Costco.  So now I have been buying all our meat here.  They are extremely friendly too.  They have vegetables too.  We recommend it.

title: China Town
reviews: This part of town was a bit sketchy....i did enjoy the small shops along the way and one of the restaurants i went to...then i saw this 2$ store...amazing deals and cool stuff from China and Japan.

title: Great Place to Wander
reviews: I visit there quite often for my vegetables, mango juice, mandarin orange juice, medicines, bakery, Viet coffee, tea and have eaten at Hon's.  Can't find a better deal on veggies.

title: A must see
reviews: Chinatown, need I say more. Be sure to see the Chinese Garden. This is a fun walk and an easy stroll back to Gastown.

title: Mislead by the guidebooks...
reviews: ...and didn't read tripadvisor first.  This place is truly disturbing and terrible.  I'm sure there are nice places in there somewhere that deserve your business or visit, but it's not worth it.  The Chinese garden (free side) was nice but small.  We tried to walk around for a few minutes, but it was not a place you'd want to wander around in.  We stumbled through some kind of street market that was unfortunately full of people who have seen better days and did not feel safe at all.  One of the worst single places I've ever visited, and such a shame in a nice city like Vancouver.  It was my first trip to Vancouver and this area lowered my opinion of the city a good deal. Definitely avoid it.

title: T&T Supermarket
reviews: I have appointed myself Chinatown supermarket ambassador in which one of my key responsibilities is to check their inventory and their pricing. Why....coz i am strange. The fruits and seafood selection is quite amazing, plus the fresh Chinese pastries and weird antipasti like cold jellyfish and cold pigs' ears. The place itself is extremely interesting, plenty of things to see and touch. And the smells.If you are a foodie, you must go to this supermarket and touch everything. If you are not a foodie, you must go to this suupermarket and TRY to touch everything. If you are neither....were you lost? and if so, serendipity has propelled you here, so wander around.

title: It's trying to come back - missed you!
reviews: Slowly coming back - Eat at Hon' s Won Ton - couple of good bakeries - The strathcona area is attempting to be revitilized - Fewer of the old shops of interest - Have faith ...

title: Real Chinese Food
reviews: I loved the shopping, the ambience and the best Chinese Food!! The prices are right. I bought essential oils and a nice tea pot!

title: It's too close to East Hastings
reviews: After seeing Victoria's Chinatown (fantastic vibe, food, people) I was excited to check out Vancouver's.  There were a few shops selling fresh fish (literally 2-3 and we walked several blocks), but too many boarded up buildings.  Sad and confusing.   We were told to go to Richmond.

title: keep out of china town
reviews: Keep well away from China Town and Hasting street, full of down and outs and prostitutes, if you like to see a nice China Town head to Richmond,

title: Horrible place
reviews: After visiting "GUS", the next neighborhood we decided continuing walking.What we saw was a dirty streets, strange people and in a square, many of drugs persons. And it was just 3 in the afternoon.

title: Scared the hell out of us.....
reviews: We make a point of going to every Chinatown where we travel (and we travel alot) this place scared the hell out of us. It is dirty, full of drug addicts and prostitutes, and people were literaly fighting in the streets......couldnt wait to get out of there..DONT TAKE KIDS

title: Not like I expected
reviews: There were a few nice places, I liked the chinese garden. But it did not have the allure as "china town" in London or Amsterdam. There are also man bums on the street.

title: You CAN afford to miss this
reviews: I've been to Chinatown in: Los Angeles, New York, Chicago, Singapore, Thailand, Korea, temple st Hong Kong and a few others and this is by FAR the saddest ChinaTown my eyes have seen. Do not cross through Hastings Street if you have kids or have no street life experience. Full of drugs, prostitutes, beggars, thieves. Spare the kids, definitely not a family place.

title: A Genuine Taste of China
reviews: As others have said, go to Dr. Sun Yat Sen's Chinese garden and Tea House. Be sure to go when there are no bus tours letting out. The one day we went, we were overwhelmed by the people getting off tour buses.Chinatown is a real mix. Go with a positive attitude, and good things will come your way. The local shops have delightful and friendly staff. There are some real bargains to be had. There are a number of traditional food markets with very unusual produce. Tea shops are also plentiful.There are some popular and good restaurants on Main Street.Where Main Street intersects Hastings, I felt a bit uncomfortable with the sheer number of street people I encountered. However, no one bothered me.

title: Smaller than San Francisco, but more Real.
reviews: Dr. Sun Yat Sen Center and Chinese Garden, food purveyors of everything except the usual, wonderful restaurants, and nice people.  What more can you ask for in a neighborhood?

title: Ah, the aromas!
reviews: I love everything about Chinatown, Vancouver. The hustle and bustle, the colors, the aromas, the food, the diversity of languages filtering through my ears.

title: Disappointing - it's obviously seen better days....
reviews: If you like seeing a run-down, non-dynamic Chinatown,  poor-quality tourist trap, then this is the place for you.  It's obviously seen better days.  Restaurants weren't too good either.When we were there,  there were lots of down-and-outs too and were generally unpleasant and just made us wary.  Sad.  Best avoided........except you MUST go to Dr. Sun Yat Sen's Classical Chinese Garden on Carrall Street.  It's simply beautiful and peaceful - a real treasure  (I've written a separate review so I can gush even more...)

title: Terrible
reviews: Full of vagrants,druggies, beggers We visited furring the day and it was a bit scary nevermind at night would not recommend it at all

title: Zombieland
reviews: Crowded with drugadicts everywere in Sunday noon. Poor people! miserable experience I was truly affected after visiting Chinatown.

title: neat shops and food.
reviews: This is a must see in Vancouver. There are alot of little restaurants through this area and the shops are great to just stroll through, although it is more of a ballet experience with all the shoppers there. Great fun!

title: Don't waste your time
reviews: Vancouver's "Chinatown" is for the tourists who don't know better.  Take it from someone who knows, I'm an ABC, American Born Chinese who has traveled to China and Hong Kong and knows pretty good dim sum.  The food here is crap.  Go to Richmond, particularly Fisherman's Terrace for possibly the best dim sum in the world. Better than Hong Kong and China.

title: Pick your spots
reviews: Chinatown is in flux, many people have flocked to richmond - not to miss is the sun yat sun gardens a real hidden jewel. Lot of new shops are changing this area but not the best tourist place to visit.

title: Not the best chinatown
reviews: The Chinatown in Vancouver isn't the best. It's more of a locals spot. You can buy some souvenirs and cheap things. If you miss it. Don't worry it's not all that exciting. There is a large homeless population in this area around main and pender. Not all that safe at night.Best part would be Tinseltown cinemas they usually have cheap Tuesday! Lol

title: Disappointed
reviews: We were disappointed at how run down the area was. I think the area is suffering from the bad world economy. If one has limited time in Vancouver, one should skip China Town. We did walk through a free garden by the Sun Yat -Sen memorial. It was just ok. It was interesting to look at the food stuffs available at the shops as we strolled through the area.

title: Very distressing - Give it a miss
reviews: The only good thing I could find to say about Chinatown is the Supermarket in the International Centre has fabulous live seafood and great selection of fruit and vegetables.  Other than that - YUK - what a horrible place - dirty, with hundreds of vagrants, drug users, mentally ill and various 'zombie' like people loitering  everywhere.  Vancouver has more than it's share of vagrants - but Chinatown is over run with them.  No way could I recommend a visit here - a total tragedy, and quite distressing.  The authors of the Tourist blurbs are in serious denial.

title: Disappointing to be honest
reviews: The guide books go ape over Chinatown but we were very disappointing.  Very few restaurants, and even fewer you'd consider eating at.  The main problem is that it is right next door to the vagrant ghetto and there are tramps and other fairly intimidating people all over the place.  Do the Sun Yet-Kan garden and then leave the area immediately!

title: OK in the day, lousy at night
reviews: Not much is open around here at night, and it's really close to a large segment of the drug addled population. Unfortunately, most of the restaurants were closed when we went on a Saturday evening.

title: Disappointing, dirty and got food poisoning
reviews: The websites i checked out said that Chinatown is not to be missed as it was one of the attractions when visiting Vancouver. We went on a Sunday at noon and the place looked run down, there were only a handful of places open and the other businesses were vacant.  When I went to the Chinese information center offered no information when I asked which restaurants are a good place to try and what attractions should I see.  I was told that they couldn't help and for me to just look around.  When I turned into another street, there was a horde of homeless people converging by the restrooms.  The restaurant that we opted to have lunch at was the worst Chinese restaurant because it gave us the runs (food poisoning).

title: Smelly, dirty and not a place to visit
reviews: Smelly, dirty and not a place to visit if you want to enjoy your trip without uneasiness. If you come into Chinatown via East Hastings St. It is filled with drug addicts, homeless people and is a disgrace to the way the town council have allowed this to spread thoughout the city. A suggestion is perhaps they should clean the homeless people up and give them a job to clean the city streets, which will give them back their self-respect. Some need mental treatments and this is not a problem Vancouver can sweep under the carpet and hope to attract vistors to a city that has one of the worst growing homeless problems in the western world.

title: Chinatown - not your usual.
reviews: Visited a number of Chinatowns including New York & London and this is nothing like that.  It's a really dodgy area so if you do decide to venture here keep your wits about you.  Don't expect any standard chinese restaurants they are mostly open in the day for tea/dim sum only.

title: one of the very best in N. America
reviews: This is the second largest chinatown in n. america (as compared to nyc). It is fun to spend a saturday morning walking the streets neiandering through chinatown. Dim-sum is a must but go to kirin's either downtown or at city square for the very best dim-sum in the city. Hon's is good for basic chinese food in chinatown. It is cheap and cheerful. Chinatown is a great place for gifts too. Don't wonder off to skid row though (it is the poorest zip code in canada). It is only one block north of chinatown. You can walk past it to go to gastown. Skid row is not dangerous for tourists just sad and an eye-opener.

title: Experience it
reviews: I grew up in the area, now have lived in suburbs for more than 40 years. Noticeably the area has changed, cleaned up and more shopper friendly. Still get the old time vibe but much safer to wander.

title: An okay chinatown, but not great
reviews: Chinatown itself seemed small and did not offer a whole lot of variety. Many better chinese restaurants and shops can be found throughout the rest of Vancouver. We visited on a weekend night where they had the chinese outdoor market. Most of the booths sold absolute junk. However, there was live music so that was entertaining. Overall, I was not impressed.

title: Interesting old neighborhood
reviews: Much smaller than the Chinatowns in New York and San Francisco, Vancouver's Chinatown is an authentic old neighborhood which we found to be very interesting. The Sun Yat Sen Garden (paid admission) has a charming free park; the entry is to the left as you enter the courtyard off of Pender Street. We also enjoyed the many markets for fruit, vegetables, dried food items, and other Oriental specialties. We sampled new Town Bakery and Restaurant's (Pender St) mooncakes with red bean paste, and enjoyed lunch at Phnom Penh Restaurant (on Georgia). Altogether worth a pleasant couple of hours. An easy walk to or from Gastown, too -- but avoid the area just north of Chinatown and east of Gastown, as others have mentioned.

title: BECAREFUL!
reviews: We tried to walk to Chinatown from Gastown and ended up on the WORSE streets in Vancouver. There were what seemed like 100s of homeless people and people doing drugs in the street right in front of us. Just becareful on how you get to Chinatown.

title: an interesting part of town
reviews: As a local , I have rarely ventured into this area . It has become part of my weekly walking routes . For tourists who do not have a Chinatown back home , this would be a very interesting place to explore for an hour or so . There are many good places to eat and a lot of stores selling souvenirs . It's fun to soak up the cultural aspects of the area . Be warned , it does border the worst section of Vancouver . I've never felt threatened , but as always , be aware of your surroundings and walk like you know where you are going

title: Great area!
reviews: Like the atmosphere and the food that is available in this area. Love the lights at night as well. It represents our area well.

title: Slightly less than average
reviews: It is just an average or even slightly less than average place to go.  Go there only when you really have no where to go or you rarely visit other Chinatown in North America.  Besides, stay with the few streets and don't go further north.  Restaurants are mostly average in quality except a few (especially the Vietnamese Restaurant selling Pho) are good.  If you want really good food, Richmond has the best Chinese food.  If you want to see Chinese related issue, there are not too many worth to go.

title: One of the least attractive Chinatown in North America
reviews: We went there on a Saturday afternoon, and there wasn't much of a buzz. The restaurant we went to was also quite average. It also looks like it's a dodgy neighbor that people tend to avoid.

title: Does not live up to the hype
reviews: We read about the market downtown and went to it on our first day in Vancouver.  The Food vendors were less than sanitary looking and the food was terrible.  The amount of vendors were small and comparing the vibrancy of Chinatown in New York compared to this version lead to this being a major disappointment.

title: Do not go
reviews: We were so disapointed when we visited this part of town. We saw China town in San Francisco. This part of town seemed dead and empty, whilst San Francisco was so alive and colorful! We left within the hour!

title: Great shopping, interesting sights
reviews: Liked the shopping and sights, friendly people, and the ambiance.  We went back three times and filled up our car with very reasonably priced things that we really liked and really can use - we generally don't buy much when we travel but we made an exception this time.

title: East meets West
reviews: An authentic working eastern community in a large metropolitan city. You literally feel like you are stepping into another world. Great place for local asian "Ex-Pats" to get a taste of home

title: My husbands favourite
reviews: The place goes on forever and there were some very unigue and interesting things in each store.  Came home with lots of good stuff.

title: Pretty typical as far as Chinatown's go
reviews: I have been here several times. The best thing about this place is the Dr Sun Yet Sen Japanese garden. Otherwise in the summertime there is a little night market that takes place on weekends that is interesting to go see.

title: Worth the time
reviews: Great tea shop on the main drag where the teach as well as sell.  Nice selection of stores, yes there is much that is just the usual visitor shops, but there is much more as well.  2-3 hours more than enough time.  Shopping is a large part of your trip here.

title: Great Spot for Tourists and Resident Alike
reviews: If you like real Chinese, not greasy chicken balls then this is one of the places to visit in downtown Vancouver. Authentic and delicious

title: If you've visited others
reviews: then this one is really going to disappoint, very run down and shabby. Fine if your going food shopping (i.e for cooking) but as for eating I doubt many of the places would pass a food inspection. Basically its a regular street in a run down area with a lot of grocery stores interspersed with a few tacky shops and a few restaurants.

title: Not great
reviews: If you want to see an authentic "old" time Chinatown, check out the one in Victoria!

title: A little lackluster.
reviews: But worth it all the same.  It just doesnt seem right to venture Vancouver and not hit Chinatown.  I think its worth a walk about.

title: Love China Town
reviews: This is a great place to spend an afternoon walking around looking at all the stuff you would never find in a glossy suburban mall. Pick a place and have Dim Sum... It is bound to be good

title: my first chinatown
reviews: I had heard some bad things about Chinatown in Vancouver (crime area, etc). But I had never been to a chinatown in any city so I decided to go. Even though I was walking by myself, I never felt ill at ease and felt safe. It was very interesting and everyone was friendly.

title: A shell of its former shell.
reviews: Chinatown has never been what you would call a classy place to spend time.  My memories of it from the 80s are of a child exploring a bustling yet dilapidated ethnic enclave in search of exotic ingredients and housewares, and perhaps a few shaomai if we were very good.  The enclave is still there, the dilapidated has more than kept up, but the bustle has been taken out of Chinatown by the more prosperous asian markets of Richmond.  Some places are still there just as I remeber them, but a good half of the shops are closed, and those that are open sell the same items as the shop up the street.  The curio shops have been killed by dollarama, and restaurants have all moved to better neigbourhoods or closed, and those that are left seem to be on the decline.  There are a few holdouts and a few obvious attempts at urban renewal, but this close to Skid Row, it will be a tough slog to gentrify.  If you loved Chinatown in the past, it will be a bit maudlin to see it now.  If you have never been before.... well, there are some things worth seeing.

title: Miss-able during a short trip
reviews: From my trip report: http://www.tripadvisor.com/GoListEditor-i30345-Trip_Report_Seattle_to_Bellingham_to.htmlAfter settling into the Delta hotel, it was already late afternoon. We decided to wander around Chinatown and then look for dinner. It was fun looking in a few stores and the Dr. Sun Yat Sen park. We didn't go into the Dr. Sun Yat Sen Classical Chinese Garden because it was expensive and not a strong interest for us.Compared to NYC and SF, this Chinatown didn't wow us. Maybe if we could have gone to the night market, it would have been more interesting.

title: Underdeveloped...
reviews: Not my kind of place.  Seems dirty...smelly...lots of junky stores selling lots of junk...

title: Horrible
reviews: If you are planning to go to Chinatown, make sure you don't bring any valuable items.  We ate lunch at Fleaco that is between Keeper and Main St, left our vehicle in a paid "so called" safe parking spot and end up having our computer, my son's game, back pack with school supplies and even the chips were stolen.  Asked for help from the staff and the security guard, they said that they cannot do anything about it.  I asked them to call the police since its their place but they've asked me to call the police instead.  Terrible place to visit and people are so rude.Not a safe place to visit.  I'd rather go to Lake Chelan where people are so friendly.

title: It's Chinatown Baby!
reviews: A lot of whiny, less adventurous tourists complain that Chinatown is too gritty.  Yes there are a few people with drug issues walking around - but that happens EVERYWHERE in Vancouver. Pender Street from Main to Cambie is a MUST!  You will pass several authentic Tea Houses on Pender St. and Dr. Sun Yet Sen's garden is a free attraction that was voted one of the most beautiful gardens on the world, it's small but amazing, like stepping into another time, right in urban Vancouver.  The skinniest building in the world 'Sam Kee' building now houses Jack Chow insurance.  All within a few blocks of each other on Pender St in Chinatown.This is one of the best places to see in Vancouver, if you miss it, you've missed part of what makes Vancouver the city it is today.

title: Take some time out for Chinatown.
reviews: I always love Chinatown. Just even if you like to shop for vegetables . I also like to look for nice scarfs. And I like to be there for the night market on the summer weekends. I feel I am in China a little bid and I love that..

title: Good food. Run-down feel.
reviews: China town is always interesting, with the unique sights and smells, and Vancouvers is one of the larger ones. Its a shame there was a run-down feeling in this area. Some of the scariest looking people I passed in Vancouver were in this China town. The kind of scary where the hair on the back of your neck stands up. We did enjoy hopping from small store to store, buying our favorites "to go" until we brought home a veritable feast: BBQ pork, Hum bao, Sticky Rice, Custard Buns. Mmmmm!

title: Certainly one of the more interesting
reviews: ...Chinatowns in north America, especially if you have a kitchen so you can cook yourself. The fresh produce markets are a must see.

title: Chinatown Vancouver BC Canada is PATHETIC
reviews: Seriously, don't go there for visit.  It is the pits and there are druggies, thiefs, and robbers just around the corners.  Walking there, I felt uneasy and unsafe.It is like a ghost town.  Their so-call Night market is the pits.  Chinatowns in San Francisco, NYC, Singapore are waaaaaaaay much better.And their so-called Dr. Sun Yat's Garden is a joke.  you pay so much for walking into a puny garden?!?  What a rip off.I can't believe people are THAT STUPID to give in and buy a house that looks like trashed dog house for $800k ~ $1 Million.  Toronto, LA, San Francisco, Seattle have decent looking houses for $500k.

title: Tastes, Sounds and views of far east in the far west
reviews: Vancouver chinatown has its' own smells,views and sounds - eat if you're not afraid, drink  and visit museums and gardens (recommended)avoid the tourist traps there : avoid buying cheap toys (made in china) in the market (you get the same one cheaper at home)Don;t let the influx of tourists spoil your visit.,

title: Stocking stuffers
reviews: I like shopping in Chinatown around Christmas. Lots of unique small, inexpensive gifts and of course a delicious feast of great Chinese food.

title: Had a good time.
reviews: Everyone was nice wherever we went,shopping was fun there and we found great deals. I wish I could remember where we had dinner because it was soo good I will be finnding it again next time if it takes all day. My son and I were so happy to find all the fresh fruit and veggie stands ,really welcome when we had been eating days of takeout,before china town.

title: Overpriced Junk
reviews: We walked around before the Saturday night market and went into a few stores.  The stores we went into were very overpriced, even for Vancouver.  There weren't really that many tables set up for the outside market.  There was some food for sale and some jewelry and clothes. I think you'd find better quality at the Dollarama.  It is easy to get to from the Stadium Chinatown sky train station.  We walked by one alley where there appeared to be a dead body behind the police who were standing around questioning people.  I wouldn't go back . . . ever.

title: Not like it used to be !
reviews: The last time we visited Chinatown was in 1980 and we were looking forward to see again this part of the city that we really enjoyed visiting ! Boy were we ever disappointed ! As the immagration from China (incl. Hong Kong ) had really increased over the past 20 years , we were expecting a more vibrant and rejuvunated part of the city but we found a downscaled area of the city with a lot of junkies , wanderers and not so clean streets !     Vancouver is a wonderful city but this is not anymore one of the major points of interest !

title: Always interesting
reviews: I was down to visit the Friday Night Market last Summer with my friend from Phoenix, AZ.  We enjoyed it, but it seems less authentic than it did 20 years ago down there, not sure why.

title: Worst part of vancouver
reviews: Dirty,run down, and full of the cities homeless drug addicts and prostitutes who are based on close by hastings street. The gardens were only highlight,once visited id leave that area and not return.

title: Wouldn't want to hang out at night
reviews: Yes there are druggies near there, we ended up on east hastings by mistake, holy crap is that a mess. But China town is interesting. It seems smaller than the last time i was there (20yrs ago). Interesting place and worth the visit.

title: Tradition Lives on
reviews: what can you say about one of North America's earliest Chinese settlement.  IT has been over taken by the street drug scene with lots of homeless but if you overlook this (they're harmless - sort of) you get a lot of history and traditional shopping.

title: Poop every where..
reviews: Human feces, drug addicts and bums cover the sidewalks,  over-priced plastic crap from China and people who look at you suspiciously in the stores. Avoid, day or night.

title: Chinatown in decline
reviews: Most restaurants I have frequented are gone or relocated.

title: You are not in Kansas anymore...
reviews: As we wandered the streets of Chinatown, our nose and eyes were definitely taking in new sensory experiences. As others have mentioned, you will find people asking for handouts but not in an aggressive or threatening manner.  Make sure that you stop and read about its history and don’t forget to walk the side streets. We went during the daytime and I don’t think we would feel comfortable walking at night. Stop at the entrance Millennium Gate..those gaping mouth lions once held highly polished marble balls. But just after its 2002 inauguration, they disappeared.  And where they are is a mystery.

title: An interesting part of Vancouver, too bad it is run down
reviews: This area of Vancouver is certainly interesting to walk about in, but in reality, there is limited things to do other than sight see, and with the Main and Hastings addicts, hookers, and (unfortunate) mentally ill that populate the area, it is not nearly as nice an area as it could be.I am note trying to address the current issues of society or suggest what is right or wrong, but simply want to say that this area is unfortunately very badly affected by this issue.I rate it average instead of poor, becuase, aside from this issue, it is still an interesting part of the city to check out.

title: Enjoy the ethnic experience
reviews: For some unique fun and exploration stop in Chinatown Vancouver. Check out the odd and the new, you never know what you might find. Its all in the experience... have fun with an open mind.

title: Tea anyone?
reviews: Our China Town is the second largest in North America. (San Francisco is #1). Here you can shop or meditate and learn about the cultural values. Many famous restaurants are here and dim sum is a must.

title: 2nd largest outside China
reviews: Great place, full of life, we used to brag that it was the 2nd largest China Town outside of China, but I think probably Richmond BC is now

title: fun and diversity
reviews: gives insight into the diversity of Vancouver and its wonderful Asian population.

title: Best Chinese food
reviews: Great place to go and try delious chinese food I suggest Kents kitchen on keefer  best deal going and very busy!

title: Great place for a walk and grab a bite of Chinese Cuisene.
reviews: Although not the busy place it used to be since Richmond has become the place for Asian business, it still has the history. Check out the markets and architecture. Then go for dim sum at one of the many restaurants. The International Village has my favourtie movie theatres.

title: A little bit of Dangertown
reviews: It's an interesting piece of Vancouver's history, but the area is on the dangerous side.  I'd never hang out there past 6pm.

title: A perfect outlet of the Chinese tradition
reviews: Vancouver oriental population has a perfect outlet in his Chinatown. Known as the second largest Chinatown after the one in San Francisco, it can be considered our direct connection to the orient. You can experience the Dr. Sun Yat-Sen Classical Chinese Garden or enjoy a Dim-sum the traditional Chinese food prepared in small bite-sized portions and served in small steamer baskets or have a seal with your name engraved in Chinese characters on a stone.

title: culture eye opener
reviews: great to wander in and out all the stores and taste the numerous barbeque tidbits from lots of restaurants.could easily spend a couple of hours here

title: Rundown
reviews: One of the most disappointing Chinatown in the world! Its run down, full of druggies, dirty, and... Chinatown has really moved to Richmond.

title: Worth a stroll through
reviews: My opinion is that Chinatown is a passe' construct!  When Chinese people were forced to live in this area, it may have been "interesting" to tour it.  But now that being Chinese is "all right" (!) and now that Chinese of all ethnic origins (Taiwanese, Hong Kongers, Shanghainese etc. etc.) are free to live wherever they wish (and can afford!), what's the point of this artificial construct?  If it's food you want, it's Richmond that has the best Chinese food bar none.  If it's shopping, you can come to Richmond too....and see the weird malls like Aberdeen (with it's hourly fountain shows...yes, fountains that sway to odd music!) and TN T and Yaohan (which was originally apanese-owned).

title: Vancouver Chinatown
reviews: Authentic chinese culture.  Went there with 2 chinese exchange students.  They explained the food that we did not recognize.  Fresh fish, shrimp etc. Lower price than anywhere else.

title: Needs some work to be what it used to.
reviews: It is hard to have a Chinatown in a city that has Chinese shops, businesses, and restaurants all over the city.  It isn't unique anymore.  Richmond is trying to create a bigger, better Chinatown.  It still is quite large.  From Taylor Street (West boundary) to Gore Avenue (East Boundary) total: 4 blocks.  Then from Hastings (North Boundary) to East Georgia (South Boundary) total: 3 blocks.The night market is not near the size as the one in Richmond, but still has some good stuff.Main and Hastings is a bad corner, but I've never felt in danger.  Might as well go if you are going to Gastown anyways.

title: Avoid
reviews: I consider myself to be a very seasoned traveler and very comfortable in most situations.    I went to Vancouver several years ago (2001) and wanted to see Chinatown.  We drove into the area and decided not to stay.   At this time, the area was overrun by homeless and drug addicts.  At one pt, I honestly wondered if we were in some type of leper colony.    We witnessed drug deals and people shooting up drugs just driving through in our car so I can't imagine walking around in the area and feeling safe.   It was a truly sad and heart breaking experience and I would personally encourage people to avoid this area.

title: Old Vancouver Chinatown a heritage
reviews: The old stores have such a charm to them and are so affordable.  Sadly some streets are being renovated and changed over to expensive boutique type stores.

title: It's shrinking but it's still cool.
reviews: We always try to stop in for a little BBQ pork when in the city. Duck is awesome too. My favorite BBQ place closed up but the same guy who worked there is at another place now and still always asks if you want "chop" for the pork. He's great. The fish markets are a good place to get Alaskan king crab when in season too.

title: Not for those with sensitive noses
reviews: Lots of traditional Chinese herbs and food, smells can be a bit overwhelming.  Interesting to explore with retail stores of traditional Chinese imports of furniture, knick knacks, and clothing.  A cheap visit.  Mostly pay parking.

title: And be sure to enjoy the many authentic dining options
reviews: A visit to the old downtown Chinatown and the new one in Richmond offers a very interesting view of changing times.  If you like Chinese food, either of the two offers more outstanding options than you can imagine!

title: Every Chinatown has its ups and downs
reviews: The parking in Chinatown is ridiculous. You can't find any anywhere. The food is delicious depending on where you go. New town Bakery is the best in town from what I have tried

title: A Vancouver standard
reviews: The Chinese made the rail road so we have had a china town when there were dirt roads in down town. Where other cities grew up with other races, we in Vancouver went to school and played with Chinese children. China town has been here since the rail road. Of course it has expanded and the herbalists are fairly new and have hugely expanded as you find more and more Caucasians going there to find alternate medicines. The food is still the same as when I was a child. Still love the Diamond upstairs for it's dim sum.  Could be a mainly all day trip if you include the Sun Yat-Sen gardens which are beautiful.

title: Disappointing
reviews: Mainly food shops and ticky tacky stuff. Just not very interesting anymore, not really unique as it once was.

title: Disappointing
reviews: For some reason i was expecting a large chinatown as there is a strong asian community in vancouver. This Chinatown was on 2 x 3 blocks, that did not look too much different from the rest of vwncouver. The dried fish shops were nice for my photo album, but that's about it. Nothing like the one in NYC, nor San Francisco. Also pay attention to how you get there since you may walk through some shady neighbourhoods to get there. Better beware.

title: Not Exciting
reviews: A bit grungey, not in the nicest part of town. Not something I recommend. I personally don't go there.

title: charming
reviews: Not bad. A lot like Chinatowns in other cities, but still a charming place. The shops here are cheap and fun to explore.

title: Large China town
reviews: We ate shopped and took in the sites and sounds. I really enjoyed this Chinatown and I have visited many. They even had a large Chinese pharmacy.

title: Depressing Place
reviews: I've never been to such a sad looking Chinatown. Run down and half the shops boarded up. Few places to eat either. Chinatowns are usually the place to get great food and a good price, not this one! The scariest part is the street life, harmless I think but depressing. Oh Vancouver how could you let this happen!

title: TERRIBLE AND HORRFYING EXPERIENCE
reviews: It was my very first time to visit Vancouver, Canada and was so excited. Though my husband has gone there before, he suggested that we all all first go to Chinatown to buy our favorite local fruit back home called lanzones, so we can bring it to the park. It was almost 11:00am and we parked at  this "they say safe parking lot". At around 1:00pm we went back to the parking lot and was horrified to find out that our van got broken into. The police where even about to tow our van had we not returned immediately. I can not even imagine having this happened in broad day light and all they can say is "I am sorry this has happened". The worst part is cleaning the mess and had to go back to Seattle right after the incident with some kind of vinyl that covered our back seat window travelling at 60 mph. Though the "bad guys" did not get anything except for a bag with clothes, the inconvenience, stress and spoiling the fun made me think of not ever going back to Chinatown in Vancouver, Canada.

title: Total dump! Dress down and keep your valuables at home!
reviews: If you want to see a ton of panhandlers and drug addicts then china town is for you! Too bad pepper spray is illegal in Canada because you'll be batting these creeps away. If you like to visit a Chinese area where you won't get mugged go to minerou ave (google hilton Vancouver airport)

title: What a weird area
reviews: On a Friday morning, we decided to hit Vancouver downtown as a couple of things were highly recommended by my guide. One of them was Chinatown. So we park close to this area and things got really weird.
